DR replica remains passive unless primary region fails.

Performance Considerations:

HA adds overhead:
- Synchronous replication increases write latency
- Additional replicas increase storage costs
- Network traffic between replicas

Benchmark performance:

nova deploy benchmark <deployment-id> --compare-single-replica

Failover Testing:

Test failover behavior:

nova deploy ha-test <deployment-id> --simulate-failure

Simulates replica failure, verifies automatic failover.

title: Managing Multiple Profiles
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 introduced profile support for managing multiple accounts, organizations, or environments from a single installation. Profiles eliminate the need to repeatedly authenticate when switching contexts.

Profiles store authentication credentials, default settings, and frequently used configurations separately. Each profile has a name and can be activated independently.

List existing profiles:

nova profiles list

The active profile is marked with an asterisk.

Create a new profile:

nova profiles create work

This creates an empty profile named "work". Authenticate with this profile:

nova auth login --profile work

Provide credentials for your work account. These credentials are stored under the work profile only.

Switch between profiles:

nova profiles use work

All subsequent commands use the work profile's credentials and settings until you switch again.

Create additional profiles for different contexts:

nova profiles create personal
nova auth login --profile personal

nova profiles create staging
nova auth login --profile staging

View which profile is active:

nova profiles current

Each profile can have custom default settings:

nova settings set --profile work default.region us-east-1
nova settings set --profile personal default.region eu-west-2

When creating deployments without specifying a region, NovaCLI uses the active profile's default.

Temporarily use a different profile without switching:

nova --profile personal deploy list

This executes a single command with the personal profile while keeping work as the active profile.

Rename a profile:

nova profiles rename staging production

Delete a profile:

nova profiles delete old-account

This removes stored credentials and settings but doesn't affect deployments created with that profile.

Export profile configuration for backup or sharing:

nova profiles export work --output work-profile.yaml

Import on another machine:

nova profiles import work-profile.yaml

Profile data is stored in ~/.novacli/profiles/ with separate directories for each profile. Credentials are encrypted at rest.

For automation and CI/CD, avoid profiles. Use environment variables instead:

NOVA_API_TOKEN=<token> nova deploy create --name ci-build

title: Configuration File Migration: YAML to TOML
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 replaced YAML configuration with TOML for improved clarity and type safety. This guide explains the migration process and highlights key differences.

Automatic Migration:

The migration tool automatically converts YAML to TOML:

nova config migrate --from-version 2.0

This command:
1. Reads existing ~/.nova/config.yaml
2. Converts to TOML format
3. Writes to ~/.nova/config.toml
4. Backs up original YAML file
5. Validates new configuration

Manual Migration:

For custom or complex configurations, manual migration may be preferred.

YAML Example (v2.x):
yaml
defaults:
  region: us-east
  size: large
  backup_enabled: true

api:
  endpoint: https://api.nova.io
  timeout: 30

logging:
  level: info
  file: ~/.nova/logs/cli.log


TOML Equivalent (v3.x):
toml
[defaults]
region = "us-east"
size = "large"
backup_enabled = true

[api]
endpoint = "https://api.nova.io"
timeout = 30

[logging]
level = "info"
file = "~/.nova/logs/cli.log"


Key Differences:

Section Headers:
- YAML: section:
- TOML: [section]

String Values:
- YAML: Quotes optional for simple strings
- TOML: Quotes required for strings

Booleans:
- YAML: true, false, yes, no
- TOML: true, false only

Arrays:
- YAML: - item1n  - item2
- TOML: ["item1", "item2"]

Nested Configuration:

YAML nested structure:
yaml
deployment:
  production:
    region: us-east
    size: large


TOML nested structure:
toml
[deployment.production]
region = "us-east"
size = "large"


Validating Migrated Configuration:

Validate syntax and values:

nova config validate

Check specific settings:

nova config get defaults.region

Common Migration Issues:

Issue: Boolean conversion errors
Cause: YAML yes/no not valid TOML
Solution: Migration tool converts to true/false automatically

Issue: Multiline strings
Cause: Different multiline syntax
Solution: TOML uses triple quotes for multiline strings

Issue: Comments
Cause: Comment syntax differs
Solution: YAML uses #, TOML uses #. Migration preserves comments.

Reverting to YAML:

If needed, keep v2.x CLI installed alongside v3.x:

alias nova2='/usr/local/bin/nova-v2'
alias nova3='/usr/local/bin/nova-v3'

Both can coexist using separate configuration files.

title: Backups API Endpoints
body:
The Backups API manages automated and manual backups for deployments. This reference covers backup creation, restoration, and management endpoints.

List Backups:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups

Query parameters:
- type: Filter by type (auto, manual)
- limit: Results per page
- offset: Pagination offset

Example:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer API_KEY" 
  "https://api.novacli.io/v1/deployments/dep-abc123/backups"

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "backup-xyz789",
      "type": "auto",
      "size_bytes": 1073741824,
      "created_at": "2024-09-15T02:00:00Z",
      "expires_at": "2024-10-15T02:00:00Z",
      "status": "completed"
    }
  ]
}

Get Backup Details:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}

Returns detailed backup metadata including:
- Backup size
- Compression ratio
- Backup duration
- Data integrity checksum

Create Manual Backup:

POST /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups

Request body:

{
  "name": "pre-migration-backup",
  "description": "Backup before major schema migration",
  "retention_days": 90
}

Response (201 Created):

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": "backup-abc123",
    "status": "in_progress",
    "estimated_completion": "2024-09-15T10:45:00Z"
  }
}

Restore from Backup:

POST /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}/restore

Request body (optional):

{
  "target_deployment_id": "dep-different",
  "verify_before_restore": true
}

If target_deployment_id omitted, restores to source deployment.

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "restore_id": "restore-xyz789",
    "status": "in_progress",
    "estimated_completion": "2024-09-15T11:00:00Z"
  }
}

Delete Backup:

DELETE /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}

Permanently deletes backup.

Response (204 No Content)

Download Backup:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}/download

Returns pre-signed URL for backup download:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "download_url": "https://backups.novacli.io/...",
    "expires_at": "2024-09-15T12:00:00Z"
  }
}

Verify Backup Integrity:

POST /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}/verify

Validates backup integrity without restoration.

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "valid": true,
    "checksum": "sha256:abc123...",
    "size_bytes": 1073741824
  }
}

Configure Backup Schedule:

PUT /deployments/{deployment_id}/backup-schedule

Request body:

{
  "enabled": true,
  "frequency": "daily",
  "time": "02:00",
  "timezone": "UTC",
  "retention_days": 7
}

Get Backup Schedule:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/backup-schedule

Restore Status:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/restores/{restore_id}

Check restoration progress:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": "restore-xyz789",
    "status": "in_progress",
    "progress_percent": 45,
    "estimated_completion": "2024-09-15T11:00:00Z"
  }
}

Copy Backup:

POST /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/{backup_id}/copy

Copy backup to different region:

Request body:

{
  "target_region": "eu-west-1"
}

Export Backup Metadata:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/backups/export

Exports backup inventory as CSV or JSON.

title: API Gateway Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 includes an integrated API gateway for managing external API access to deployments. This guide covers gateway configuration, rate limiting, and authentication.

Gateway Activation:

Enable API gateway:

[api_gateway]
enabled = true
port = 8443
bind_address = "0.0.0.0"

Gateway proxies requests to backend deployments.

Route Configuration:

Define API routes:

[api_gateway.routes]

[[api_gateway.routes.route]]
path = "/api/v1/deployments"
backend = "http://deployment-service:8080"
methods = ["GET", "POST"]
authentication_required = true

[[api_gateway.routes.route]]
path = "/api/v1/metrics"
backend = "http://metrics-service:9090"
methods = ["GET"]
authentication_required = false

Path Rewriting:

Rewrite paths before forwarding:

[api_gateway.rewrite]
"/api/v1/" = "/internal/v1/"
"/public/" = "/"

Upstream requests use rewritten paths.

Load Balancing:

Distribute across multiple backends:

[[api_gateway.routes.route]]
path = "/api/v1/deployments"
backends = [
  "http://backend1:8080",
  "http://backend2:8080",
  "http://backend3:8080"
]
load_balance_strategy = "round_robin"  # or "least_connections", "ip_hash"

Health Checks:

Monitor backend health:

[api_http://gateway.health_checks]
enabled = true
interval = 10  # seconds
timeout = 5
unhealthy_threshold = 3
healthy_threshold = 2
path = "/health"

Unhealthy backends excluded from rotation.

Request Rate Limiting:

Limit request rates per client:

[api_gateway.rate_limiting]
enabled = true
requests_per_minute = 100
burst_size = 20
identifier = "ip_address"  # or "api_key", "jwt_subject"

Tier-based limits:

[api_gateway.rate_limiting.tiers]
free = 60
basic = 300
premium = 1000

Authentication:

Multiple authentication methods:

[api_gateway.authentication]

[[api_gateway.authentication.jwt]]
enabled = true
secret = "${JWT_SECRET}"
token_header = "Authorization"
token_prefix = "Bearer"

[[api_gateway.authentication.api_key]]
enabled = true
header = "X-API-Key"
query_param = "api_key"

CORS Configuration:

Configure cross-origin requests:

[api_gateway.cors]
enabled = true
allowed_origins = ["https://app.company.com", "https://dashboard.company.com"]
allowed_methods = ["GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE"]
allowed_headers = ["Content-Type", "Authorization"]
max_age = 3600

Request/Response Transformation:

Modify requests and responses:

[api_gateway.transformations]

[[api_gateway.transformations.request]]
add_headers = {"X-Gateway" = "NovaCLI"}
remove_headers = ["X-Internal"]

[[api_gateway.transformations.response]]
add_headers = {"X-Response-Time" = "${response_time_ms}"}

Circuit Breaker:

Prevent cascading failures:

[api_gateway.circuit_breaker]
enabled = true
failure_threshold = 5
timeout = 10  # seconds
reset_timeout = 60

Opens circuit after consecutive failures.

Request Logging:

Log all gateway requests:

[api_gateway.logging]
enabled = true
log_headers = true
log_body = false
log_response_time = true

Caching:

Cache responses at gateway:

[api_gateway.cache]
enabled = true
ttl = 60  # seconds
cache_methods = ["GET"]
cache_status_codes = [200]

Retry Policy:

Retry failed requests:

[api_gateway.retry]
enabled = true
max_attempts = 3
retry_on_status = [502, 503, 504]
backoff_strategy = "exponential"

WebSocket Support:

Proxy WebSocket connections:

[api_gateway.websocket]
enabled = true
upgrade_header = "Upgrade"
connection_header = "Connection"

Metrics and Monitoring:

Expose gateway metrics:

[api_gateway.metrics]
enabled = true
request_count = true
response_time = true
error_rate = true
active_connections = true

title: Migrating Custom Scripts and Automation
body:
Organizations using custom scripts and automation with NovaCLI must update these tools when migrating to v3.x. This guide identifies common patterns requiring updates.

Command Name Changes:

Primary changes in v3.0:

v2.x: nova config <subcommand>
v3.x: nova settings <subcommand>

v2.x commands still work with deprecation warnings until v4.0.

Updating Scripts:

Find affected commands:

grep -r "nova config" /path/to/scripts/

Update with sed:

sed -i 's/nova config/nova settings/g' /path/to/scripts/*.sh

Output Format Changes:

JSON output structure is unchanged. Scripts parsing JSON output require no modifications.

Human-readable output may differ. Scripts parsing human-readable output should switch to --format json.

Before (v2.x):
nova deploy list | awk '{print $1}'

After (v3.x):
nova deploy list --format json | jq -r '.[].id'

Environment Variables:

All v2.x environment variables work in v3.x:
- NOVA_API_TOKEN
- NOVA_API_ENDPOINT
- NOVA_CONFIG_PATH
- NOVA_LOG_LEVEL

New v3.x variables:
- NOVA_OUTPUT_FORMAT: Default output format (json, yaml, table)
- NOVA_TIMEOUT: Global operation timeout

Exit Codes:

Exit codes remain consistent:
- 0: Success
- 1: General error
- 2: Invalid usage
- 3: Authentication error
- 4: Resource not found

API Compatibility:

REST API v3 is fully compatible with v2 API calls. Existing API integrations work without modification.

New v3 endpoints provide enhanced functionality but are optional.

CI/CD Pipeline Updates:

GitHub Actions example:

yaml
steps:
  - name: Install NovaCLI
    run: |
      curl -sSL https://install.nova.io | bash
      nova --version
  
  - name: Authenticate
    run: nova auth login --token $ secrets.NOVA_API_TOKEN 
  
  - name: Deploy
    run: nova deploy upgrade $ vars.DEPLOYMENT_ID  --version 3.1


No changes needed for v3.x compatibility.

Testing Automation:

Create test script:

bash
#!/bin/bash
set -e

# Test deployment creation
nova deploy create --name test-migration --size small

# Test configuration
nova settings get test-deployment

# Test cleanup
nova deploy delete test-deployment --confirm

echo "All tests passed"


Run against v3.x test environment before production migration.

Documenting Changes:

Maintain migration log:
- Scripts updated
- Changes made
- Testing results
- Rollback procedures

Informs future maintenance and troubleshooting.

title: Regions API Reference
Custom Command Aliases
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 allows defining custom command aliases to simplify common workflows and reduce typing. This guide covers alias creation, management, and best practices.

Basic Alias Definition:

Define aliases in configuration:

[aliases]
ls = "deploy list"
stat = "deploy stats"
logs = "logs tail"

Use aliases like built-in commands:

nova ls
nova stat <deployment-id>
nova logs <deployment-id>

Aliases with Arguments:

Pass arguments through to underlying command:

[aliases]
quick-deploy = "deploy create --size small --region us-east-1"

Invoke with additional arguments:

nova quick-deploy --name my-deployment

Expands to:

nova deploy create --size small --region us-east-1 --name my-deployment

Parameterized Aliases:

Use placeholders for dynamic values:

[aliases]
restart = "deploy stop $1 && deploy start $1"
scale = "deploy update $1 --size $2"

Positional parameters:

nova restart my-deployment
nova scale my-deployment large

Chained Commands:

Execute multiple commands sequentially:

[aliases]
full-status = "deploy list && deploy stats $1 && logs tail $1 --lines 20"

Commands separated by && execute if previous succeeds.

Conditional Execution:

Execute based on success or failure:

[aliases]
safe-restart = "deploy backup-create $1 && deploy restart $1 || echo Restart failed"

|| executes right side if left fails.

Shell Command Integration:

Execute shell commands within aliases:

[aliases]
local-backup = "!tar czf backup-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz /var/lib/nova"

! prefix indicates shell command, not NovaCLI command.

Environment Variable Substitution:

Reference environment variables:

[aliases]
prod-deploy = "deploy create --config ${PROD_CONFIG_PATH} --env production"

Variables expand at execution time.

Global vs Profile Aliases:

Global aliases available in all profiles:

[aliases]
status = "deploy list"

Profile-specific aliases:

nova settings set --profile production alias.quick-restart "deploy restart $1 --force"

Alias Listing:

View defined aliases:

nova alias list

Displays alias name and expansion.

Alias Removal:

Delete alias:

nova alias remove quick-deploy

Or edit configuration file directly.

Alias Precedence:

Resolution order:
1. Built-in commands
2. Profile-specific aliases
3. Global aliases
4. Plugins

Aliases cannot override built-in commands.

Sharing Aliases:

Teams can standardize aliases:

# team-aliases.toml
[aliases]
deploy-prod = "deploy create --config prod.toml --backup-before"
deploy-staging = "deploy create --config staging.toml"

Import shared aliases:

nova settings load --merge team-aliases.toml

Alias Best Practices:

- Keep aliases short and memorable
- Document complex aliases in comments
- Avoid deeply nested alias chains
- Test aliases before sharing with team
- Use descriptive names for infrequently used aliases

Debugging Aliases:

Show alias expansion without executing:

nova alias show quick-deploy

Displays full command that would execute.

title: Rolling Back Failed Migrations
body:
Migration rollback procedures help recover from unexpected issues during v2.x to v3.x migration. This guide covers rollback strategies and execution.

When to Rollback:

Consider rollback if:
- Deployment health checks fail after upgrade
- Performance degradation exceeds 20%
- Critical functionality breaks
- Data inconsistencies appear
- Upgrade exceeds maximum time window

Quick Rollback Decision Matrix:

Impact Severity vs Time Elapsed:
- Critical + <1 hour: Rollback immediately
- Critical + >1 hour: Investigate, rollback if no fix within 30 min
- High + <2 hours: Attempt fix, rollback if unsuccessful
- Medium: Monitor, schedule maintenance for fix
- Low: Document, fix in next maintenance window

Pre-Rollback Checks:

Before rolling back:
1. Capture logs and error messages
2. Document the issue thoroughly
3. Verify backup integrity
4. Notify stakeholders
5. Ensure rollback window availability

CLI Rollback:

Rollback CLI to v2.x:

Linux/macOS:
curl -sSL https://install.nova.io/v2 | bash

Windows:
Download v2.x installer from https://downloads.nova.io/v2/

Verify rollback:
nova --version
# Should show v2.x

Deployment Rollback:

Rollback individual deployment:

nova deploy rollback deployment-id --target-version 2.6

Rollback completes in 2-5 minutes using previous version snapshot.

Batch rollback:

for deployment in $(cat deployment-list.txt); do
  nova deploy rollback $deployment --target-version 2.6
  echo "Rolled back $deployment"
done

Configuration Rollback:

Restore v2.x YAML configuration:

mv ~/.nova/config.toml ~/.nova/config.toml.backup
mv ~/.nova/config.yaml.backup ~/.nova/config.yaml

Verify:
nova config validate

Verifying Rollback Success:

Post-rollback checks:
1. Verify CLI version
2. Test deployment connectivity
3. Run health checks
4. Verify functionality
5. Monitor for 1 hour

Health check:
nova deploy health deployment-id

Data Integrity:

Verify data integrity after rollback:

1. Run integrity checks:
   nova deploy check-integrity deployment-id

2. Compare record counts
3. Validate critical data
4. Test application functionality

Post-Rollback Actions:

1. Document rollback reason
2. Analyze failure cause
3. Update migration plan
4. Schedule retry after fixes
5. Communicate status to stakeholders

Preventing Future Rollbacks:

Improve success rate:
- More thorough testing in staging
- Gradual rollout (start with non-critical deployments)
- Extended monitoring periods
- Better rollback criteria definition
- Improved team training

Re-attempting Migration:

After rollback and fixes:
1. Wait minimum 24 hours
2. Review and address root cause
3. Re-test in staging
4. Update migration procedures
5. Schedule new migration window
6. Execute with lessons learned

title: Billing and Usage API
body:
The Billing API provides access to billing information, usage metrics, and invoice management. This reference covers billing queries, payment methods, and cost analysis.

Get Current Usage:

GET /billing/usage

Query parameters:
- start_date: ISO date (default: beginning of current month)
- end_date: ISO date (default: today)
- group_by: Grouping dimension (deployment, region, resource_type)

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "period": {
      "start": "2024-09-01",
      "end": "2024-09-15"
    },
    "total_cost": 1250.75,
    "currency": "USD",
    "breakdown": [
      {
        "resource_type": "compute",
        "usage_hours": 720,
        "cost": 720.00
      },
      {
        "resource_type": "storage",
        "usage_gb_hours": 150000,
        "cost": 450.00
      },
      {
        "resource_type": "data_transfer",
        "usage_gb": 500,
        "cost": 80.75
      }
    ]
  }
}

Get Usage by Deployment:

GET /billing/usage/deployments

Breakdown costs by deployment:

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "deployment_id": "dep-abc123",
      "deployment_name": "production-api",
      "cost": 850.50,
      "compute_cost": 600.00,
      "storage_cost": 200.00,
      "transfer_cost": 50.50
    }
  ]
}

List Invoices:

GET /billing/invoices

Query parameters:
- status: Filter by status (paid, pending, overdue)
- year: Filter by year
- limit: Results per page

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "inv-abc123",
      "number": "INV-2024-09-001",
      "date": "2024-09-01",
      "due_date": "2024-09-15",
      "status": "paid",
      "total": 1500.00,
      "currency": "USD",
      "paid_at": "2024-09-03T10:00:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

Get Invoice:

GET /billing/invoices/{invoice_id}

Detailed invoice with line items.

Download Invoice:

GET /billing/invoices/{invoice_id}/download

Returns PDF invoice download URL.

Payment Methods:

GET /billing/payment-methods

List saved payment methods:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "pm-abc123",
      "type": "card",
      "card": {
        "brand": "visa",
        "last4": "4242",
        "exp_month": 12,
        "exp_year": 2025
      },
      "is_default": true
    }
  ]
}

Add Payment Method:

POST /billing/payment-methods

Request body:

{
  "type": "card",
  "token": "tok_visa_4242"  # From Stripe.js or similar
}

Update Default Payment Method:

PUT /billing/payment-methods/{method_id}/default

Delete Payment Method:

DELETE /billing/payment-methods/{method_id}

Billing Settings:

GET /billing/settings

Retrieve billing configuration:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "billing_email": "mailto:billing@company.com",
    "billing_address": {
      "line1": "123 Main St",
      "city": "San Francisco",
      "state": "CA",
      "postal_code": "94105",
      "country": "US"
    },
    "tax_id": "12-3456789"
  }
}

Update Billing Settings:

PUT /billing/settings

Cost Forecast:

GET /billing/forecast

Query parameters:
- months: Forecast horizon (1-12)

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "current_month_projection": 2500.00,
    "next_month_forecast": 2600.00,
    "confidence": 0.85
  }
}

Usage Alerts:

POST /billing/alerts

Create spending alert:

Request body:

{
  "threshold": 1000.00,
  "period": "monthly",
  "channels": ["email"]
}

Export Usage Data:

GET /billing/usage/export

Query parameters:
- format: Export format (csv, json)
- start_date: ISO date
- end_date: ISO date

Credits and Discounts:

GET /billing/credits

View account credits:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "balance": 100.00,
    "currency": "USD",
    "expires_at": "2024-12-31"
  }
}

title: Regional Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 supports multi-region deployments with region-specific configuration. This guide covers configuring region preferences, latency optimization, and data residency.

Default Region:

Set preferred deployment region:

[regions]
default = "us-east-1"
fallback = "us-west-2"

All deployments use default unless overridden.

Available Regions:

NovaCLI supports these regions:

North America:
- us-east-1 (Virginia)
- us-west-2 (Oregon)
- ca-central-1 (Canada)

Europe:
- eu-west-1 (Ireland)
- eu-central-1 (Frankfurt)

Asia Pacific:
- ap-southeast-1 (Singapore)
- ap-northeast-1 (Tokyo)

Query available regions:

nova regions list

Region-Specific Settings:

Configure per-region overrides:

[http://regions.us-east-1]
availability_zones = ["us-east-1a", "us-east-1b", "us-east-1c"]
default_size = "large"
backup_region = "us-west-2"

[http://regions.eu-central-1]
availability_zones = ["eu-central-1a", "eu-central-1b"]
default_size = "medium"
backup_region = "eu-west-1"

Multi-Region Deployments:

Deploy to multiple regions:

nova deploy create-multi 
  --name global-app 
  --regions us-east-1,eu-west-1,ap-southeast-1 
  --replication synchronous

Replication modes:
- synchronous: All regions updated simultaneously
- asynchronous: Primary updates immediately, replicas eventually

Region Selection Strategy:

Automatic region selection:

[regions.selection]
strategy = "latency"  # or "cost", "compliance"
latency_threshold_ms = 100

Latency strategy selects nearest region.

Data Residency:

Enforce data residency requirements:

[regions.compliance]
data_residency_regions = ["eu-west-1", "eu-central-1"]
prohibited_regions = ["us-east-1"]

EU data stays in EU for GDPR compliance.

Cross-Region Traffic:

Configure cross-region routing:

[regions.routing]
cross_region_enabled = true
prefer_local_region = true
failover_to_nearest = true

Fails over to nearest healthy region.

Region Affinity:

Pin users to specific regions:

[regions.affinity]
enabled = true
affinity_key = "user_id"
sticky_region = true

Same user always routed to same region.

Latency Monitoring:

Monitor inter-region latency:

[regions.monitoring]
latency_checks = true
check_interval = 60  # seconds
alert_threshold_ms = 200

Region Costs:

View region pricing:

nova regions pricing

Compare costs:

nova deploy cost-estimate 
  --size large 
  --regions us-east-1,eu-west-1

Region Failover:

Configure automatic failover:

[regions.failover]
auto_failover = true
failover_threshold = 3  # consecutive failures
failover_delay = 30  # seconds

Test failover:

nova deploy failover-test <deployment-id>

Region Quotas:

View region quotas:

nova regions quota us-east-1

Region limits:
- max_deployments
- max_connections
- max_storage_gb

Region Maintenance:

Scheduled maintenance windows:

nova regions maintenance

Displays upcoming maintenance by region.

Migrate regions:

nova deploy migrate <deployment-id> --to-region eu-west-1

Region Performance:

Benchmark region performance:

nova regions benchmark --regions us-east-1,us-west-2

Measures latency, throughput, and IOPS.

Geographic Load Balancing:

Route to nearest region:

[regions.geo_lb]
enabled = true
routing_policy = "geoproximity"
health_check_enabled = true

DNS Configuration:

Configure global DNS:

[regions.dns]
global_endpoint = "http://global.app.company.com"
regional_endpoints = true
ttl = 60

title: Database Schema Changes During Migration
body:
Deployment upgrades may include schema changes requiring special handling. This guide covers schema migration patterns and best practices for NovaCLI version upgrades.

Understanding Schema Changes:

Schema changes include:
- New columns or tables
- Modified column types
- Index additions or modifications
- Constraint changes
- Default value updates

Major version upgrades (v1v2, v2v3) may include schema changes. Minor versions (v3.0v3.1) rarely change schemas.

Automatic Schema Migration:

NovaCLI handles most schema changes automatically during deployment upgrade:

nova deploy upgrade deployment-id --version 3.0

During upgrade:
1. Deployment enters maintenance mode
2. Schema changes applied
3. Data migrated to new schema
4. Indexes rebuilt
5. Deployment returns to normal operation

Manual Schema Validation:

Before upgrading, validate schema compatibility:

nova deploy validate-upgrade deployment-id --target-version 3.0

This dry-run identifies potential issues:
- Incompatible data types
- Constraint violations
- Missing required data
- Space requirements

Handling Large Deployments:

Schema changes on large deployments (>500GB) require extended time:

1. Estimate migration time:
   nova deploy estimate-upgrade deployment-id --target-version 3.0

2. Schedule adequate maintenance window

3. Increase timeout:
   nova deploy upgrade deployment-id --version 3.0 --timeout 7200

Data Type Migrations:

Some upgrades change column data types. Example: v2.0 changed timestamp storage from UNIX epoch to ISO-8601.

Automatic conversion handles:
- Numeric to string conversions
- Timestamp format changes
- Boolean representation changes

Backup Before Schema Changes:

Always backup before schema-changing upgrades:

nova backup create deployment-id --label "pre-v3-upgrade"

Verify backup:
nova backup verify backup-id

Rolling Back Schema Changes:

If upgrade fails mid-schema-change, automatic rollback restores previous schema:

nova deploy rollback deployment-id

Rollback works if:
- Migration hasn't completed
- Pre-upgrade snapshot exists
- No manual schema changes made during migration

Testing Schema Migrations:

Test schema changes in staging:

1. Clone production to staging:
   nova deploy clone production-id --name staging-upgrade-test

2. Upgrade clone:
   nova deploy upgrade staging-upgrade-test --version 3.0

3. Verify functionality

4. Delete test clone:
   nova deploy delete staging-upgrade-test

Post-Migration Validation:

After schema migration, validate data integrity:

1. Row counts:
   nova deploy query deployment-id --query "SELECT COUNT() FROM critical_table"

2. Data samples:
   nova deploy query deployment-id --query "SELECT  FROM users LIMIT 10"

3. Application testing:
   Run end-to-end application tests

Performance After Schema Changes:

Schema changes may affect performance temporarily:
- Index rebuilds in progress
- Query plan updates
- Cache invalidation

Monitor performance for 24 hours post-upgrade.

title: API Rate Limit Tiers and Pricing
body:
NovaCLI API access is tiered based on subscription plans with corresponding rate limits and features. This reference covers plan tiers, pricing, and enterprise options.

Pricing Tiers:

Free Tier:
- Cost: $0/month
- Rate limit: 100 requests/hour
- Burst: None
- Deployments: 1 active
- Support: Community
- Features: Basic API access

Basic Tier:
- Cost: $29/month
- Rate limit: 1,000 requests/hour
- Burst: 100 requests
- Deployments: 5 active
- Support: Email (48h response)
- Features: All API endpoints, webhooks

Pro Tier:
- Cost: $99/month
- Rate limit: 10,000 requests/hour
- Burst: 500 requests
- Deployments: 25 active
- Support: Priority email (12h response)
- Features: GraphQL API, advanced metrics, SLA

Enterprise Tier:
- Cost: Custom pricing
- Rate limit: Custom (negotiable)
- Burst: Custom
- Deployments: Unlimited
- Support: Dedicated account manager, 24/7 phone
- Features: All features, custom integrations, SSO

Rate Limit Details:

Hourly limits:
- Free: 100 requests per hour
- Basic: 1,000 requests per hour
- Pro: 10,000 requests per hour
- Enterprise: Custom

Minute limits:
- Free: 10 requests per minute
- Basic: 50 requests per minute
- Pro: 200 requests per minute
- Enterprise: Custom

Burst allowance:
- Accumulated during idle periods
- Used during traffic spikes
- Replenishes at tier rate
- Free tier has no burst

Endpoint-Specific Limits:

Write operations (all tiers):
- POST /deployments: 10 per hour
- DELETE /deployments: 5 per hour
- POST /backups/restore: 3 per hour

Read operations:
- Use standard tier limits
- No additional restrictions

Upgrade Benefits:

Free  Basic:
- 10x rate limit increase
- Burst handling
- 4 additional deployments
- Webhook support
- Email support

Basic  Pro:
- 10x rate limit increase
- 5x burst capacity
- 20 additional deployments
- GraphQL API access
- Advanced metrics
- Priority support
- 99.9% SLA

Pro  Enterprise:
- Custom rate limits
- Unlimited deployments
- Dedicated support
- Custom integrations
- SSO/SAML
- Compliance certifications
- Volume discounts

Pricing Examples:

Small startup:
- 5 deployments
- 500 API calls/hour
- Recommendation: Basic ($29/month)

Growing company:
- 15 deployments
- 5,000 API calls/hour
- GraphQL needed
- Recommendation: Pro ($99/month)

Enterprise:
- 100+ deployments
- 50,000+ API calls/hour
- Compliance requirements
- Recommendation: Enterprise (custom pricing)

Overage Charges:

Rate limit exceeded:
- Free: API returns 429, no overages
- Basic: Soft limit, $10 per 1,000 additional requests
- Pro: Soft limit, $5 per 1,000 additional requests
- Enterprise: Negotiated in contract

Deployment overages:
- Basic: $5 per additional deployment/month
- Pro: $3 per additional deployment/month
- Enterprise: Included or negotiated

Billing:

Monthly billing:
- Charged on signup date
- Pro-rated for mid-month changes
- Automatic renewal
- Cancel anytime

Annual billing:
- 2 months free (Basic: $290/year)
- 2 months free (Pro: $990/year)
- No refunds for early cancellation

Payment methods:
- Credit card
- ACH (Pro and Enterprise only)
- Invoice (Enterprise only)
- Wire transfer (Enterprise only)

Usage Monitoring:

View current usage:

nova billing usage --current-month

Output:
Plan: Pro
Rate limit: 10,000/hour
Current usage: 3,450/hour (34.5%)
Deployments: 12/25 (48%)
Overage charges: $0

Set alerts:

nova billing alert create 
  --threshold 80% 
  --channel email

Plan Comparison:

Compare features:

| Feature | Free | Basic | Pro | Enterprise |
|---------|------|-------|-----|------------|
| API rate limit | 100/h | 1K/h | 10K/h | Custom |
| GraphQL |  |  |  |  |
| Webhooks |  |  |  |  |
| SLA |  |  | 99.9% | 99.99% |
| Support | Community | Email | Priority | Dedicated |

Upgrade Process:

Self-service upgrade:

nova billing upgrade --plan pro

Effect:
- Immediate rate limit increase
- Pro-rated billing
- New features activated

Downgrade:

nova billing downgrade --plan basic

Effect:
- Takes effect next billing cycle
- Rate limits reduced at renewal
- No pro-rated refund

Enterprise Sales:

Contact information:
Email: mailto:enterprise@novacli.io
Phone: +1-555-0100
Schedule call: https://novacli.io/enterprise

Typical enterprise requirements:
- 50+ deployments
- 25,000+ API requests/hour
- Compliance certifications needed
- Custom SLA requirements
- Volume discounts
- Multi-year contracts

title: Internationalization and Localization
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 supports multiple languages and locales for output messages, error reporting, and documentation. This guide covers i18n configuration and customization.

Language Selection:

Set default language:

[i18n]
default_language = "en-US"
fallback_language = "en"

Supported languages: en, es, fr, de, ja, zh, pt, it.

Per-User Language:

Users can override:

nova settings set language es-MX

Or via environment variable:

export NOVA_LANG=fr-FR
nova deploy list

Locale Configuration:

Configure locale settings:

[i18n.locale]
timezone = "America/New_York"
date_format = "YYYY-MM-DD"
time_format = "HH:mm:ss"
number_format = "1,000.00"
currency = "USD"

Formats follow Unicode CLDR standards.

Message Translation:

Customize messages:

[i18n.messages.en]
deployment_created = "Deployment created successfully"
deployment_failed = "Deployment failed: {error}"

[http://i18n.messages.es]
deployment_created = "Despliegue creado exitosamente"
deployment_failed = "Despliegue fallido: {error}"

Placeholders support dynamic values.

Date and Time Formatting:

Localized datetime display:

en-US: "January 15, 2024 3:30 PM"
es-MX: "15 de enero de 2024 15:30"
de-DE: "15. Januar 2024 15:30"

Automatic based on locale.

Number Formatting:

Localized number display:

en-US: 1,234,567.89
de-DE: 1.234.567,89
fr-FR: 1 234 567,89

Currency Formatting:

Localized currency:

en-US + USD: $1,234.56
es-ES + EUR: 1.234,56 
ja-JP + JPY: 1,235

Right-to-Left Languages:

Support RTL languages:

[i18n.rtl]
languages = ["ar", "he", "fa"]
auto_detect = true

UI direction adjusts automatically.

Translation Files:

Load custom translations:

[i18n.translations]
path = "/etc/nova/translations"
format = "json"  # or "yaml", "po"

File structure:

translations/
  en-US.json
  es-MX.json
  fr-FR.json

Pluralizations:

Handle plural forms:

[i18n.messages.en.plurals]
item_count = {
  zero = "No items",
  one = "1 item",
  other = "{count} items"
}

Rules vary by language.

Error Message Localization:

Translate error messages:

[i18n.errors.en]
connection_timeout = "Connection timeout: Could not reach {host}"
invalid_config = "Invalid configuration: {details}"

[http://i18n.errors.es]
connection_timeout = "Tiempo de conexin agotado: No se pudo alcanzar {host}"
invalid_config = "Configuracin invlida: {details}"

Help Text Localization:

Translate command help:

nova help --lang es

Displays help in Spanish.

Translation Coverage:

Check translation completeness:

nova i18n coverage

Reports missing translations by language.

Fallback Behavior:

Handle missing translations:

[i18n.fallback]
mode = "graceful"  # or "strict"
show_key_if_missing = false

Graceful mode shows English if translation missing.

Locale Detection:

Automatic locale detection:

[http://i18n.auto_detect]
from_env = true
from_system = true
from_terminal = true

Detects from LANG environment variable, system settings, or terminal.

Custom Locale Data:

Override locale defaults:

[i18n.custom_locales.en-COMPANY]
base = "en-US"
date_format = "DD/MM/YYYY"
currency = "EUR"
custom_formats = true

Contributing Translations:

Submit new translations:

nova i18n export --language en --output en-US.json

Edit and submit via GitHub.

title: Migrating Large-Scale Deployments
body:
Enterprise deployments with large data volumes require specialized migration strategies. This guide addresses challenges specific to large-scale NovaCLI migrations.

Defining Large-Scale:

Large-scale deployments typically have:
- Data volume: >500GB
- Query volume: >10,000 queries/minute
- User base: >1,000 concurrent users
- Uptime requirements: 99.9%+
- Multiple regions or availability zones

Unique Challenges:

1. Extended migration times:
   Schema changes on 1TB database may take 2-4 hours

2. Data transfer overhead:
   Moving large datasets between instances

3. Downtime sensitivity:
   High-availability requirements

4. Testing complexity:
   Difficult to replicate production scale

5. Rollback risk:
   Longer rollback times

Pre-Migration Optimization:

Reduce migration time:

1. Archive old data:
   nova deploy archive deployment-id --table logs --older-than 365d

2. Remove unused indexes:
   nova deploy indexes deployment-id --unused

3. Vacuum database:
   nova deploy vacuum deployment-id --full

4. Optimize tables:
   nova deploy optimize deployment-id

Phased Migration:

Migrate in phases to reduce risk:

Phase 1: Non-production environments
- Development
- Testing
- Staging

Learn from these migrations before production.

Phase 2: Read replicas
- Upgrade replicas first
- Validate upgraded replicas
- No impact on primary

Phase 3: Regional rollout
- Migrate one region at a time
- Monitor each region before proceeding
- Gradual global rollout

Phase 4: Primary deployment
- Migrate primary last
- All replicas already upgraded
- Shortest primary downtime

Resource Provisioning:

Temporarily over-provision during migration:

1. Increase deployment size:
   nova deploy resize deployment-id --size 2xlarge

2. Additional IOPS:
   nova deploy update deployment-id --iops 10000

3. More parallel workers:
   nova deploy update deployment-id --migration-workers 8

4. After migration, downsize if appropriate

Data Transfer Acceleration:

Speed up large data transfers:

1. Use parallel transfer:
   nova deploy replicate source-id --target target-id --parallel 8

2. Compression:
   nova deploy replicate source-id --target target-id --compress

3. Incremental sync:
   Transfer bulk data first, then sync delta during final cutover

Monitoring Large Migrations:

Detailed progress tracking:

1. Migration progress:
   nova deploy upgrade-status deployment-id

2. Estimated completion:
   Shows time remaining

3. Resource utilization:
   Monitor CPU, memory, disk I/O during migration

4. Lock monitoring:
   Ensure migration isn't blocking critical operations

Rollback Planning:

Large deployment rollback considerations:

1. Pre-migration snapshot:
   May be very large (100s of GB)

2. Rollback time:
   Proportional to data size

3. RPO/RTO:
   Define acceptable data loss and downtime

4. Partial rollback:
   May roll back per-region or per-replica

Stakeholder Communication:

Frequent updates for large migrations:

- T-30 days: Initial announcement
- T-14 days: Detailed plan
- T-7 days: Reminder
- T-1 day: Final confirmation
- During: Hourly updates
- Post: Completion report

Contingency Planning:

Prepare for extended migrations:

1. Extended maintenance window:
   Plan for 2x estimated time

2. Support coverage:
   24/7 support during migration period

3. Emergency contacts:
   Escalation path for critical issues

4. Vendor support:
   Engage Nova support for large migrations

title: Cost Management Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.0 provides cost management features to monitor, optimize, and control cloud spending. This guide covers cost tracking, budgets, and optimization recommendations.

Cost Tracking:

Enable cost tracking:

[cost_management]
tracking_enabled = true
granularity = "hourly"  # or "daily", "monthly"
currency = "USD"

View current costs:

nova cost current <deployment-id>

Displays costs by resource type.

Budgets:

Set spending budgets:

[cost_management.budgets]

[[cost_management.budgets.budget]]
name = "Monthly Production"
amount = 5000
period = "monthly"
alert_threshold = 0.80  # Alert at 80%
hard_limit = false

[[cost_management.budgets.budget]]
name = "Development"
amount = 500
period = "monthly"
hard_limit = true  # Block spending over budget

Budget Alerts:

Configure budget notifications:

[cost_management.alerts]
channels = ["email", "slack"]
thresholds = [0.50, 0.75, 0.90, 1.00]
recipients = ["mailto:finops@company.com"]

Cost Allocation:

Allocate costs to teams or projects:

[cost_management.allocation]
tags = ["team", "project", "environment"]
auto_tag = true

Tag deployments:

nova deploy update <deployment-id> 
  --tag team=engineering 
  --tag project=api-platform

Cost Reports:

Generate cost reports:

nova cost report 
  --period monthly 
  --group-by project 
  --format pdf

Schedule automatic reports:

[cost_management.reporting]
auto_generate = true
frequency = "weekly"
recipients = ["mailto:finance@company.com"]

Cost Forecasting:

Forecast future costs:

nova cost forecast 
  --horizon 90 
  --confidence 0.95

Based on historical usage patterns.

Cost Optimization:

Receive optimization recommendations:

nova cost optimize <deployment-id>

Recommendations include:
- Rightsizing opportunities
- Reserved capacity
- Idle resource cleanup
- Storage optimization

Rightsizing:

Automatic rightsizing:

[cost_management.rightsizing]
enabled = true
analysis_period_days = 30
utilization_threshold = 0.60
auto_apply = false  # Recommend only

Reserved Capacity:

Manage reserved capacity:

[cost_management.reservations]
auto_recommend = true
min_coverage = 0.70
commitment_term = 12  # months

Purchase reservations:

nova cost reserve 
  --size large 
  --quantity 5 
  --term 12

Cost Anomaly Detection:

Detect unusual spending:

[cost_management.anomaly_detection]
enabled = true
sensitivity = "medium"  # or "low", "high"
alert_on_anomaly = true

Idle Resource Cleanup:

Identify idle resources:

nova cost idle-resources 
  --min-idle-days 30

Automatic cleanup:

[cost_management.cleanup]
auto_cleanup = false
idle_threshold_days = 60
require_approval = true

Cost by Environment:

Track costs by environment:

nova cost breakdown 
  --by environment 
  --period monthly

Storage Optimization:

Optimize storage costs:

[cost_http://management.storage]
auto_compress = true
archive_old_backups = true
archive_after_days = 90

Cost Showback:

Showback reports for internal billing:

nova cost showback 
  --team engineering 
  --period monthly

Cost Governance:

Enforce cost policies:

[cost_management.governance]
max_deployment_cost_per_day = 100
require_budget_tag = true
block_expensive_operations = false

Export cost data:

nova cost export 
  --format csv 
  --output costs.csv

title: Compliance and Regulatory Considerations
body:
Version migrations may impact compliance posture. This guide addresses regulatory considerations for NovaCLI migrations in regulated industries.

Regulatory Frameworks:

Common regulations affecting deployments:
- GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
- HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
- SOC 2 (Service Organization Control 2)
- PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
- ISO 27001

Data Residency:

Version migration must maintain data location requirements:

1. Verify region compliance:
   nova regions list --compliance gdpr

2. Check deployment location:
   nova deploy get deployment-id --format json | jq '.region'

3. Ensure migration doesn't move data to non-compliant region

GDPR Considerations:

GDPR requirements during migration:

1. Data protection:
   - Maintain encryption in transit and at rest
   - No unauthorized data transfers
   - Audit logging of data access

2. Right to erasure:
   - Ensure deletion capabilities remain functional
   - Verify backup retention policies

3. Data breach notification:
   - Monitor for anomalies during migration
   - Report any data exposure within 72 hours

HIPAA Requirements:

Healthcare data migrations:

1. Business Associate Agreement (BAA):
   Verify Nova has valid BAA before migration

2. Encryption:
   - All data encrypted during transfer
   - Encrypted backups
   - Secure deletion of old data

3. Access controls:
   - Maintain role-based access
   - Audit trail of all access
   - No unauthorized access during migration

4. Minimum necessary principle:
   Only migrate data required for operations

SOC 2 Compliance:

Maintain SOC 2 controls during migration:

1. Change management:
   - Documented migration plan
   - Approval from stakeholders
   - Testing in non-production

2. Availability:
   - Minimize downtime
   - Redundancy during migration
   - Incident response plan

3. Confidentiality:
   - Access controls maintained
   - Data classification respected
   - Secure communication channels

Documentation Requirements:

Maintain compliance documentation:

1. Migration plan:
   - Scope and objectives
   - Risk assessment
   - Security controls
   - Rollback procedures

2. Execution log:
   - Actions taken
   - Timestamps
   - Personnel involved
   - Issues and resolutions

3. Validation reports:
   - Testing results
   - Security scans
   - Data integrity checks
   - Sign-off from compliance team

Audit Trails:

Maintain audit logs during migration:

nova account audit-log --since migration-start --until migration-end

Capture:
- Administrative actions
- Data access
- Configuration changes
- Security events

Retain audit logs per compliance requirements (typically 1-7 years).

Risk Assessment:

Document migration risks:

1. Data loss or corruption
2. Unauthorized access
3. Compliance violation
4. Service disruption
5. Data breach

Mitigation for each risk.

Third-Party Audits:

Coordinate with auditors:

1. Notify auditors of planned migration
2. Provide migration documentation
3. Address audit findings before migration
4. Schedule post-migration audit review

Incident Response:

Prepare for compliance incidents:

1. Incident response team on standby
2. Notification procedures documented
3. Evidence preservation plan
4. Legal counsel availability

title: Team Training for Version Migrations
body:
Successful migrations require team preparation. This guide covers training strategies to ensure teams are ready for NovaCLI version transitions.

Training Objectives:

Teams should understand:
- New features and changes in target version
- Migration procedure and timeline
- Rollback procedures
- Troubleshooting common issues
- Communication protocols

Identifying Training Needs:

Assess team readiness:

1. Technical skills:
   - CLI proficiency
   - Backup and restore operations
   - Troubleshooting experience
   - Database administration

2. Role-specific needs:
   - Developers: New API features
   - Operators: Migration execution
   - Support: Common issues
   - Management: Risk and timeline

3. Knowledge gaps:
   Identify areas requiring focused training

Training Materials:

Prepare comprehensive resources:

1. Documentation:
   - Migration guide
   - New feature overview
   - Troubleshooting playbook
   - FAQ document

2. Hands-on labs:
   - Practice migration in test environment
   - Rollback exercises
   - New feature exploration

3. Video tutorials:
   - Recorded migration walkthrough
   - Feature demonstrations
   - Best practices

Training Schedule:

Phased training approach:

Week 1: Overview and Planning
- Migration announcement
- High-level changes review
- Timeline and expectations
- Q&A session

Week 2: Technical Deep Dive
- New features detailed
- Breaking changes explained
- Hands-on lab exercises
- Tool familiarization

Week 3: Migration Procedures
- Step-by-step walkthrough
- Rollback procedures
- Incident response
- Communication protocols

Week 4: Practice and Validation
- Mock migration in test environment
- Troubleshooting scenarios
- Role-specific training
- Final preparation

Role-Specific Training:

Developers:
- API changes and new endpoints
- Configuration format (TOML)
- New command syntax
- Integration testing procedures

Operations:
- Migration execution steps
- Monitoring and alerting
- Rollback procedures
- Incident escalation

Support Team:
- Common post-migration issues
- New error messages
- Troubleshooting guides
- Escalation paths

Management:
- Migration timeline and risks
- Business impact
- Communication strategy
- Success metrics

Hands-On Practice:

Lab exercises:

1. CLI upgrade:
   Practice upgrading CLI to new version

2. Configuration migration:
   Convert YAML to TOML manually

3. Deployment upgrade:
   Upgrade test deployment end-to-end

4. Rollback drill:
   Practice rolling back failed migration

5. Troubleshooting:
   Work through common issues

Provide sandbox environment for safe experimentation.

Knowledge Verification:

Assess team readiness:

1. Quiz:
   Test understanding of new features and procedures

2. Practical exam:
   Execute migration in test environment

3. Role-playing:
   Simulate incident response scenarios

4. Sign-off:
   Team members acknowledge readiness

Ongoing Support:

Post-training resources:

1. Migration day support:
   - Experienced personnel available
   - War room or communication channel
   - Real-time troubleshooting

2. Reference materials:
   - Quick reference guides
   - Command cheat sheets
   - Contact list

3. Post-migration training:
   - Lessons learned session
   - Advanced features workshop
   - Continuous learning

Communication Channels:

Establish support channels:
- Slack channel: #migration-support
- Email: mailto:migration-team@company.com
- On-call rotation for critical issues
- Escalation path documented

Feedback Loop:

Continuous improvement:

1. Gather feedback on training effectiveness
2. Document issues encountered
3. Update training materials
4. Share lessons learned
5. Improve future migrations

title: Migration Cost Estimation and Budgeting
body:
Understanding migration costs helps with planning and budget allocation. This guide covers cost components and estimation methods for NovaCLI version migrations.

Direct Migration Costs:

Infrastructure costs during migration:

1. Temporary resource scaling:
   - Larger instance sizes during migration
   - Additional IOPS provisioning
   - Estimated cost: $50-500 per deployment

2. Dual deployment periods:
   - Running old and new versions simultaneously
   - Blue-green deployment costs
   - Duration: Hours to days
   - Estimated cost: 2x normal infrastructure cost

3. Data transfer:
   - Cross-region migration fees
   - Backup data transfer
   - Estimated: $0.02-0.12 per GB

4. Additional storage:
   - Pre-migration backups
   - Migration snapshots
   - Temporary data duplication
   - Estimated: 1.5-2x normal storage cost

Labor Costs:

Personnel time investment:

1. Planning:
   - Migration strategy development
   - Risk assessment
   - Timeline creation
   - Estimated: 20-40 hours

2. Testing:
   - Staging environment setup
   - Migration testing
   - Validation procedures
   - Estimated: 40-80 hours

3. Execution:
   - Migration day activities
   - Monitoring
   - Issue resolution
   - Estimated: 8-24 hours

4. Post-migration:
   - Validation
   - Documentation
   - Team training
   - Estimated: 20-40 hours

Total labor: 88-184 hours per major migration

Tool and Service Costs:

Additional expenses:

1. Monitoring tools:
   - Enhanced monitoring during migration
   - Third-party APM tools
   - Estimated: $100-1,000

2. Testing environments:
   - Temporary staging deployments
   - Load testing services
   - Estimated: $200-2,000

3. Professional services:
   - Nova migration support (optional)
   - Consulting services
   - Estimated: $5,000-50,000 for large migrations

4. Training:
   - Team training materials
   - Workshops or courses
   - Estimated: $500-5,000

Risk and Contingency:

Budget for unexpected costs:

1. Extended migration time:
   - Longer than planned downtime
   - Additional personnel hours
   - Extra infrastructure costs

2. Rollback scenarios:
   - Cost of rolling back
   - Re-attempting migration
   - Lost productivity

3. Issue remediation:
   - Emergency support
   - Data recovery
   - Performance optimization

Recommended contingency: 20-30% of estimated costs

Hidden Costs:

Often overlooked expenses:

1. Opportunity cost:
   - Team time diverted from other projects
   - Delayed feature development
   - Business impact of downtime

2. Training time:
   - Team members learning new version
   - Reduced productivity during learning curve
   - Estimated: 1-2 weeks reduced efficiency

3. Technical debt:
   - Updating documentation
   - Refactoring deprecated code
   - Modernizing integrations

Cost Estimation Template:

Calculate total migration cost:

1. Infrastructure: $__
2. Labor: $__
3. Tools/Services: $__
4. Contingency (25%): $__
5. Hidden costs: $__

Total estimated cost: $__

Cost by Deployment Size:

Typical costs by scale:

Small (<50GB, <10 users):
- Infrastructure: $50-200
- Labor: $2,000-8,000
- Total: $2,500-10,000

Medium (50-500GB, 10-100 users):
- Infrastructure: $200-1,000
- Labor: $8,000-20,000
- Total: $10,000-30,000

Large (>500GB, >100 users):
- Infrastructure: $1,000-10,000
- Labor: $20,000-100,000
- Total: $30,000-150,000

Cost Optimization:

Reduce migration expenses:

1. Thorough testing:
   Reduces risk of costly rollbacks

2. Automation:
   Scripts reduce manual labor

3. Off-peak scheduling:
   Lower infrastructure costs

4. Incremental migration:
   Spread costs over time

5. Team preparation:
   Reduces troubleshooting time

ROI Analysis:

Justify migration investment:

Benefits of upgrading:
- Performance improvements
- New features enabling business value
- Security enhancements
- Long-term support
- Reduced operational complexity

Calculate payback period for migration investment.

title: Recovering from Configuration File Corruption
body:
Configuration file corruption in NovaCLI v3.0 can prevent the tool from functioning correctly. Understanding config file structure and recovery procedures helps restore functionality quickly.

Symptoms of Corruption:

Corrupted configuration files cause various errors:

- "Failed to parse configuration file"
- "Invalid TOML syntax at line X"
- "Unknown configuration key: [section.key]"
- Unexpected behavior or ignored settings

Configuration File Locations:

NovaCLI v3.0 stores configuration in:

Linux/macOS: ~/.nova/config.toml
Windows: %USERPROFILE%.novaconfig.toml

Backup your configuration before making changes.

Validating Configuration:

Validate configuration syntax without applying changes:

nova config validate

This reports syntax errors, invalid values, and deprecated settings.

Manual Recovery:

If validation fails and NovaCLI won't start, manually edit the configuration file. Open in a text editor and look for:

- Incomplete lines or missing closing brackets
- Incorrect TOML syntax (missing quotes, invalid escaping)
- Duplicate section headers
- Invalid values for known settings

Comment out problematic lines with # and retry validation.

Reset to Defaults:

If manual recovery fails, reset to default configuration:

mv ~/.nova/config.toml ~/.nova/config.toml.backup
nova config init

This creates a fresh configuration file. You'll need to reconfigure authentication and custom settings.

Restore from Backup:

NovaCLI automatically backs up configuration before major changes. Restore the most recent backup:

ls -lt ~/.nova/backups/
cp ~/.nova/backups/config.toml.2024-09-01 ~/.nova/config.toml

Migration Issues:

Configuration corruption often occurs during version migrations. NovaCLI v3.0 uses TOML instead of YAML from v2.0. If upgrading from v2.0, run the migration tool:

nova config migrate --from-version 2.0

This converts YAML configuration to TOML format, preserving all settings.

Environment Variables:

By-pass corrupted configuration files using environment variables for critical settings:

export NOVA_API_ENDPOINT=https://api.nova.io
export NOVA_API_TOKEN=your-token

This allows basic functionality while you repair the configuration file.

title: Configuration Management Best Practices
body:
Effective configuration management is the foundation of maintainable infrastructure. Whether you're deploying to production or managing development environments, a well-structured configuration strategy prevents errors, speeds up troubleshooting, and enables rapid scaling.

Configuration files serve as the contract between your application and its runtime environment. They define how services communicate, where data persists, and what security policies apply. Poor configuration practices lead to incidents: production outages from missing environment variables, security breaches from hardcoded credentials, and deployment failures from format inconsistencies.

Start by separating configuration from code. Never embed environment-specific values directly in application logic. Use external configuration files that can be swapped during deployment without recompiling or restarting services. This separation enables the same codebase to run in development, staging, and production with different behavior.

Version control your configuration files alongside code, but treat secrets differently. Store non-sensitive defaults in repositories while injecting sensitive values through environment variables, secret managers, or encrypted vaults. Document which values require customization for each environment.

Structure configuration hierarchically. Group related settings into logical sections: server connection parameters, authentication settings, logging configuration, and feature flags. Clear organization makes it easier for team members to locate and modify specific values without hunting through flat key-value lists.

Validate configuration before deployment. Implement schema validation that catches typos, missing required fields, and invalid value ranges. Automated validation in CI/CD pipelines prevents broken configurations from reaching production.

Maintain multiple environment profiles within configuration systems. Development environments need verbose logging and relaxed timeouts, while production demands optimized performance and strict security. Profile-based configuration eliminates the need for separate files per environment.

Document configuration options thoroughly. Each setting should have clear descriptions, valid value ranges, default behaviors, and examples. Good documentation reduces onboarding time and prevents misconfiguration.

title: Observability and Monitoring Strategies
body:
Modern applications require comprehensive observability to maintain reliability, diagnose issues, and optimize performance. Effective monitoring strategies combine metrics, logs, and traces to provide complete visibility into system behavior across distributed architectures.

Observability differs from traditional monitoring by focusing on understanding system state from external outputs rather than predicting failure modes in advance. You cannot anticipate every possible failure scenario, but observable systems allow engineers to ask arbitrary questions about behavior when incidents occur.

Logs provide the narrative of what happened in your application. Every significant action, error condition, and state transition should generate a log entry with sufficient context for later investigation. Logs answer questions about specific requests, user actions, and error sequences that metrics alone cannot capture.

Structured logging transforms logs from unstructured text into queryable data. Instead of parsing free-form messages with regular expressions, structured logs use consistent key-value pairs that enable powerful aggregation and filtering. Query languages designed for structured data make it trivial to find patterns across millions of log entries.

Log aggregation centralizes logs from distributed services into a single queryable system. Centralized logging enables correlation across service boundaries, revealing how a single user request flows through multiple microservices and where failures occur in complex workflows.

Metrics complement logs by tracking quantitative measurements over time: request rates, error counts, latency percentiles, resource utilization. While logs capture individual events, metrics reveal trends and patterns that inform capacity planning and performance optimization.

Tracing connects related events across service boundaries using correlation IDs. A single API request might trigger dozens of internal service calls, database queries, and external API requests. Distributed tracing reconstructs the complete execution path, showing where time is spent and where errors originate.

Alerting transforms observability data into actionable notifications. Define thresholds based on service level objectives, alert on rate of change rather than absolute values, and route notifications based on severity and on-call schedules.

title: Twelve-Factor App Configuration Principles
body:
The twelve-factor methodology provides time-tested principles for building modern, cloud-native applications that scale horizontally, deploy reliably, and maintain portability across execution environments. Factor III focuses on configuration management, one of the most critical aspects of application design.

Configuration comprises everything that varies between deployments: database credentials, API endpoints, feature flags, resource limits, and external service URLs. The fundamental principle is strict separation of config from code. Configuration should never be hardcoded in source files or checked into version control alongside application logic.

Environment variables provide the simplest and most portable configuration mechanism. They work identically across operating systems, container platforms, and cloud providers. Unlike configuration files that require filesystem access and parsing, environment variables are available through standard language APIs from process startup.

Grouping configuration into named environments (development, staging, production) represents an anti-pattern according to twelve-factor principles. Environment-based grouping doesn't scale as deployments multiply: you'll eventually need production-europe, production-asia, staging-customer-a configurations that don't fit the original three-environment model. Instead, manage configuration granularly with independent variables.

Language and framework-agnostic configuration enables polyglot architectures where services written in different languages share configuration patterns. A Python service and a Go service can both read REDIS_URL without requiring language-specific configuration libraries or file formats.

Cloud platforms embrace environment variable configuration as the primary mechanism for runtime customization. Container orchestration systems like Kubernetes inject configuration through environment variables, config maps, and secrets. Serverless platforms provide environment variables as the standard configuration interface.

Configuration validation should occur at application startup, failing fast if required variables are missing or contain invalid values. Clear error messages that list missing variables help operators diagnose deployment issues quickly rather than encountering cryptic failures deep in application logic.

Backing services (databases, caches, message queues) should be attachable resources referenced through URLs in configuration. An application shouldn't distinguish between local and third-party services, making it trivial to swap a local database for a managed cloud database by changing a single configuration value.

title: Network Security Configuration
body:
Network security configuration controls which clients can access your NovaCLI deployments. Proper configuration prevents unauthorized access while maintaining legitimate connectivity.

IP Allowlisting:

Restrict connections to known IP addresses or ranges:

nova ip-allowlist add <deployment-id> 203.0.113.0/24
nova ip-allowlist add <deployment-id> 198.51.100.42/32

CIDR notation specifies ranges. /32 allows a single IP; /24 allows 256 addresses.

List current allowlist:

nova ip-allowlist list <deployment-id>

Remove entries:

nova ip-allowlist remove <deployment-id> 203.0.113.0/24

Default deny policy: If any allowlist entries exist, all other IPs are blocked.

VPC Peering:

For private network access, establish VPC peering:

nova vpc-peer create 
  --deployment <deployment-id> 
  --vpc-id vpc-abc123 
  --region us-east-1

Deployments become accessible from your VPC without traversing the internet.

Private Endpoints:

Enable private endpoints for internal-only access:

nova settings set deployment.<deployment-id>.network.private_endpoint true

Disables public internet access. Connect only via VPC peering or direct connect.

Firewall Rules:

Configure custom firewall rules:

[firewall]
rule.1.source = "10.0.0.0/8"
rule.1.protocol = "tcp"
rule.1.port = 5432
rule.1.action = "allow"

rule.2.source = "0.0.0.0/0"
rule.2.action = "deny"

Rules are evaluated in order. First match determines action.

DDoS Protection:

Enable rate limiting to mitigate denial of service:

[security]
rate_limit_enabled = true
max_connections_per_ip = 100
connection_rate_limit = 10  # connections per second

Aggressive limits may affect legitimate high-volume clients.

Intrusion Detection:

Enable logging of connection attempts:

[logging]
log_connections = true
log_disconnections = true
log_failed_auth = true

Review logs regularly for suspicious patterns:

nova logs search <deployment-id> "failed authentication"

Network Monitoring:

Monitor network metrics:

nova deploy stats <deployment-id> --metric network

Displays active connections, bytes transferred, connection failures.

Geographic Restrictions:

Restrict access by country (requires enterprise plan):

[geo]
allowed_countries = ["US", "CA", "MX"]
blocked_countries = ["*"]

Useful for compliance with data residency requirements.

Audit Logging:

Log all configuration changes:

nova audit-log enable --deployment <deployment-id>

Review audit trail:

nova audit-log show <deployment-id> --days 30

title: Caching Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides built-in caching mechanisms to reduce latency and improve performance. This guide covers configuring application-level caching, cache invalidation, and distributed caching.

Application Cache:

Enable in-memory application caching:

[cache]
enabled = true
backend = "memory"  # or "redis", "memcached"
max_size_mb = 512
eviction_policy = "lru"  # or "lfu", "fifo"

LRU (Least Recently Used) works well for most workloads.

Cache TTL:

Configure time-to-live for cached entries:

[cache.ttl]
default = 300  # seconds
query_results = 60
configuration = 3600
static_content = 86400

Different TTLs for different data types optimize cache hit rate.

Redis Backend:

Use Redis for distributed caching:

[cache.redis]
url = "redis://cache-cluster:6379/0"
password = "${REDIS_PASSWORD}"
max_connections = 50
connection_timeout = 5

Cluster mode:

[cache.redis.cluster]
enabled = true
nodes = ["redis1:6379", "redis2:6379", "redis3:6379"]

Memcached Backend:

Alternative distributed cache:

[cache.memcached]
servers = ["memcached1:11211", "memcached2:11211"]
max_connections_per_server = 10

Cache Warming:

Pre-populate cache at startup:

[cache.warming]
enabled = true
keys = ["frequent_query_1", "frequent_query_2"]
warm_on_startup = true
warm_on_clear = true

Reduces cold start latency.

Cache Invalidation:

Invalidate cache on changes:

[cache.invalidation]
strategy = "write-through"  # or "write-back", "write-around"
auto_invalidate_on_update = true

Write-through updates cache and database simultaneously.

Manual invalidation:

nova cache clear <key>
nova cache clear --pattern "user:*"
nova cache flush  # Clear entire cache

Cache Keys:

Structure cache keys consistently:

[cache.keys]
prefix = "novacli"
namespace_separator = ":"
version_keys = true

Example key: novacli:v1:user:123:profile

Cache Bypass:

Bypass cache for specific requests:

nova deploy list --no-cache

Configuration:

[cache.bypass]
headers = ["X-No-Cache", "Cache-Control: no-cache"]

Cache Monitoring:

Expose cache metrics:

[cache.metrics]
enabled = true
hit_rate = true
miss_rate = true
eviction_count = true
size_bytes = true

View cache statistics:

nova cache stats

Cache Compression:

Compress large cached values:

[cache.compression]
enabled = true
min_size_bytes = 1024
algorithm = "gzip"  # or "lz4", "zstd"

Trade CPU for memory savings.

Cache Partitioning:

Partition cache by tenant or environment:

[cache.partitions]
tenant_isolation = true
partition_key = "tenant_id"

Prevents cache pollution across tenants.

Cache Persistence:

Persist cache to disk:

[cache.persistence]
enabled = true
interval = 300  # seconds
path = "/var/lib/nova/cache"

Survives process restarts.

Read-Through Cache:

Automatic cache population:

[http://cache.read_through]
enabled = true
loader = "database"  # or "api", "file"

Cache miss triggers data load and cache update.

Cache Stampede Prevention:

Prevent thundering herd:

[cache.stampede]
prevention_enabled = true
lock_timeout = 5  # seconds

Single request regenerates expired entry; others wait.

Multi-Tier Caching:

Combine memory and distributed caches:

[cache.tiers]
l1_cache = "memory"
l2_cache = "redis"
promotion_threshold = 10  # access count

Frequently accessed items promoted to faster tier.

title: Diagnosing SSL Certificate Errors
body:
SSL certificate errors prevent secure connections between NovaCLI and the Nova API. These errors appear as certificate verification failures and require understanding certificate chains, validity periods, and trust stores.

Common SSL Errors:

Certificate verification errors typically present as:

- "SSL certificate verify failed: certificate has expired"
- "SSL certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain"
- "SSL certificate verify failed: unable to get local issuer certificate"

Expired Certificates:

If you encounter an expired certificate error, first verify the current date and time on your system. Incorrect system time causes certificate validation failures. Sync your system clock with a time server:

On Linux/macOS: sudo ntpdate http://pool.ntp.org
On Windows: Settings > Time & Language > Set time automatically

If your system time is correct but errors persist, Nova's SSL certificate may be near expiration. Check the certificate expiry date:

openssl s_client -connect http://api.nova.io:443 -servername http://api.nova.io < /dev/null 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -dates

Self-Signed Certificate Errors:

Corporate networks often use SSL inspection, inserting a self-signed corporate certificate in the chain. This is legitimate in corporate environments. Configure NovaCLI to trust your corporate CA:

nova config set http://ssl.ca_bundle /etc/ssl/certs/corporate-ca.pem

Alternatively, obtain the CA certificate from your IT department and add it to your system trust store.

Missing CA Certificates:

"Unable to get local issuer certificate" indicates missing root CA certificates in your system trust store. This commonly affects minimal Linux installations or containers. Install CA certificates:

Ubuntu/Debian: sudo apt-get install ca-certificates
CentOS/RHEL: sudo yum install ca-certificates
Alpine: apk add ca-certificates

Disabling Verification (Not Recommended):

For testing only, you can disable certificate verification:

nova config set ssl.verify false

This is insecure and should never be used in production. Only use for debugging to determine if SSL is the issue.

Proxy SSL Termination:

Proxies performing SSL termination may cause certificate mismatches. Configure proxy SSL settings:

nova config set proxy.ssl_verify true
nova config set http://proxy.ca_bundle /path/to/proxy-ca.pem

title: Command-Line Interface Design Principles
body:
Command-line interfaces remain the preferred tool for developers, system administrators, and power users who value speed, scriptability, and precise control. A well-designed CLI can transform complex operations into simple, memorable commands that become second nature to daily users.

Effective CLI design starts with consistency. Users should be able to predict command structure based on patterns they've already learned. Verb-noun ordering, consistent flag naming, and predictable output formats reduce cognitive load and minimize the need to constantly reference documentation.

Command hierarchy matters for discoverability. Flat command structures with dozens of top-level commands overwhelm users and make features hard to find. Group related functionality under logical parent commands, allowing users to explore capabilities through intuitive navigation. A user who knows how to manage deployments should easily guess where to find deployment logs.

Flags and arguments should follow conventions established by widely-used tools. Single-dash short flags (-v) pair with double-dash long flags (--verbose) for the same option. Boolean flags shouldn't require values, while flags that accept input should fail clearly when values are missing. Required arguments appear before optional ones.

Error messages deserve as much attention as success paths. When a command fails, explain what went wrong, why it matters, and what the user can do to fix it. Suggest corrections for typos, explain missing prerequisites, and provide examples of correct usage. Never leave users staring at cryptic error codes.

Output formatting should adapt to context. Interactive sessions benefit from human-readable tables with colors and formatting, while scripts need machine-parsable JSON or CSV. Respect the NO_COLOR environment variable and provide explicit format flags for users who need consistent output.

Backward compatibility prevents breaking changes from disrupting user workflows. Deprecate commands gracefully with warnings before removal, provide migration paths, and maintain aliases for renamed commands during transition periods.

title: Plugin System Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 supports extensibility through a plugin system. Plugins add custom commands, data sources, and integrations without modifying core functionality. This guide covers plugin installation, configuration, and development.

Plugin Installation:

Install plugins from the official registry:

nova plugin install <plugin-name>

Example:

nova plugin install prometheus-exporter

Installs the Prometheus exporter plugin, adding monitoring endpoints to deployments.

List installed plugins:

nova plugin list

Displays plugin name, version, status (enabled/disabled).

Plugin Configuration:

Configure plugins via dedicated configuration sections:

[plugins.prometheus-exporter]
enabled = true
port = 9090
metrics_path = "/metrics"

[plugins.slack-notifier]
enabled = true
webhook_url = "${SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL}"
default_channel = "#deployments"

Plugin-specific settings are documented in plugin README files.

Plugin Discovery:

Browse available plugins:

nova plugin search <keyword>

Search registry by functionality, tags, or author.

View plugin details:

nova plugin info prometheus-exporter

Displays description, version history, configuration options, and dependencies.

Plugin Updates:

Update plugins to latest versions:

nova plugin update <plugin-name>

Update all plugins:

nova plugin update --all

Automatic updates (requires configuration):

[plugins]
auto_update = true
update_check_interval = 86400  # Daily

Plugin Removal:

Uninstall plugins:

nova plugin uninstall <plugin-name>

Removes plugin code and configuration. Existing deployments using plugin features may break.

Custom Plugin Development:

Create custom plugins for organization-specific needs:

nova plugin init my-custom-plugin

Generates plugin scaffold with manifest, entry point, and example commands.

Plugin manifest (plugin.toml):

name = "my-custom-plugin"
version = "1.0.0"
author = "your-name"
description = "Custom functionality"

[dependencies]
nova_sdk = "^3.1"

[commands]
my-command = "http://commands.my_command:main"

Implement plugin commands in Python:

from nova_sdk import Command, Context

def main(ctx: Context):
    http://ctx.logger.info("Custom command executed")
    # Plugin logic here

Test plugin locally:

nova plugin install --dev ./my-custom-plugin

Publish to private registry:

nova plugin publish --registry https://plugins.company.com

Plugin Security:

Plugins run with full access to NovaCLI functionality. Only install trusted plugins.

Audit plugin permissions:

nova plugin audit <plugin-name>

Displays requested permissions and potential security concerns.

Sandboxed execution (experimental):

[http://plugins.security]
sandbox_enabled = true
allow_network = false
allow_filesystem = false

Restricts plugin capabilities. May break plugins requiring external resources.

title: Service Mesh Integration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 integrates with service mesh platforms for advanced traffic management, observability, and security. This guide covers Istio and Linkerd integration.

Service Mesh Selection:

Choose service mesh platform:

[service_mesh]
enabled = true
provider = "istio"  # or "linkerd", "consul"
version = "1.18.0"

Automatic sidecar injection:

[service_mesh.injection]
auto_inject = true
namespaces = ["production", "staging"]

Traffic Management:

Configure traffic routing:

[service_mesh.traffic]
load_balancing = "round_robin"  # or "least_request", "random"
connection_pool_size = 100
timeout_seconds = 30

Traffic splitting:

nova service-mesh route update 
  --deployment <deployment-id> 
  --version v1 --weight 90 
  --version v2 --weight 10

Circuit Breaking:

Configure circuit breakers:

[service_mesh.circuit_breaker]
enabled = true
max_connections = 100
max_pending_requests = 50
max_requests = 100
consecutive_errors = 5

Retry Policy:

Configure retry behavior:

[service_mesh.retry]
enabled = true
attempts = 3
per_try_timeout = 10  # seconds
retry_on = ["5xx", "gateway-error", "refused-stream"]

Timeout Configuration:

Set request timeouts:

[service_mesh.timeouts]
