- Resolutions applied
- Sign-off from stakeholders

Go/No-Go Decision:

Determine if migration is successful:

Go criteria:
 All health checks pass
 No critical errors in logs
 Performance within acceptable range
 Core functionality working
 Integration tests pass

No-Go criteria (rollback required):
 Critical functionality broken
 Data loss or corruption
 Performance degradation >20%
 Unresolved critical errors

title: Pagination and Filtering Best Practices
body:
The NovaCLI API provides flexible pagination and filtering for list endpoints. This reference covers optimal strategies for efficient data retrieval and client implementation patterns.

Pagination Methods:

Offset-based pagination:

GET /deployments?limit=50&offset=100

Advantages:
- Simple implementation
- Can jump to specific pages
- Predictable behavior

Disadvantages:
- Inefficient for large offsets
- Results may shift with concurrent changes
- Poor performance at high offsets

Cursor-based pagination:

GET /deployments?limit=50&cursor=eyJpZCI6MTIzfQ

Advantages:
- Consistent results during iteration
- Efficient for large datasets
- Handles concurrent changes gracefully

Disadvantages:
- Cannot jump to specific page
- Cursor opaque to clients

Recommendation: Use cursor-based for production systems, offset for user-facing page navigation.

Pagination Response:

Standard pagination metadata:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [...],
  "pagination": {
    "limit": 50,
    "offset": 100,
    "total": 250,
    "has_more": true,
    "next_cursor": "eyJpZCI6MTUwfQ",
    "next_url": "/deployments?limit=50&cursor=eyJpZCI6MTUwfQ"
  }
}

Iterating Through Results:

Offset-based iteration:

offset = 0
limit = 50
while True:
    response = get(f"/deployments?limit={limit}&offset={offset}")
    if not response['data']:
        break
    process(response['data'])
    offset += limit

Cursor-based iteration:

cursor = None
limit = 50
while True:
    url = f"/deployments?limit={limit}"
    if cursor:
        url += f"&cursor={cursor}"
    response = get(url)
    if not response['data']:
        break
    process(response['data'])
    cursor = response['pagination']['next_cursor']
    if not cursor:
        break

Filtering:

Supported filter types:

Equality filters:
GET /deployments?status=active&region=us-east-1

Multiple values (OR):
GET /deployments?status=active,stopped

Range filters:
GET /deployments?created_after=2024-09-01&created_before=2024-09-15

Pattern matching:
GET /deployments?name_like=prod-%

Array contains:
GET /deployments?tags_contain=production

Negation filters:
GET /deployments?status_not=failed

Filter Combinations:

Multiple filters use AND logic:

GET /deployments?status=active&region=us-east-1&size=large

Returns: active AND us-east-1 AND large

Complex filtering requires multiple values:

GET /deployments?status=active,stopped&region=us-east-1

Returns: (active OR stopped) AND us-east-1

Sorting:

Single field sort:
GET /deployments?sort=created_at

Descending order:
GET /deployments?sort=-created_at

Multiple fields:
GET /deployments?sort=region,-created_at

Sorts by region ascending, then created_at descending.

Field Selection:

Reduce payload size:

GET /deployments?fields=id,name,status

Returns only specified fields.

Full response (default):
GET /deployments

Performance Optimization:

Limit considerations:
- Small limits: More requests, lower latency
- Large limits: Fewer requests, higher latency
- Recommended: 50-100 for balance
- Maximum: 1000 per request

Index-friendly filters:
- Filter by indexed fields (id, created_at, status)
- Avoid pattern matching on large datasets
- Combine with sorting on indexed fields

Caching:
- Cache results for read-heavy workloads
- Use ETags for conditional requests
- Invalidate on write operations

Parallel Requests:

Fetch multiple pages simultaneously:

- Use cursor pagination
- Maintain order client-side
- Respect rate limits
- Handle cursor expiration

Error Handling:

Invalid cursor:
{
  "error": {
    "code": "INVALID_CURSOR",
    "message": "Cursor expired or invalid"
  }
}

Response: Start over from beginning.

Filter validation error:
{
  "error": {
    "code": "INVALID_FILTER",
    "message": "Field 'status' does not support operator 'gt'"
  }
}

title: Notification Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 sends notifications for deployment events, alerts, and errors through multiple channels. This guide covers configuring email, Slack, webhook, and PagerDuty notifications.

Email Notifications:

Configure SMTP for email alerts:

[http://notifications.email]
enabled = true
smtp_host = "http://smtp.gmail.com"
smtp_port = 587
smtp_user = "mailto:notifications@company.com"
smtp_password = "${SMTP_PASSWORD}"
from_address = "mailto:novacli@company.com"

Recipient configuration:

[http://notifications.email.recipients]
default = ["mailto:ops-team@company.com"]
critical = ["mailto:ops-team@company.com", "mailto:oncall@company.com"]
info = ["mailto:logs@company.com"]

Slack Integration:

Send notifications to Slack channels:

[notifications.slack]
enabled = true
webhook_url = "${SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL}"
default_channel = "#deployments"
username = "NovaCLI"
icon_emoji = ":rocket:"

Channel routing by severity:

[notifications.slack.routing]
critical = "#incidents"
warning = "#alerts"
info = "#deployments"

Webhook Notifications:

Send HTTP POST to custom endpoint:

[notifications.webhook]
enabled = true
url = "https://webhook.company.com/novacli"
method = "POST"
headers = {"Authorization" = "Bearer ${WEBHOOK_TOKEN}"}
timeout = 10

Payload format:

{
  "event": "deployment.failed",
  "deployment_id": "dep-abc123",
  "timestamp": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z",
  "severity": "critical",
  "message": "Deployment failed: connection timeout"
}

PagerDuty Integration:

Create PagerDuty incidents for critical events:

[notifications.pagerduty]
enabled = true
integration_key = "${PAGERDUTY_INTEGRATION_KEY}"
severity_threshold = "critical"

Only critical events trigger pages.

Microsoft Teams:

Post to Teams channels:

[notifications.teams]
enabled = true
webhook_url = "${TEAMS_WEBHOOK_URL}"

Event Filtering:

Control which events trigger notifications:

[notifications.filters]
events = [
  "deployment.created",
  "deployment.failed",
  "backup.completed",
  "certificate.expiring"
]

Exclude noisy events:

[notifications.filters]
exclude_events = [
  "deployment.stats_updated",
  "connection.established"
]

Severity-Based Routing:

Route by severity level:

[notifications.routing]
critical = ["pagerduty", "slack", "email"]
warning = ["slack", "email"]
info = ["slack"]

Critical events use all channels; info uses only Slack.

Quiet Hours:

Suppress non-critical notifications during off-hours:

[notifications.quiet_hours]
enabled = true
start = "22:00"
end = "08:00"
timezone = "America/New_York"
except_severity = ["critical"]

Critical events always notify.

Rate Limiting:

Prevent notification storms:

[notifications.rate_limiting]
max_per_hour = 50
max_burst = 10

Throttles excessive notifications from cascading failures.

Notification Templates:

Customize message format:

[notifications.templates]
deployment_failed = " Deployment .DeploymentID failed: .Error"
backup_completed = " Backup completed for .DeploymentID"

Digest Mode:

Batch notifications into periodic summaries:

[notifications.digest]
enabled = true
interval = 3600  # seconds
min_events = 5

Sends single digest instead of individual notifications.

title: Structured Logging Configuration in NovaCLI v3.1
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 implements structured logging using JSON format by default, providing machine-readable output that integrates seamlessly with modern observability platforms. This guide covers logging configuration, output formats, and best practices for production deployments.

Structured logging replaced plain text logs in v2.0, and v3.1 refined the schema to include additional context fields for distributed tracing and correlation. Each log entry now includes timestamp, level, message, source location, and custom metadata.

Logging configuration resides in the [logging] section of config.toml:

[logging]
level = "info"
format = "json"
output = "/var/log/novacli/app.log"
max_size_mb = 100
max_backups = 5
compress = true

[logging.fields]
service = "novacli"
environment = "production"
version = "3.1.0"

Log levels follow standard severity ordering: debug, info, warn, error, fatal. Set the level to control verbosity. Debug logs include detailed internal state and are suitable for troubleshooting but generate significant volume in production.

JSON format enables structured querying in log aggregation systems:

{"timestamp":"2024-09-15T14:32:10Z","level":"info","message":"deployment started","deployment_id":"dep-12345","user":"admin","service":"novacli","environment":"production"}

For human-readable output during development, use format = "text":

2024-09-15 14:32:10 INFO deployment started deployment_id=dep-12345 user=admin

Log rotation prevents disk exhaustion. The max_size_mb setting triggers rotation when log files reach the specified size. The max_backups setting limits retained historical files. Enable compression to reduce storage costs.

Custom fields in [logging.fields] appear in every log entry, providing consistent context for filtering and aggregation. Add fields for service name, environment, region, or any metadata relevant to your infrastructure.

Dynamic log level adjustment allows runtime changes without restart:

nova settings set logging.level debug
nova settings reload

Integration with external logging systems requires configuring output destinations. NovaCLI supports file, stdout, and syslog outputs:

output = "stdout" # For container environments
output = "syslog://http://localhost:514" # For centralized logging

Sensitive data redaction prevents credential leakage in logs. Configure redaction patterns in [logging.redact].

title: Addressing High CPU Usage
body:
High CPU usage impacts deployment responsiveness and can trigger throttling or crashes. Identifying CPU-intensive operations and optimizing them restores normal performance in NovaCLI v3.1.

Monitoring CPU Usage:

Track CPU metrics over time:

nova deploy stats deployment-id --metric cpu --duration 24h

Sustained usage above 80% indicates performance issues requiring investigation.

Identifying CPU Consumers:

Profile CPU usage to find hot spots:

nova deploy profile deployment-id --type cpu --duration 300

This samples CPU activity for 5 minutes and reports the top consumers by function or component.

Query-Related CPU Usage:

Inefficient queries often cause high CPU. Identify expensive queries:

nova deploy top-queries deployment-id --order-by cpu

Optimize queries using indexes, query rewriting, or caching.

Background Jobs:

Maintenance operations consume CPU. Check active jobs:

nova deploy jobs deployment-id

Reschedule intensive jobs to off-peak hours:

nova deploy schedule-job deployment-id vacuum --time "02:00" --frequency weekly

Connection Overhead:

Excessive connection churn increases CPU usage. Monitor connection statistics:

nova deploy connections deployment-id --stats

Use connection pooling to reduce overhead:

nova deploy update deployment-id --enable-connection-pooling --pool-size 50

Encryption Overhead:

SSL/TLS encryption consumes CPU. For internal deployments where encryption isn't required, disable SSL:

nova deploy update deployment-id --ssl-mode disabled

Only disable encryption for non-production or isolated environments.

Compression:

Data compression trades CPU for I/O efficiency. If CPU-bound, reduce compression:

nova deploy update deployment-id --compression-level low

Vertical Scaling:

If optimization doesn't reduce CPU usage sufficiently, scale to more CPU cores:

nova deploy resize deployment-id --size cpu-optimized-large

CPU-optimized instance types provide more compute capacity.

Load Distribution:

For read-heavy workloads, distribute load across replicas:

nova deploy create-replica deployment-id --region us-east

Configure read traffic to use replicas:

nova deploy update deployment-id --read-replica-routing enabled

title: Webhooks API Reference
body:
The Webhooks API enables real-time event notifications to external systems. This reference covers webhook configuration, event types, and payload formats.

Create Webhook:

POST /webhooks

Request body:

{
  "url": "https://your-app.com/novacli-webhook",
  "events": ["deployment.created", "deployment.failed", "backup.completed"],
  "secret": "your-webhook-secret",
  "enabled": true,
  "description": "Production webhook"
}

Response (201 Created):

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": "webhook-abc123",
    "url": "https://your-app.com/novacli-webhook",
    "events": [...],
    "created_at": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z"
  }
}

List Webhooks:

GET /webhooks

Returns all configured webhooks.

Get Webhook:

GET /webhooks/{webhook_id}

Update Webhook:

PUT /webhooks/{webhook_id}

Modify webhook configuration.

Delete Webhook:

DELETE /webhooks/{webhook_id}

Available Events:

Deployment events:
- deployment.created
- deployment.updated
- deployment.deleted
- deployment.started
- deployment.stopped
- deployment.failed
- deployment.scaled

Backup events:
- backup.created
- backup.completed
- backup.failed
- backup.deleted

Restore events:
- restore.started
- restore.completed
- restore.failed

Alert events:
- alert.triggered
- alert.resolved

Maintenance events:
- maintenance.scheduled
- maintenance.started
- maintenance.completed

Webhook Payload:

All webhooks receive JSON payload:

{
  "event": "deployment.created",
  "timestamp": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z",
  "data": {
    "deployment": {
      "id": "dep-abc123",
      "name": "production-api",
      "status": "creating"
    }
  },
  "metadata": {
    "webhook_id": "webhook-abc123",
    "delivery_id": "delivery-xyz789"
  }
}

Webhook Signature:

Verify webhook authenticity using HMAC signature:

X-NovaCLI-Signature: sha256=abc123...

Compute signature:

HMAC-SHA256(webhook_secret, request_body)

Example verification (Python):

import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(secret, body, signature):
    expected = http://hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        body.encode(),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    return http://hmac.compare_digest(f"sha256={expected}", signature)

Webhook Headers:

Requests include:

Content-Type: application/json
User-Agent: NovaCLI-Webhooks/1.0
X-NovaCLI-Event: deployment.created
X-NovaCLI-Signature: sha256=...
X-NovaCLI-Delivery: delivery-xyz789

Retry Policy:

Failed webhooks retry automatically:

- Retry on: HTTP 5xx, timeout, connection error
- Retry attempts: 5
- Backoff: Exponential (1s, 2s, 4s, 8s, 16s)
- Give up after: 31 seconds total

Webhook Deliveries:

GET /webhooks/{webhook_id}/deliveries

View delivery history:

Query parameters:
- status: Filter by status (success, failed, pending)
- limit: Results per page

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "delivery-xyz789",
      "event": "deployment.created",
      "status": "success",
      "status_code": 200,
      "delivered_at": "2024-09-15T10:30:05Z",
      "attempts": 1
    }
  ]
}

Redeliver Webhook:

POST /webhooks/{webhook_id}/deliveries/{delivery_id}/redeliver

Manually retry failed delivery.

Test Webhook:

POST /webhooks/{webhook_id}/test

Send test event to verify configuration.

Webhook Timeout:

Webhook endpoint must respond within 10 seconds.

Disable Webhook:

PATCH /webhooks/{webhook_id}

Request body:

{
  "enabled": false
}

Disabled webhooks do not receive events.

title: Migrating Between Cloud Regions
body:
Moving NovaCLI deployments between geographic regions requires careful planning to maintain data integrity and minimize downtime. This guide covers cross-region migration strategies.

Reasons for Region Migration:

Common migration drivers:
- Regulatory compliance (GDPR, data sovereignty)
- Latency optimization (moving closer to users)
- Cost reduction (regional pricing differences)
- Disaster recovery planning
- Cloud provider availability

Pre-Migration Planning:

Assess migration requirements:

1. Data volume and transfer time:
   Estimate based on deployment size and network bandwidth

2. Network costs:
   Cross-region data transfer incurs charges

3. Compliance requirements:
   Verify target region meets regulatory needs

4. Service availability:
   Confirm all required features available in target region

Migration Methods:

Method 1: Backup and Restore

Best for: Small to medium deployments (<100GB)

Procedure:
1. Create backup in source region:
   nova backup create source-deployment-id

2. Create new deployment in target region:
   nova deploy create --region target-region --name new-deployment

3. Restore backup to target:
   nova backup restore backup-id --target new-deployment-id

4. Validate data integrity

5. Update application connection strings

6. Delete source deployment

Downtime: Duration of backup + restore (30 min to 2 hours)

Method 2: Cross-Region Replication

Best for: Large deployments, minimal downtime requirements

Procedure:
1. Create read replica in target region:
   nova deploy create-replica source-id --region target-region

2. Monitor replication lag:
   nova deploy replication-status source-id

3. When lag is minimal (<5 seconds), promote replica:
   nova deploy promote-replica replica-id

4. Update application to use new primary

5. Decommission old primary

Downtime: 30-60 seconds during promotion

Method 3: Dual-Write Pattern

Best for: Zero-downtime requirement, complex applications

Procedure:
1. Create deployment in target region

2. Configure application to write to both regions

3. Backfill historical data to target

4. Verify target region data completeness

5. Switch reads to target region

6. Stop writes to source region

7. Decommission source

Downtime: None (requires application changes)

Data Transfer Considerations:

Optimize large data transfers:

1. Compression:
   nova backup create source-id --compress

2. Incremental transfer:
   Transfer in chunks during off-peak hours

3. Parallel streams:
   Use multiple connection streams for faster transfer

Network costs:
Monitor data transfer charges. Cross-region transfer typically costs $0.02-0.12 per GB.

DNS and Connection Updates:

Update application connections:

1. DNS changes:
   Update DNS records to point to new region
   Set low TTL before migration for quick propagation

2. Connection strings:
   Update application configuration with new endpoint

3. Load balancers:
   Reconfigure to route to new region

4. VPN connections:
   Update VPN peering if using private connectivity

Validation:

Verify successful migration:

1. Data completeness:
   Compare row counts between source and target

2. Application functionality:
   Test all critical features

3. Performance:
   Measure query latency from application servers

4. Compliance:
   Verify data residency requirements met

Rollback Plan:

Prepare for migration failure:

1. Keep source deployment running during validation period
2. Maintain backup from just before migration
3. Document DNS rollback procedure
4. Define rollback decision criteria

Cost Analysis:

Calculate migration costs:
- Data transfer fees
- Temporary dual-deployment costs
- Potential regional pricing differences
- Labor costs for migration execution

title: Users and Teams API
body:
The Users and Teams API manages workspace members, roles, and team organization. This reference covers user management, role assignment, and team collaboration features.

List Users:

GET /users

Query parameters:
- role: Filter by role
- status: Filter by status (active, invited, disabled)
- limit: Results per page

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "user-abc123",
      "email": "mailto:alice@company.com",
      "name": "Alice Smith",
      "role": "admin",
      "status": "active",
      "last_login": "2024-09-15T09:00:00Z",
      "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

Get User:

GET /users/{user_id}

Get Current User:

GET /users/me

Returns authenticated user's profile.

Invite User:

POST /users/invite

Request body:

{
  "email": "mailto:bob@company.com",
  "role": "developer",
  "teams": ["team-engineering"],
  "message": "Welcome to the team!"
}

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": "user-xyz789",
    "email": "mailto:bob@company.com",
    "status": "invited",
    "invitation_expires_at": "2024-09-22T10:30:00Z"
  }
}

Update User:

PUT /users/{user_id}

Request body:

{
  "name": "Alice Johnson",
  "role": "admin"
}

Available Roles:

- owner: Full workspace access
- admin: Administrative access
- developer: Create and manage deployments
- operator: Operate existing deployments
- viewer: Read-only access

Remove User:

DELETE /users/{user_id}

Removes user from workspace.

Resend Invitation:

POST /users/{user_id}/resend-invitation

Create Team:

POST /teams

Request body:

{
  "name": "Engineering",
  "description": "Engineering team",
  "members": ["user-abc123", "user-xyz789"]
}

List Teams:

GET /teams

Get Team:

GET /teams/{team_id}

Returns team details and members:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": "team-abc123",
    "name": "Engineering",
    "description": "Engineering team",
    "members": [
      {
        "user_id": "user-abc123",
        "name": "Alice Smith",
        "role": "admin"
      }
    ],
    "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
  }
}

Update Team:

PUT /teams/{team_id}

Delete Team:

DELETE /teams/{team_id}

Add Team Member:

POST /teams/{team_id}/members

Request body:

{
  "user_id": "user-xyz789",
  "role": "member"
}

Remove Team Member:

DELETE /teams/{team_id}/members/{user_id}

Team Permissions:

PUT /teams/{team_id}/permissions

Configure team-level permissions:

Request body:

{
  "deployments": {
    "create": true,
    "update": true,
    "delete": false
  },
  "backups": {
    "create": true,
    "restore": false
  }
}

User Activity:

GET /users/{user_id}/activity

Query parameters:
- start_date: ISO date
- end_date: ISO date
- limit: Results per page

Returns user activity log:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "activity-abc123",
      "user_id": "user-abc123",
      "action": "deployment.created",
      "resource": "dep-xyz789",
      "timestamp": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

User Sessions:

GET /users/{user_id}/sessions

List active sessions:

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "session-abc123",
      "device": "Chrome on macOS",
      "ip_address": "203.0.113.42",
      "last_active": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z",
      "created_at": "2024-09-15T09:00:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

Revoke Session:

DELETE /users/{user_id}/sessions/{session_id}

SSO Configuration:

GET /sso/config

Retrieve SSO settings (admin only).

title: API Rate Limiting and Throttling
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 interacts with the Nova REST API, which enforces rate limits to ensure fair resource allocation and service stability. Understanding rate limits helps you design resilient integrations and avoid 429 Too Many Requests errors.

Rate Limit Tiers:

The API applies different rate limits based on your account tier:

- Free tier: 100 requests per minute, 10,000 requests per day
- Pro tier: 500 requests per minute, 100,000 requests per day
- Enterprise tier: 2,000 requests per minute, 1,000,000 requests per day

Rate Limit Headers:

Every API response includes headers indicating your current rate limit status:

X-RateLimit-Limit: Maximum requests allowed in the current window
X-RateLimit-Remaining: Requests remaining in the current window
X-RateLimit-Reset: Unix timestamp when the rate limit resets

Handling Rate Limits:

When you exceed your rate limit, the API returns a 429 status code with a Retry-After header indicating seconds to wait before retrying. Implement exponential backoff in your integration:

1. Check X-RateLimit-Remaining before making requests
2. If you receive a 429, wait for the duration specified in Retry-After
3. Implement exponential backoff: double wait time after each consecutive 429
4. Use batch endpoints when available to reduce request count

Burst Allowance:

All tiers include a burst allowance of 2x the per-minute limit for short periods. This accommodates temporary spikes without triggering errors. However, sustained traffic above your tier limit will result in throttling.

Request Prioritization:

The API prioritizes requests in this order:

1. Health checks and monitoring
2. Write operations (create, update, delete)
3. Read operations (list, get)
4. Bulk operations

During high load, bulk operations may experience additional throttling to protect service availability.

title: Performance Tuning Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides numerous configuration options for optimizing deployment performance. This guide covers the most impactful settings for improving throughput, reducing latency, and maximizing resource utilization.

Connection Pool Configuration:

Connection pooling significantly impacts application performance. Configure pool size based on your workload:

[database]
max_connections = 100
min_connections = 10
connection_timeout = 30

Max connections should be 2-3x your expected concurrent queries. Too high wastes resources; too low creates bottlenecks.

Query Performance:

Enable query caching for frequently executed queries:

[performance]
query_cache_enabled = true
query_cache_size_mb = 256
query_cache_ttl = 300

Cache TTL balances freshness against performance. Adjust based on your data update frequency.

Resource Allocation:

Tune memory allocation for optimal performance:

[resources]
shared_buffers = "4GB"
work_mem = "64MB"
maintenance_work_mem = "512MB"
effective_cache_size = "12GB"

Shared buffers should be 25% of system RAM. Work_mem affects sort and hash operations; higher values speed complex queries but increase memory usage.

Checkpoint Configuration:

Checkpoints write dirty buffers to disk. Tuning reduces I/O spikes:

[checkpoint]
max_wal_size = "2GB"
min_wal_size = "1GB"
checkpoint_completion_target = 0.9

Higher checkpoint completion target spreads I/O over longer periods, reducing spikes.

Vacuum Settings:

Automatic vacuuming maintains performance:

[autovacuum]
autovacuum_enabled = true
autovacuum_max_workers = 3
autovacuum_naptime = 60

More workers handle large databases faster but consume additional resources.

Network Configuration:

Optimize network settings for your deployment:

[network]
tcp_keepalives_idle = 60
tcp_keepalives_interval = 10
tcp_keepalives_count = 5

Keepalives detect broken connections, preventing resource leaks.

Monitor performance impact:

nova deploy stats <deployment-id> --detailed

Compare metrics before and after tuning. Adjust incrementally rather than changing multiple settings simultaneously.

Performance testing:

nova deploy benchmark <deployment-id> --workload typical

Runs standardized benchmarks to measure throughput, latency percentiles, and resource utilization under load.

title: Creating Your First Deployment
body:
After installing and authenticating with NovaCLI v3.1, you're ready to create your first deployment. This tutorial walks through the deployment creation process step by step, explaining each configuration option.

Start by listing available regions to understand where you can deploy:

nova regions list

This displays all regions, their current capacity status, and approximate latency from your location. Choose a region close to your users for optimal performance.

Next, review available instance sizes:

nova sizes list

Instance sizes range from small (suitable for development and testing) to extra-large (designed for production workloads with high traffic). Each size displays CPU cores, RAM, storage, and hourly cost.

Create your deployment using the interactive wizard for a guided experience:

nova deploy create --interactive

The wizard asks for:

Deployment name: Choose a meaningful identifier. Names must be unique within your organization and can contain letters, numbers, and hyphens.

Region: Select from the list displayed earlier. Consider data residency requirements and user proximity.

Instance size: Match your workload requirements. Start small and scale up as needed. Resizing is non-disruptive in v3.1.

Environment type: Specify development, staging, or production. This tag affects monitoring, logging verbosity, and backup schedules.

Database engine: Choose PostgreSQL, MySQL, or MongoDB. Each engine version is listed with its end-of-life date.

Alternatively, provide all parameters via flags for automation:

nova deploy create --name my-first-app --region us-east-1 --size medium --env development --engine postgresql-15

NovaCLI validates your inputs and displays a cost estimate. Confirm to proceed. The deployment process takes 3-5 minutes.

Monitor progress:

nova deploy status <deployment-id> --watch

The --watch flag refreshes status automatically until deployment completes. Status progresses through: queued, provisioning, configuring, starting, active.

Once active, retrieve connection details:

nova deploy info <deployment-id> --format json

Save the connection string, username, and password securely. These credentials cannot be retrieved later without a password reset.

title: Lessons Learned: Common Migration Pitfalls
body:
Learning from common migration mistakes helps avoid costly errors. This guide documents frequently encountered pitfalls and how to avoid them.

Insufficient Testing:

Pitfall: Migrating to production without adequate testing

Consequences:
- Unexpected issues in production
- Extended downtime
- Data integrity problems
- Forced rollback

Prevention:
1. Always test in staging first
2. Replicate production environment closely
3. Test rollback procedures
4. Validate with real workload patterns
5. Include edge cases in testing

Poor Communication:

Pitfall: Inadequate stakeholder communication

Consequences:
- Surprised users during downtime
- Business disruption
- Lack of management support
- Insufficient resources allocated

Prevention:
1. Announce migration 2-4 weeks in advance
2. Send reminders at regular intervals
3. Provide specific downtime windows
4. Establish communication channels
5. Post-migration status updates

Underestimating Migration Time:

Pitfall: Insufficient time allocated for migration

Consequences:
- Rushed execution
- Incomplete validation
- Migration during business hours
- Inadequate troubleshooting time

Prevention:
1. Test in staging to estimate duration
2. Add 50% buffer to estimate
3. Schedule during lowest-traffic period
4. Plan for unexpected delays
5. Have rollback time limit

Missing Backups:

Pitfall: Migrating without recent backups

Consequences:
- No rollback option
- Risk of data loss
- Extended recovery time
- Potential data corruption

Prevention:
1. Create backup immediately before migration
2. Verify backup integrity
3. Test restore procedure
4. Keep multiple backup generations
5. Document backup location and credentials

Ignoring Dependencies:

Pitfall: Not accounting for external dependencies

Consequences:
- Broken integrations
- Third-party service failures
- API incompatibilities
- Authentication issues

Prevention:
1. Map all external dependencies
2. Verify API compatibility
3. Update integration configurations
4. Test integrations in staging
5. Coordinate with third-party vendors

Skipping Rollback Planning:

Pitfall: No rollback strategy defined

Consequences:
- Prolonged outage if issues occur
- Panic decision-making
- Incomplete rollback
- Data loss risk

Prevention:
1. Define rollback triggers beforehand
2. Document rollback procedure
3. Test rollback in staging
4. Set rollback time limits
5. Assign rollback decision authority

Inadequate Monitoring:

Pitfall: Insufficient monitoring during migration

Consequences:
- Issues go undetected
- Delayed problem response
- Incomplete validation
- Performance degradation

Prevention:
1. Enhanced monitoring during migration
2. Real-time dashboards
3. Alert thresholds tightened
4. Dedicated monitoring personnel
5. Historical baseline for comparison

Configuration Drift:

Pitfall: Staging and production configurations differ

Consequences:
- Staging tests don't reflect production
- Unexpected production behavior
- Migration failures in production

Prevention:
1. Configuration management tools
2. Regular staging-production sync
3. Documented configuration differences
4. Automated configuration validation

Premature Decommissioning:

Pitfall: Deleting old deployment too quickly

Consequences:
- No rollback option
- Lost data or configuration
- Extended recovery if issues found

Prevention:
1. Validation period before decommissioning
2. Keep old deployment for 7-30 days
3. Monitor new deployment thoroughly
4. Final stakeholder sign-off required

Lack of Training:

Pitfall: Team unprepared for new version

Consequences:
- Operational errors
- Inefficient troubleshooting
- Underutilization of new features
- Support burden

Prevention:
1. Training sessions before migration
2. Documentation updates
3. Hands-on practice in staging
4. Post-migration support available

Best Practices Summary:

1. Test thoroughly in staging
2. Communicate early and often
3. Buffer time estimates significantly
4. Always have recent backups
5. Map and test dependencies
6. Plan and practice rollback
7. Monitor intensively
8. Validate configuration parity
9. Delay decommissioning old resources
10. Train team adequately

Post-Mortem Process:

After every migration:
1. Document what went well
2. Identify issues encountered
3. Record time spent
4. Gather team feedback
5. Update procedures for next time
6. Share lessons learned

title: Logs API Reference
body:
The Logs API provides access to deployment logs, audit trails, and system events. This reference covers log querying, filtering, and streaming capabilities.

Get Deployment Logs:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/logs

Query parameters:
- lines: Number of lines (default 100, max 10000)
- since: ISO timestamp or duration (e.g., "1h", "24h")
- until: ISO timestamp
- level: Log level filter (debug, info, warning, error, critical)
- search: Text search query
- follow: Stream logs (true/false)

Example:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer API_KEY" 
  "https://api.novacli.io/v1/deployments/dep-abc123/logs?lines=500&level=error&since=1h"

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "logs": [
      {
        "timestamp": "2024-09-15T10:30:00.123Z",
        "level": "error",
        "message": "Connection timeout to database",
        "source": "database-connector",
        "metadata": {
          "deployment_id": "dep-abc123",
          "host": "db-primary"
        }
      }
    ],
    "has_more": true,
    "next_cursor": "cursor-xyz789"
  }
}

Stream Logs:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/logs?follow=true

Streams logs via Server-Sent Events (SSE):

Content-Type: text/event-stream

data: {"timestamp":"2024-09-15T10:30:00Z","level":"info","message":"Query executed successfully"}

data: {"timestamp":"2024-09-15T10:30:01Z","level":"info","message":"Connection pool size: 50"}

Search Logs:

POST /logs/search

Advanced log search with multiple filters:

Request body:

{
  "query": "connection timeout",
  "deployment_ids": ["dep-abc123", "dep-xyz789"],
  "start_time": "2024-09-15T00:00:00Z",
  "end_time": "2024-09-15T23:59:59Z",
  "levels": ["error", "critical"],
  "sources": ["database-connector"],
  "limit": 1000
}

Response includes matching logs and aggregations.

Log Aggregations:

POST /logs/aggregate

Aggregate logs by field:

Request body:

{
  "deployment_id": "dep-abc123",
  "start_time": "2024-09-15T00:00:00Z",
  "end_time": "2024-09-15T23:59:59Z",
  "group_by": "level",
  "aggregation": "count"
}

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "aggregations": [
      {"level": "info", "count": 15000},
      {"level": "warning", "count": 250},
      {"level": "error", "count": 12}
    ]
  }
}

Export Logs:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/logs/export

Query parameters:
- format: Export format (json, csv, txt)
- start_time: ISO timestamp
- end_time: ISO timestamp
- compression: Compression format (gzip, none)

Returns download URL:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "download_url": "https://exports.novacli.io/...",
    "expires_at": "2024-09-15T12:00:00Z",
    "size_bytes": 10485760
  }
}

Audit Logs:

GET /audit-logs

Query administrative actions:

Query parameters:
- user_id: Filter by user
- action: Filter by action type
- resource: Filter by resource ID
- start_date: ISO date
- end_date: ISO date

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": [
    {
      "id": "audit-abc123",
      "timestamp": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z",
      "user_id": "user-abc123",
      "user_email": "mailto:alice@company.com",
      "action": "deployment.deleted",
      "resource": "dep-xyz789",
      "ip_address": "203.0.113.42",
      "user_agent": "NovaCLI/3.1.0"
    }
  ]
}

Log Retention:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/logs/retention

View log retention policy:

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "retention_days": 30,
    "oldest_log": "2024-08-16T00:00:00Z",
    "storage_used_gb": 5.2
  }
}

Log Alerts:

POST /log-alerts

Create alert based on log patterns:

Request body:

{
  "name": "High Error Rate",
  "deployment_id": "dep-abc123",
  "query": "level:error",
  "threshold": 10,
  "window_minutes": 5,
  "channels": ["email", "slack"]
}

Tail Logs:

GET /deployments/{deployment_id}/logs/tail

Live tail similar to tail -f.

title: SSL/TLS Certificate Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 deployments use SSL/TLS encryption by default. This guide covers custom certificate configuration for organizations with specific security requirements or internal certificate authorities.

Default Certificate Behavior:

NovaCLI automatically provisions Let's Encrypt certificates for all deployments. Certificates renew automatically 30 days before expiration.

Custom Certificate Installation:

For custom certificates, provide certificate, private key, and CA chain:

nova settings set deployment.<deployment-id>.tls.cert_file /path/to/certificate.pem
nova settings set deployment.<deployment-id>.tls.key_file /path/to/private-key.pem
nova settings set deployment.<deployment-id>.http://tls.ca_file /path/to/ca-chain.pem

Reload configuration to apply:

nova deploy reload <deployment-id>

Certificate Requirements:

Certificates must meet these criteria:
- PEM format
- Valid for deployment hostname
- RSA 2048-bit or higher, or ECDSA P-256 or higher
- Not expired
- Complete certificate chain included

Validate certificate before installation:

openssl x509 -in certificate.pem -text -noout

Verify subject alternative names match your deployment hostname.

Client Certificate Authentication:

For mutual TLS authentication, enable client certificate verification:

[tls]
client_cert_required = true
client_ca_file = "/path/to/client-ca.pem"

Only clients presenting valid certificates signed by the specified CA can connect.

Cipher Suite Configuration:

Restrict allowed cipher suites for enhanced security:

[tls]
min_protocol_version = "TLSv1.3"
cipher_suites = "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256"

Balance security against client compatibility. Older clients may not support TLS 1.3.

Certificate Monitoring:

Monitor certificate expiration:

nova deploy cert-status <deployment-id>

Displays expiration date, issuer, and validity status.

Set expiration alerts:

nova alerts create 
  --type cert-expiration 
  --deployment <deployment-id> 
  --threshold 30 
  --email mailto:security@company.com

Receive notifications 30 days before expiration.

Troubleshooting:

Common certificate issues:

- Hostname mismatch: Certificate CN or SAN must match deployment hostname
- Incomplete chain: Include all intermediate certificates
- Wrong key: Private key must match certificate public key
- Expired certificate: Check validity dates

Test SSL configuration:

openssl s_client -connect <hostname>:5432 -showcerts

title: Understanding Regions and Availability Zones
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 operates across multiple geographic regions and availability zones to provide low-latency access and high availability for your deployments. Understanding the region architecture helps you make informed decisions about deployment placement.

Regions represent physically separate geographic areas. Each region operates independently with its own infrastructure, power, and networking. NovaCLI currently supports 15 regions across North America, Europe, Asia-Pacific, and South America.

List all regions:

nova regions list --details

This displays region codes (us-east-1, eu-west-2), human-readable names, continent, and operational status. Regions marked as "limited capacity" may have longer provisioning times.

Availability zones are isolated locations within regions. Each zone has independent power, cooling, and networking to protect against localized failures. Production deployments can span multiple zones for fault tolerance.

When creating a deployment, specify a region but not an availability zone. NovaCLI automatically selects zones based on current capacity and balancing algorithms. Multi-zone deployments distribute replicas across zones automatically.

For high availability configurations:

nova deploy create --name ha-app --region us-west-1 --ha-mode multi-zone --replicas 3

This creates a deployment with three replicas distributed across availability zones. If one zone fails, the remaining replicas continue serving traffic.

Network latency varies between regions. Test latency from your location:

nova regions ping

This performs latency tests to all regions and ranks them by response time. Choose regions with <50ms latency for interactive applications.

Data residency regulations may require keeping data within specific geographic boundaries. Regions are grouped by regulatory framework:

- US regions: Compliant with US data protection standards
- EU regions: GDPR compliant
- APAC regions: Varied compliance depending on specific requirements

Check region compliance:

nova regions info <region-code> --compliance

Cross-region replication enables disaster recovery by maintaining copies in geographically distant regions. Configure during deployment creation or add later:

nova deploy update <deployment-id> --backup-region eu-central-1

Backup regions store encrypted copies updated every 6 hours.

title: Troubleshooting Log Collection Failures
body:
Log collection is essential for debugging deployment issues. When log retrieval fails in NovaCLI v3.1, several factors may be responsible, from permissions to retention policies.

Log Access Permissions:

Insufficient permissions are the most common cause of log collection failures. Error: "Permission denied: cannot access logs for deployment." Verify your role has log access:

nova auth status

The Viewer role and above can read logs. If you lack permissions, request a role upgrade from your administrator.

Log Retention Limits:

Logs older than your plan's retention period are automatically deleted. Free plans retain 7 days, Pro retains 30 days, Enterprise retains 90 days. Attempting to retrieve older logs fails with "No logs available for specified time range."

Query the available log time range:

nova logs deployment-id --available-range

This shows the earliest and latest log timestamps.

Large Log Queries:

Querying large log volumes may timeout. Error: "Log query exceeded maximum execution time." Narrow your query with filters:

nova logs deployment-id --since "2024-09-01" --until "2024-09-02" --level error

Filtering by level, source, or time range reduces data volume and improves query performance.

Log Streaming Issues:

Real-time log streaming (nova logs --follow) may disconnect due to network instability. The connection automatically reconnects, but gaps may occur during disconnection. For continuous monitoring, use the Nova dashboard's log viewer, which handles reconnection transparently.

Log Export Failures:

Exporting large log volumes to files may fail due to memory constraints or disk space. Export in smaller time windows:

nova logs deployment-id --since "2024-09-01 00:00" --until "2024-09-01 06:00" > logs-part1.txt
nova logs deployment-id --since "2024-09-01 06:00" --until "2024-09-01 12:00" > logs-part2.txt

Missing Logs:

If logs are unexpectedly missing, verify logging is enabled for your deployment:

nova deploy get deployment-id --format json | jq '.logging.enabled'

Enable logging if disabled:

nova deploy update deployment-id --enable-logging

Log Format Issues:

Corrupted log entries may cause parsing errors. Use the --raw flag to retrieve unparsed logs:

nova logs deployment-id --raw

This bypasses parsing and returns raw log data.

title: NovaCLI v3.1 Command Reference
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 restructured the command hierarchy to improve discoverability and consistency. This guide covers the current command syntax and common usage patterns for the latest stable release.

The v3.0 release introduced a major breaking change: the nova config command was deprecated and replaced with nova settings. This change aligns NovaCLI with industry standards and reduces confusion with configuration file management versus runtime settings management.

All NovaCLI commands follow the pattern: nova [global-flags] <command> <subcommand> [flags] [arguments]

Global flags apply to any command and must appear immediately after nova:

--profile <name>: Use a specific configuration profile
--config <path>: Override default config file location
--verbose: Enable detailed output
--quiet: Suppress non-error messages
--format <json|yaml|table>: Set output format

Core commands in v3.1:

nova settings show: Display current configuration
nova settings set <key> <value>: Modify a configuration value
nova settings reload: Reload configuration from file
nova settings validate: Check configuration syntax

nova deploy start: Initialize a new deployment
nova deploy status: Check deployment progress
nova deploy rollback: Revert to previous version

nova auth login: Authenticate with credentials
nova auth logout: Clear authentication tokens
nova auth whoami: Display current user identity

nova logs tail: Stream real-time logs
nova logs search <query>: Search historical logs
nova logs export --from <date> --to <date>: Export log archive

The nova settings command replaced all functionality previously under nova config. Commands that worked in v2.x no longer function:

DEPRECATED (v2.x): nova config get http://database.host
CURRENT (v3.x): nova settings show http://database.host

DEPRECATED (v2.x): nova config update
CURRENT (v3.x): nova settings reload

Command aliases provide shortcuts for frequent operations:

ns = nova settings
nd = nova deploy
na = nova auth

For detailed help on any command, use: nova <command> --help

Common errors include using deprecated v2.x syntax or forgetting required flags. The CLI provides helpful suggestions when commands fail.

title: Configuration Validation and Testing
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides tools for validating configuration files before deployment, preventing errors and misconfigurations. This guide covers validation commands, testing strategies, and troubleshooting.

Basic Validation:

Validate configuration syntax:

nova config validate config.toml

Checks:
- TOML syntax correctness
- Required fields present
- Type correctness
- Value constraints

Reports errors with line numbers.

Schema Validation:

Validate against strict schema:

nova config validate config.toml --strict

Strict mode:
- Disallows unknown properties
- Enforces recommended settings
- Warns about deprecated options

Dry-Run Deployment:

Test configuration without creating deployment:

nova deploy create --config config.toml --dry-run

Simulates deployment, reports what would happen without making changes.

Configuration Diff:

Compare configurations:

nova config diff config-old.toml config-new.toml

Highlights added, removed, and modified settings.

Compare against running deployment:

nova settings diff <deployment-id> --against config.toml

Identifies configuration drift.

Linting:

Check for common issues and anti-patterns:

nova config lint config.toml

Reports:
- Security concerns (weak settings)
- Performance issues (suboptimal values)
- Style inconsistencies
- Deprecated options

Lint severity levels:
- Error: Must fix
- Warning: Should fix
- Info: Consider fixing

Configuration Testing:

Automated testing for configuration changes:

# http://test-config.sh
nova config validate production.toml
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
  nova config lint production.toml
  nova deploy create --config production.toml --dry-run
fi

Integrate into CI/CD pipeline.

Variable Expansion Test:

Verify environment variable substitution:

nova config expand config.toml

Displays configuration with variables expanded, without exposing sensitive values.

Secure mode redacts secrets:

nova config expand config.toml --redact-secrets

Dependency Validation:

Check external dependencies:

nova config check-deps config.toml

Verifies:
- Network connectivity to required services
- DNS resolution for hostnames
- Port availability
- Secret backend accessibility

Constraint Validation:

Enforce organizational policies:

# policy.toml
[constraints]
min_backup_retention_days = 7
required_ssl = true
allowed_regions = ["us-east-1", "us-west-2"]

Validate against policy:

nova config validate config.toml --policy policy.toml

Fails if configuration violates policy constraints.

Export Validation Report:

Generate detailed report:

nova config validate config.toml --report validation-report.json

JSON output suitable for parsing by automation tools.

Interactive Validation:

Interactive mode suggests fixes:

nova config validate config.toml --interactive

Prompts to apply suggested fixes automatically.

Configuration Templates:

Start from validated templates:

nova config init --template production

Templates: development, staging, production, high-availability.

Validation Best Practices:

- Validate in CI before merge
- Use strict mode in production
- Test configuration changes in staging first
- Maintain policy file for organizational standards
- Review lint warnings regularly

Troubleshooting Validation Errors:

Common errors:

- Syntax error: Check TOML formatting
- Missing required field: Add required configuration
- Type mismatch: Correct value type
- Invalid value: Check constraints and ranges

Verbose output for debugging:

nova config validate config.toml --verbose

title: Connecting to Your Deployment
body:
Once your NovaCLI deployment reaches the active state, you can connect using standard database clients, application frameworks, or the built-in CLI tools. This guide covers connection methods for all supported database engines.

Retrieve connection information:

nova deploy info <deployment-id>

This displays the connection string, hostname, port, database name, username, and initial password. Connection strings are formatted for immediate use with popular tools.

For PostgreSQL deployments, connect using psql:

psql $(nova deploy connection-string <deployment-id>)

Or manually:

psql -h hostname -p 5432 -U username -d database_name

MySQL deployments use mysql client:

mysql -h hostname -P 3306 -u username -p database_name

MongoDB deployments require mongosh:

mongosh $(nova deploy connection-string <deployment-id> --format mongo)

Connection strings include SSL/TLS parameters by default. All NovaCLI deployments enforce encrypted connections. Disable encryption only for testing:

nova deploy info <deployment-id> --insecure-connection

Application frameworks typically need individual parameters rather than connection strings. Extract specific values:

nova deploy info <deployment-id> --output yaml

This provides structured output suitable for environment variables or configuration files.

For Python applications using SQLAlchemy:

from sqlalchemy import create_engine
engine = create_engine(connection_string)

Node.js applications using connection pools:

const pool = new Pool({
  connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
  ssl: { rejectUnauthorized: true }
})

Test connectivity:

nova deploy test-connection <deployment-id>

This verifies network reachability, authentication, and SSL certificate validity. If connection fails, check:

- Firewall rules allow outbound connections to the deployment IP
- IP allowlist includes your current IP (check with nova ip-allowlist list)
- Credentials haven't expired

Connection pooling improves performance by reusing database connections. Configure pool size based on your application's concurrency:

nova settings set deployment.<deployment-id>.max_connections 100

Monitor active connections:

nova deploy stats <deployment-id> --metric connections

title: Resolving Concurrent Connection Errors
body:
Connection limit errors prevent new clients from connecting to deployments. Managing connection pools and identifying connection leaks resolves these issues in NovaCLI v3.1.

Error Messages:

Connection limit errors appear as:

- "Too many connections: limit 100 reached"
- "Connection refused: max_connections exceeded"
- "Connection pool exhausted"

Monitoring Connections:

View current connection usage:

nova deploy connections deployment-id

This shows active connections, idle connections, and connection limit.

Increasing Connection Limit:

Raise the maximum connection limit:

nova deploy update deployment-id --max-connections 200

Connection limits are constrained by deployment size. Larger deployments support more connections.

Connection Pooling:

Implement connection pooling in applications to reuse connections:

- Configure pool size: typically 10-20 connections per application instance
- Set max lifetime: recycle connections after 30-60 minutes
- Enable connection validation: test connections before use

Identifying Connection Leaks:

Applications failing to close connections cause leaks. Find long-lived idle connections:

nova deploy connections deployment-id --idle --min-duration 3600

This shows connections idle for over 1 hour. Investigate application code for unclosed connections.

Killing Idle Connections:

Force-close idle connections to free capacity:

nova deploy kill-connection deployment-id connection-id

For bulk termination of idle connections:

nova deploy kill-connections deployment-id --idle --min-duration 1800

Connection Timeout:

Configure idle connection timeout to automatically close stale connections:

nova deploy update deployment-id --idle-connection-timeout 600

Connections idle for 10 minutes are automatically closed.

PgBouncer Integration:

For applications with many short-lived connections, use connection pooling middleware:

nova deploy enable-pgbouncer deployment-id --pool-mode transaction --pool-size 50

PgBouncer pools connections, allowing thousands of client connections while maintaining a small number of database connections.

Monitoring and Alerts:

Alert when approaching connection limits:

nova alerts create --deployment deployment-id --metric connection-usage --threshold 85

This alerts at 85% of max_connections, allowing proactive response.

title: Error Codes and Messages Reference
body:
The NovaCLI API uses standard HTTP status codes and custom error codes to communicate failures. This reference documents all error codes, their meanings, and recommended client responses.

Error Response Format:

All API errors return consistent JSON structure:

{
  "status": "error",
  "error": {
    "code": "ERROR_CODE",
    "message": "Human-readable error description",
    "details": {
      "field": "Additional context",
      "request_id": "req-abc123"
    },
    "documentation_url": "https://docs.novacli.io/errors/ERROR_CODE"
  }
}

HTTP Status Codes:

400 Bad Request:
- INVALID_PARAMETER: Parameter validation failed
- MISSING_REQUIRED_FIELD: Required field not provided
- INVALID_FORMAT: Data format incorrect
- INVALID_JSON: Request body not valid JSON

401 Unauthorized:
- INVALID_API_KEY: API key invalid or expired
- API_KEY_REQUIRED: No authentication provided
- TOKEN_EXPIRED: OAuth token expired
- INVALID_TOKEN: Token signature invalid

403 Forbidden:
- INSUFFICIENT_PERMISSIONS: User lacks required permissions
- RESOURCE_FORBIDDEN: Access to resource denied
- SCOPE_INSUFFICIENT: API key missing required scope
- IP_BLOCKED: Request from blocked IP address

404 Not Found:
- RESOURCE_NOT_FOUND: Requested resource doesn't exist
- DEPLOYMENT_NOT_FOUND: Deployment ID invalid
- BACKUP_NOT_FOUND: Backup ID invalid
- USER_NOT_FOUND: User ID invalid
- ENDPOINT_NOT_FOUND: API endpoint doesn't exist

409 Conflict:
- RESOURCE_CONFLICT: Resource already exists
- DEPLOYMENT_NAME_TAKEN: Deployment name in use
- CONCURRENT_MODIFICATION: Resource modified concurrently
- STATE_CONFLICT: Operation invalid for current state

422 Unprocessable Entity:
- VALIDATION_FAILED: Business logic validation failed
- INVALID_CONFIGURATION: Configuration invalid
- CAPACITY_INSUFFICIENT: Insufficient capacity available
- QUOTA_EXCEEDED: Resource quota exceeded

429 Too Many Requests:
- RATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED: Rate limit threshold exceeded
- TOO_MANY_REQUESTS: Generic rate limiting

500 Internal Server Error:
- INTERNAL_ERROR: Unexpected server error
- DATABASE_ERROR: Database operation failed
- SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE: Backend service unavailable

503 Service Unavailable:
- MAINTENANCE_MODE: API in maintenance mode
- TEMPORARY_UNAVAILABLE: Temporary service disruption

Deployment Errors:

- DEPLOYMENT_CREATE_FAILED: Deployment creation failed
- DEPLOYMENT_START_FAILED: Failed to start deployment
- DEPLOYMENT_STOP_FAILED: Failed to stop deployment
- DEPLOYMENT_DELETE_FAILED: Deletion failed
- DEPLOYMENT_SCALING_FAILED: Scaling operation failed
- DEPLOYMENT_TIMEOUT: Operation timed out

Backup Errors:

- BACKUP_CREATE_FAILED: Backup creation failed
- BACKUP_RESTORE_FAILED: Restoration failed
- BACKUP_VERIFY_FAILED: Integrity verification failed
- BACKUP_EXPIRED: Backup has expired
- BACKUP_CORRUPTED: Backup data corrupted

Authentication Errors:

- LOGIN_FAILED: Login credentials invalid
- MFA_REQUIRED: Multi-factor authentication required
- MFA_INVALID: MFA code incorrect
- SESSION_EXPIRED: User session expired
- PASSWORD_WEAK: Password doesn't meet requirements

Error Handling Best Practices:

1. Always check HTTP status code first
2. Parse error.code for programmatic handling
3. Display error.message to users
4. Log error.details.request_id for support
5. Implement exponential backoff for 429/503
6. Don't retry 4xx errors (except 429)
7. Retry 5xx errors with backoff

Retry Strategy:

Retryable errors: 429, 500, 502, 503, 504
Non-retryable errors: All 4xx except 429

Exponential backoff formula:
wait_time = base_delay  (2  attempt) + jitter

Example (Python):

import time
import random

def api_call_with_retry(func, max_attempts=3):
    for attempt in range(max_attempts):
        try:
            return func()
        except ApiError as e:
            if e.status_code not in [429, 500, 502, 503, 504]:
                raise
            if attempt == max_attempts - 1:
                raise
            wait = (2 * attempt) + random.uniform(0, 1)
            time.sleep(wait)

title: Common Getting Started Issues
body:
New NovaCLI v3.1 users occasionally encounter setup issues during installation, authentication, or first deployment. This guide addresses the most common problems and their solutions.

Installation Issues:

Problem: "nova: command not found" after installation.

Solution: The installation directory isn't in your PATH. Add it manually:

For Linux/macOS: echo 'export PATH="$PATH:/usr/local/bin"' >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc

For Windows: Add C:Program FilesNovaCLI to your PATH through System Properties.

Alternatively, reinstall using a package manager which handles PATH configuration automatically.

Problem: Permission denied errors on Linux/macOS.

Solution: The nova binary lacks execute permissions. Fix with:

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/nova

Authentication Issues:

Problem: "Invalid credentials" when running nova auth login.

Solution: Verify you're using the correct email and password for your Nova account. If you signed up with OAuth, use the browser-based flow:

nova auth login --browser

Problem: "Token expired" errors.

Solution: Authentication tokens expire after 30 days. Re-authenticate:

nova auth login --force

The --force flag replaces the existing token even if it hasn't expired.

Deployment Creation Issues:

Problem: "Region not available" error.

Solution: The selected region is at capacity. Choose an alternative region:

nova regions list --available-only

Problem: "Quota exceeded" preventing deployment creation.

Solution: Your account has reached its deployment limit. View current usage:

nova quota show

Delete unused deployments or request a quota increase through the web console.

Problem: Deployment stuck in "provisioning" state.

Solution: Provisioning typically completes within 5 minutes. If stuck longer:

nova deploy status <deployment-id> --debug

This reveals detailed status messages. Contact support if provisioning exceeds 15 minutes.

Connection Issues:

Problem: Cannot connect to deployment from application.

Solution: Check IP allowlist:

nova ip-allowlist list

Add your IP:

nova ip-allowlist add <your-ip>/32

Problem: SSL certificate verification fails.

Solution: Ensure your system has updated CA certificates. On Ubuntu:

sudo apt update && sudo apt install ca-certificates

title: SDK Documentation for Python
body:
The official NovaCLI Python SDK provides a high-level interface to the NovaCLI API. This reference covers installation, configuration, and common usage patterns for Python developers.

Installation:

Install via pip:

pip install novacli-sdk

Requires Python 3.8 or higher.

Verify installation:

python -c "import novacli; print(novacli.version)"

Basic Configuration:

Initialize client:

from novacli import Client

client = Client(api_key="nova_sk_abc123...")

Alternatively, use environment variable:

export NOVACLI_API_KEY="nova_sk_abc123..."

from novacli import Client
client = Client()  # Reads from environment

Client configuration options:

client = Client(
    api_key="nova_sk_abc123...",
    base_url="https://api.novacli.io",
    timeout=30,
    max_retries=3,
    region="us-east-1"
)

Deployment Operations:

List deployments:

deployments = client.deployments.list(
    status="active",
    region="us-east-1",
    limit=50
)

for deployment in deployments:
    print(f"{http://deployment.id}: {http://deployment.name}")

Get deployment:

deployment = client.deployments.get("dep-abc123")
print(f"Status: {deployment.status}")
print(f"Region: {deployment.region}")

Create deployment:

deployment = client.deployments.create(
    name="my-deployment",
    size="medium",
    region="us-east-1",
    config={
        "max_connections": 100,
        "backup_enabled": True
    },
    tags={"env": "production"}
)

print(f"Created: {http://deployment.id}")

Update deployment:

deployment = client.deployments.update(
    "dep-abc123",
    size="large",
    config={"max_connections": 200}
)

Delete deployment:

client.deployments.delete("dep-abc123", force=False)

Backup Operations:

List backups:

backups = client.backups.list(
    deployment_id="dep-abc123",
    type="manual"
)

Create backup:

backup = client.backups.create(
    deployment_id="dep-abc123",
    name="pre-migration",
    retention_days=90
)

Restore backup:

restore = client.backups.restore(
    deployment_id="dep-abc123",
    backup_id="backup-xyz789",
    verify_before_restore=True
)

print(f"Restore status: {restore.status}")

Error Handling:

SDK exceptions:

from novacli import (
    ApiError,
    AuthenticationError,
    NotFoundError,
    RateLimitError
)

try:
    deployment = client.deployments.get("invalid-id")
except NotFoundError as e:
    print(f"Deployment not found: {e}")
except AuthenticationError as e:
    print(f"Authentication failed: {e}")
except RateLimitError as e:
    print(f"Rate limited. Retry after {e.retry_after}s")
except ApiError as e:
    print(f"API error: {e.status_code} - {e.message}")

Pagination:

Automatic pagination:

for deployment in client.deployments.iterate():
    print(http://deployment.name)

Manual pagination:

page = client.deployments.list(limit=50)
while page.has_more:
    for deployment in http://page.data:
        print(http://deployment.name)
    page = client.deployments.list(
        limit=50,
        cursor=http://page.next_cursor
    )

Async Support:

Async client:

from novacli import AsyncClient
import asyncio

async def main():
    async with AsyncClient(api_key="...") as client:
        deployments = await client.deployments.list()
        for deployment in deployments:
            print(http://deployment.name)

http://asyncio.run(main())

Streaming Logs:

Stream deployment logs:

for log in http://client.logs.stream(deployment_id="dep-abc123"):
    print(f"{log.timestamp} [{log.level}] {log.message}")

Webhooks:

Create webhook:

webhook = client.webhooks.create(
    url="https://myapp.com/webhook",
    events=["deployment.created", "deployment.failed"],
    secret="webhook_secret_123"
)

Verify webhook signature:

import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(secret, body, signature):
    expected = http://hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        body.encode(),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    return http://hmac.compare_digest(
        f"sha256={expected}",
        signature
    )

SDK Configuration:

Custom timeout:

client = Client(
    api_key="...",
    timeout=60,
    connect_timeout=10
)

Proxy support:

client = Client(
    api_key="...",
    proxies={
        "http": "http://proxy.company.com:8080",
        "https": "https://proxy.company.com:8080"
    }
)

Logging:

import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

Shows all API requests and responses.

title: GitOps Integration Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 supports GitOps workflows for declarative configuration management. This guide covers Git repository integration, automated sync, and drift detection.

GitOps Activation:

Enable GitOps mode:

[gitops]
enabled = true
repository_url = "https://github.com/company/novacli-config.git"
branch = "main"
auto_sync = true

Repository Structure:

Organize configurations:

novacli-config/
  environments/
    production/
      deployments/
      configs/
    staging/
      deployments/
      configs/
  templates/
  policies/

Authentication:

Configure Git authentication:

[gitops.auth]
method = "ssh"  # or "token", "app"
ssh_key_path = "/etc/nova/ssh/id_rsa"
known_hosts_path = "/etc/nova/ssh/known_hosts"

For token auth:

[gitops.auth]
method = "token"
token = "${GIT_TOKEN}"

Sync Configuration:

Configure sync behavior:

[gitops.sync]
interval = 300  # seconds
auto_prune = true
self_heal = true
retry_limit = 5

Manual sync:

nova gitops sync <deployment-id>

Force sync:

nova gitops sync <deployment-id> --force

Drift Detection:

Detect configuration drift:

[gitops.drift]
detection_enabled = true
check_interval = 600  # seconds
alert_on_drift = true

View drift:

nova gitops diff <deployment-id>

Shows differences between Git and actual state.

Auto-Remediation:

Automatically fix drift:

[gitops.remediation]
auto_remediate = true
remediation_strategy = "git_wins"  # or "manual", "merge"

Commit Strategy:

Define commit workflow:

[gitops.commits]
require_pull_request = true
auto_commit_interval = 0  # Manual commits only
commit_message_template = "[novacli] {action} {resource}"

Create PR for changes:

nova deploy update <deployment-id> 
  --size large 
  --gitops-pr "Increase deployment size"

Branch Strategy:

Manage branches:

[gitops.branches]
production_branch = "main"
staging_branch = "staging"
feature_branch_pattern = "feature/*"

Deploy from branch:

nova deploy create 
  --gitops-branch feature/new-config

Validation:

Validate before apply:

[gitops.validation]
pre_sync_validation = true
schema_validation = true
policy_validation = true

Validation webhook:

[gitops.webhooks]
validation_url = "https://validator.company.com/validate"
timeout = 30  # seconds

Rollback:

Rollback to previous Git revision:

nova gitops rollback <deployment-id> 
  --to-commit abc123

Automatic rollback:

[gitops.rollback]
auto_rollback_on_failure = true
health_check_timeout = 300

Multi-Environment:

Manage multiple environments:

[gitops.environments]

[[gitops.environments.env]]
name = "production"
path = "environments/production"
require_approval = true

[[gitops.environments.env]]
name = "staging"
path = "environments/staging"
auto_promote = false

Notifications:

Notify on GitOps events:

[gitops.notifications]
sync_success = ["slack"]
sync_failure = ["slack", "pagerduty"]
drift_detected = ["slack"]

Encryption:

Encrypt secrets in Git:

[gitops.encryption]
method = "sealed_secrets"  # or "sops", "vault"
public_key_path = "/etc/nova/http://sealing-key.pub"

Seal secret:

nova gitops seal-secret 
  --input secret.yaml 
  --output sealed-secret.yaml

Audit:

Audit GitOps operations:

[gitops.audit]
log_all_operations = true
log_destination = "elasticsearch"

View GitOps history:

nova gitops history <deployment-id>

Policy Enforcement:

Enforce policies via Git:

[gitops.policy]
enforce_policies = true
policy_path = "policies/"
block_on_violation = true

title: Resolving Connection Timeout Errors
body:
Connection timeout errors are among the most common issues when using NovaCLI v3.1. These errors typically manifest as "Connection to http://api.nova.io timed out after 30 seconds" and can stem from network configuration, firewall rules, or API availability.

Common Causes:

Network connectivity issues are the primary cause. Verify your internet connection and ensure your network allows HTTPS traffic on port 443. Corporate networks often restrict outbound connections, requiring firewall rule updates or proxy configuration.

Firewall and Proxy Settings:

If you're behind a corporate firewall, configure NovaCLI to use your proxy:

nova config set proxy.url http://proxy.company.com:8080
nova config set proxy.username your-username

For authentication, the proxy password is stored securely in your system keychain.

DNS Resolution:

DNS issues can cause connection failures. Test DNS resolution:

nslookup http://api.nova.io

If this fails, configure alternative DNS servers (such as 8.8.8.8 or 1.1.1.1) in your network settings.

API Status:

Verify Nova service availability at http://status.nova.io. Scheduled maintenance or incidents may cause temporary connectivity issues. The status page displays current service health and upcoming maintenance windows.

Timeout Configuration:

Increase timeout values for slow networks:

nova config set network.timeout 60

This sets the connection timeout to 60 seconds instead of the default 30.

SSL Certificate Verification:

Corporate networks using SSL inspection may cause certificate validation errors. If you see "SSL certificate verification failed," your network is likely intercepting HTTPS traffic. Configure NovaCLI to trust your corporate CA certificate:

nova config set http://ssl.ca_bundle /path/to/corporate-ca.pem

Diagnostic Commands:

Run connection diagnostics:

nova debug connection

This tests connectivity to all Nova API endpoints and reports detailed error information, including DNS resolution, TCP connection, and SSL handshake status.

title: SDK Documentation for JavaScript
API Error Codes and Troubleshooting
body:
The Nova REST API uses standard HTTP status codes to indicate the success or failure of requests. Understanding error codes helps diagnose issues quickly and implement proper error handling in your integrations.

Success Codes:

200 OK: Request succeeded, response body contains requested data
201 Created: Resource created successfully, Location header contains new resource URL
204 No Content: Request succeeded, no response body (typically for delete operations)

Client Error Codes:

400 Bad Request: Invalid request syntax or missing required parameters. Check the error message in the response body for details.

401 Unauthorized: Authentication required or invalid credentials. Verify your API token with nova auth status.

403 Forbidden: Valid authentication but insufficient permissions. Check your account role and resource permissions.

404 Not Found: Resource does not exist. Verify the resource ID and ensure it hasn't been deleted.

409 Conflict: Request conflicts with current resource state. Common when attempting to create a duplicate resource or modify a resource that has been updated by another client.

422 Unprocessable Entity: Request is syntactically correct but semantically invalid. Review field validation requirements in the API documentation.

429 Too Many Requests: Rate limit exceeded. Check X-RateLimit-Reset header and implement exponential backoff.

Server Error Codes:

500 Internal Server Error: Unexpected server error. Retry the request with exponential backoff. If the issue persists, contact support with the X-Request-ID from the response headers.

503 Service Unavailable: Temporary service disruption or scheduled maintenance. Check http://status.nova.io for service status and retry after a delay.

Error Response Format:

All error responses include a JSON body with detailed information:

{"error": {"code": "INVALID_DEPLOYMENT_CONFIG", "message": "Deployment size 'extra-huge' is not valid", "details": {"valid_sizes": ["small", "medium", "large"]}}}

Use the error code for programmatic handling and the message for user-facing error display.

title: Secrets Management Integration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 integrates with external secrets management systems to avoid storing sensitive values in configuration files. This guide covers integration with HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, and Azure Key Vault.

Secrets Management Benefits:

- Centralized secret storage
- Audit logging of secret access
- Automatic rotation
- Fine-grained access control
- Encryption at rest and in transit

HashiCorp Vault Integration:

Configure Vault connection:

[secrets.vault]
address = "https://vault.company.com:8200"
auth_method = "token"  # or "kubernetes", "aws"
token = "${VAULT_TOKEN}"
namespace = "admin"

Reference secrets in configuration:

[database]
password = "vault://secret/data/database#password"

[api]
api_key = "vault://secret/data/api#key"

NovaCLI fetches secrets at runtime. Secrets never written to disk.

AWS Secrets Manager:

Configure AWS Secrets Manager:

[http://secrets.aws]
region = "us-east-1"
auth_method = "iam"  # Uses IAM role

Reference secrets:

[database]
password = "aws-secretsmanager://prod/database/password"

Requires IAM permissions:

{
  "Effect": "Allow",
  "Action": [
    "secretsmanager:GetSecretValue",
    "secretsmanager:DescribeSecret"
  ],
  "Resource": "arn:aws:secretsmanager:us-east-1:123456789012:secret:prod/*"
}

Azure Key Vault:

Configure Azure Key Vault:

[http://secrets.azure]
vault_url = "https://myvault.vault.azure.net"
auth_method = "managed_identity"
tenant_id = "${AZURE_TENANT_ID}"

Reference secrets:

[database]
password = "azure-keyvault://database-password"

Secret Caching:

Cache secrets to reduce latency:

[secrets]
cache_enabled = true
cache_ttl = 3600  # seconds

Balances performance against secret freshness. Shorter TTL means more frequent fetches.

Secret Rotation:

Automatic rotation integration:

[secrets.rotation]
auto_reload = true
reload_interval = 300  # seconds

Periodically checks for updated secrets, reloads without restart.

Fallback Configuration:

Provide fallback if secrets backend unavailable:

[secrets]
fallback_mode = "error"  # or "env", "file"

Error mode fails immediately. Env mode falls back to environment variables. File mode reads from encrypted local file.

Secret Templates:

Compose secrets from multiple sources:

[database]
connection_string = "postgres://${secrets:vault://user}:${secrets:vault://password}@${http://database.host}:5432/${http://database.name}"

Supports mixing secrets with configuration values.

Audit Logging:

Log secret access:

[secrets.audit]
log_access = true
log_destination = "syslog"

Compliance requirement for many organizations.

Local Development:

Use environment variables during development:

export DATABASE_PASSWORD="devpassword"

[database]
password = "${DATABASE_PASSWORD}"

Automatic promotion to secrets manager in production.

Troubleshooting:

Test secrets connectivity:

nova secrets test

Validates connection to secrets backend and retrieves test secret.

title: Using NovaCLI with Docker
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides an official Docker image for containerized environments, making it easy to integrate into CI/CD pipelines and development workflows without local installation.

Pull the official image from Docker Hub:

docker pull nova/cli:3.1

The image is based on Alpine Linux and includes only NovaCLI and its dependencies, resulting in a compact 45MB compressed size.

Run commands directly:

docker run --rm nova/cli:3.1 nova --version

For interactive sessions:

docker run -it --rm nova/cli:3.1 sh

This drops you into a shell with nova available in the PATH.

Authentication in containers requires passing credentials securely. Mount your credentials as a volume:

docker run --rm -v ~/.novacli:/root/.novacli nova/cli:3.1 nova auth whoami

Alternatively, use environment variables:

docker run --rm -e NOVA_API_TOKEN=$NOVA_API_TOKEN nova/cli:3.1 nova deploy list

For CI/CD pipelines, store tokens in secure secret managers and inject them at runtime. Never embed tokens in Dockerfiles or commit them to version control.

GitHub Actions example:

- name: Deploy with NovaCLI
  run: docker run --rm -e NOVA_API_TOKEN=$ secrets.NOVA_TOKEN  nova/cli:3.1 nova deploy create --name ci-build-$ http://github.run_number 

GitLab CI example:

deploy:
  image: nova/cli:3.1
  script:
    - nova deploy create --name $CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME
  only:
    - main

For development, create a custom image extending the base:

FROM nova/cli:3.1
COPY scripts/ /scripts/
WORKDIR /scripts
CMD ["./http://deploy.sh"]

The official image supports multiple architectures: amd64, arm64, and armv7. Docker automatically pulls the appropriate variant for your platform.

Version pinning ensures reproducible builds:

docker run nova/cli:3.1.2

Use specific version tags rather than :latest in production.

Multi-stage builds optimize image size for custom tooling:

FROM nova/cli:3.1 as nova
FROM alpine:3.18
COPY --from=nova /usr/local/bin/nova /usr/local/bin/

This extracts just the nova binary into a minimal base image.

title: GraphQL API Reference
Disaster Recovery Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides comprehensive disaster recovery capabilities to ensure business continuity. This guide covers DR planning, configuration, and testing.

DR Strategy:

Define disaster recovery strategy:

[disaster_recovery]
strategy = "hot_standby"  # or "warm_standby", "cold_backup"
rpo_minutes = 15  # Recovery Point Objective
rto_minutes = 60  # Recovery Time Objective

Hot standby: Active-passive with synchronous replication
Warm standby: Standby with periodic sync
Cold backup: Restore from backups only

DR Site Configuration:

Configure secondary site:

[disaster_recovery.secondary_site]
region = "us-west-2"
replication_enabled = true
replication_mode = "asynchronous"  # or "synchronous"
lag_threshold_seconds = 30

Replication Monitoring:

Monitor replication health:

[disaster_recovery.monitoring]
health_check_interval = 10  # seconds
lag_alert_threshold = 60
failure_detection_time = 30

View replication status:

nova dr status <deployment-id>

Displays replication lag, health, and last sync time.

Failover Configuration:

Configure automatic or manual failover:

[disaster_recovery.failover]
