auto_failover = false  # Manual approval required
failover_timeout = 300  # seconds
require_approval = true
approvers = ["mailto:oncall@company.com"]

Initiate failover:

nova dr failover <deployment-id> 
  --to-region us-west-2 
  --reason "Primary region outage"

Failback Procedure:

Return to primary site:

nova dr failback <deployment-id> 
  --to-region us-east-1 
  --sync-mode full

Sync modes:
- full: Complete data synchronization
- incremental: Only changes since failover
- verify: Validate before failback

Data Replication:

Configure replication scope:

[disaster_recovery.replication]
replicate_data = true
replicate_config = true
replicate_secrets = false  # Manage separately
exclude_tables = ["temp_data", "cache"]

Backup Integration:

Integrate with backup system:

[disaster_recovery.backup]
continuous_backup = true
backup_frequency = 15  # minutes
cross_region_backup = true
backup_encryption = true

DR Testing:

Schedule DR drills:

[disaster_recovery.testing]
scheduled_drills = true
drill_frequency_days = 90
auto_verify = true
notify_team = true

Run DR test:

nova dr test <deployment-id> 
  --type failover 
  --duration 3600

Test without affecting production.

Split-Brain Prevention:

Prevent split-brain scenarios:

[disaster_recovery.split_brain]
prevention_enabled = true
quorum_size = 3
fencing_enabled = true

Network Partitioning:

Handle network partitions:

[disaster_http://recovery.network]
partition_detection = true
prefer_primary = true
auto_reconnect = true
reconnect_delay = 10  # seconds

Data Consistency:

Ensure consistency during failover:

[disaster_recovery.consistency]
mode = "strong"  # or "eventual"
validation_enabled = true
conflict_resolution = "primary_wins"

DR Runbook:

Generate DR runbook:

nova dr runbook <deployment-id> 
  --output runbook.pdf

Incudes step-by-step failover procedures.

Notifications:

Notify during DR events:

[disaster_recovery.notifications]
failover_channels = ["pagerduty", "slack", "email"]
test_channels = ["slack"]
include_metrics = true

DR Metrics:

Track DR performance:

[disaster_recovery.metrics]
rpo_actual = true
rto_actual = true
failover_count = true
replication_lag = true

Audit DR events:

nova dr audit --days 30

Cost Optimization:

Optimize DR costs:

[disaster_recovery.cost]
standby_size = "medium"  # Smaller than primary
auto_scale_on_failover = true
pause_standby_when_healthy = false

title: NovaCLI Shell Completion
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides shell completion for Bash, Zsh, Fish, and PowerShell, enabling faster command entry and discovery through tab completion.

Shell completion suggests commands, subcommands, flags, and in some cases, dynamic values like deployment IDs and region names. This reduces the need to reference documentation during interactive use.

For Bash, add completion to your shell configuration:

echo 'source <(nova completion bash)' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

Alternatively, for system-wide installation:

nova completion bash | sudo tee /etc/bash_completion.d/nova

For Zsh users:

echo 'source <(nova completion zsh)' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

If you encounter errors about completion functions not found, ensure compinit is initialized:

autoload -Uz compinit
compinit

For Fish shell:

nova completion fish | source

Make it permanent:

nova completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/http://nova.fish

For PowerShell on Windows:

nova completion powershell | Out-String | Invoke-Expression

Add to your profile for persistence:

nova completion powershell >> $PROFILE

Verify completion works by typing nova and pressing Tab. You should see available commands like auth, deploy, settings, logs.

Completion for subcommands:

nova deploy <Tab>

Displays: create, delete, info, list, rollback, start, status, stop, update

Flag completion:

nova deploy create --<Tab>

Shows all available flags: --name, --region, --size, --env, --engine, --ha-mode

Dynamic value completion requires authentication. Once authenticated, completion suggests real values:

nova deploy info <Tab>

Suggests your actual deployment IDs from the API.

nova deploy create --region <Tab>

Suggests available regions: us-east-1, us-west-1, eu-central-1, etc.

Completion scripts are generated from command metadata, ensuring they stay synchronized with available commands as NovaCLI evolves.

For custom aliases, completion still works:

alias nd='nova deploy'
nd <Tab>  # Still completes subcommands

Some shells require additional configuration for alias completion. Consult your shell's documentation for details.

Disable completion temporarily by unsourcing the completion script or commenting out the line in your shell configuration.

title: Understanding Maintenance Window Behavior
body:
Maintenance windows allow scheduled operations to run during off-peak hours. Understanding maintenance behavior helps plan around potential service interruptions in NovaCLI v3.1.

Automatic Maintenance:

Nova schedules automatic maintenance for critical updates:

- Security patches: applied within 48 hours of release
- Minor version updates: scheduled based on account preferences
- Infrastructure maintenance: announced 7 days in advance

Configuring Maintenance Windows:

Set preferred maintenance windows:

nova deploy set-maintenance-window deployment-id --day sunday --time "02:00-06:00"

Maintenance operations will be scheduled during this window when possible.

Maintenance Notifications:

Nova sends notifications before scheduled maintenance:

- 7 days before: email notification for infrastructure maintenance
- 24 hours before: dashboard notification for minor updates
- 1 hour before: API notification and deployment status change

Check upcoming maintenance:

nova deploy maintenance deployment-id

This lists scheduled maintenance with dates, expected duration, and impact description.

Deferring Maintenance:

Defer non-critical maintenance by up to 14 days:

nova deploy defer-maintenance deployment-id maintenance-id --days 7

Critical security patches cannot be deferred.

Maintenance Impact:

Different maintenance types have varying impact:

- Rolling updates: no downtime, temporary performance impact
- Minor version upgrades: 2-5 minute connection interruption
- Infrastructure maintenance: potential 10-15 minute downtime

During Maintenance:

Deployment behavior during maintenance:

- Read operations: generally available during rolling updates
- Write operations: may be temporarily blocked
- New connections: may be rejected during brief windows
- Existing connections: gracefully terminated with warnings

Post-Maintenance Validation:

After maintenance completes, verify deployment health:

nova deploy health deployment-id

Check for any warnings or issues introduced by maintenance.

Emergency Maintenance:

Critical security issues may require emergency maintenance with minimal notice. Emergency maintenance is performed as quickly as possible, potentially outside configured windows.

title: CLI API Integration Commands
body:
The NovaCLI tool provides direct API integration commands for scripting and automation. This reference covers CLI commands that interact with the REST API programmatically.

API Key Management:

Create API key:
nova api-key create --name "ci-cd-pipeline" --scopes "deployments:write" --expires 2025-12-31

List API keys:
nova api-key list --format json

Output:
[
  {
    "id": "key-abc123",
    "name": "ci-cd-pipeline",
    "created_at": "2024-09-15",
    "expires_at": "2025-12-31"
  }
]

Revoke API key:
nova api-key revoke key-abc123

Rotate API key:
nova api-key rotate key-abc123 --save-to .env

Raw API Requests:

Make raw API calls:
nova api request GET /deployments --query "status=active&limit=10"

POST with body:
nova api request POST /deployments --data '{
  "name": "my-deployment",
  "size": "medium",
  "region": "us-east-1"
}'

PATCH request:
nova api request PATCH /deployments/dep-abc123 --data '{
  "size": "large"
}'

Output formatting:
nova api request GET /deployments --format json
nova api request GET /deployments --format yaml
nova api request GET /deployments --format table

Authentication:

Set API key:
nova config set api_key "nova_sk_abc123..."

Or use environment variable:
export NOVACLI_API_KEY="nova_sk_abc123..."

Verify authentication:
nova auth verify

Output:
Authenticated as: mailto:user@company.com
API Key: nova_sk_abc...123 (expires 2025-12-31)
Scopes: deployments:read, deployments:write

Batch Operations:

Batch create from file:
nova api batch create-deployments --input deployments.json

deployments.json:
[
  {"name": "deploy1", "size": "small", "region": "us-east-1"},
  {"name": "deploy2", "size": "medium", "region": "eu-west-1"}
]

Batch update:
nova api batch update-deployments --input updates.json

Parallel requests:
nova api batch --parallel 5 --input requests.json

Output Filtering:

JQ-style filtering:
nova api request GET /deployments | jq '.data[] | select(.status=="active")'

NovaCLI built-in filtering:
nova api request GET /deployments --filter '.data[].name'

Output:
[
  "production-api",
  "staging-db",
  "dev-app"
]

Pagination:

Auto-paginate:
nova api request GET /deployments --paginate --limit 50

Fetches all pages automatically.

Manual pagination:
nova api request GET /deployments --limit 50 --offset 100

Cursor-based:
nova api request GET /deployments --cursor "eyJpZCI6MTIzfQ"

Error Handling:

Verbose errors:
nova api request GET /deployments/invalid --verbose

Output:
Error: 404 Not Found
Code: DEPLOYMENT_NOT_FOUND
Message: Deployment with ID 'invalid' not found
Request ID: req-abc123

Retry on failure:
nova api request GET /deployments --retry 3 --retry-delay 5

Ignore errors:
nova api request GET /deployments/invalid --ignore-errors

Export to File:

Save response:
nova api request GET /deployments --output deployments.json

Append to file:
nova api request GET /deployments --output deployments.json --append

Multiple formats:
nova api request GET /deployments --output deployments.json --format json
nova api request GET /deployments --output deployments.yaml --format yaml

Headers:

Custom headers:
nova api request GET /deployments --header "X-Custom: value" --header "X-Request-ID: req123"

Response headers:
nova api request GET /deployments --include-headers

Output includes response headers:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 847
Content-Type: application/json

Testing:

Dry run:
nova api request POST /deployments --data '{...}' --dry-run

Shows request without sending.

Benchmark:
nova api benchmark GET /deployments --requests 100 --concurrency 10

Output:
Total requests: 100
Successful: 100
Failed: 0
Average time: 150ms
p50: 145ms
p95: 180ms
p99: 200ms

Configuration:

API base URL:
nova config set api_base_url "https://staging-api.novacli.io"

Timeout:
nova config set api_timeout 60

Proxy:
nova config set proxy "http://proxy.company.com:8080"

Scripting:

Shell integration:
#!/bin/bash

DEPLOYMENT_ID=$(nova api request POST /deployments --data '{
  "name": "scripted-deploy",
  "size": "medium"
}' --filter '.http://data.id' --quiet)

echo "Created deployment: $DEPLOYMENT_ID"

nova api request GET /deployments/$DEPLOYMENT_ID/stats

Exit codes:
- 0: Success
- 1: API error
- 2: Authentication error
- 3: Network error

title: Hello World Deployment
body:
This tutorial creates a minimal "Hello World" deployment to verify your NovaCLI v3.1 setup works correctly. The entire process takes about 5 minutes.

Before starting, verify authentication:

nova auth whoami

You should see your username. If not, run nova auth login first.

Create a minimal deployment:

nova deploy create 
  --name hello-world 
  --region us-east-1 
  --size small 
  --env development 
  --engine postgresql-15

NovaCLI displays the deployment ID immediately. Save this ID; you'll need it for subsequent commands.

Small instances are perfect for testing. They cost minimal amounts and provision quickly. Development environments skip some production validations, further speeding provisioning.

Monitor progress:

nova deploy status <deployment-id> --watch

The --watch flag updates status every 5 seconds. Status progresses: queued  provisioning  configuring  starting  active.

Provisioning typically completes in 3-4 minutes for small instances in development mode.

Once active, retrieve connection info:

nova deploy info <deployment-id>

Copy the connection string displayed. It includes hostname, port, database name, username, and password.

Test connectivity using psql (install PostgreSQL client if needed):

psql "<connection-string>"

You're now connected to your deployment. Create a test table:

CREATE TABLE greetings (message TEXT);
INSERT INTO greetings VALUES ('Hello, World!');
SELECT * FROM greetings;

You should see your greeting returned.

Exit psql:

q

View deployment logs:

nova logs tail <deployment-id> --lines 50

Logs show the CREATE TABLE and INSERT commands you executed.

Check deployment metrics:

nova deploy stats <deployment-id>

Displays CPU usage, memory, disk, and connection count.

When finished testing, delete the deployment to avoid charges:

nova deploy delete <deployment-id> --confirm

Deletion is immediate and irreversible. All data is permanently lost.

Verify deletion:

nova deploy list

Your hello-world deployment should no longer appear.

Congratulations! You've successfully created, connected to, used, and deleted a NovaCLI deployment. You're ready to build real applications.

title: Memory Leak Diagnosis and Resolution
body:
Memory leaks in NovaCLI deployments cause gradual performance degradation and eventual crashes. Identifying and resolving memory leaks requires monitoring, profiling, and sometimes application code changes.

Symptoms of Memory Leaks:

Memory leaks manifest as:

- Steadily increasing memory usage over time
- Out-of-memory errors after extended runtime
- Performance degradation correlating with uptime
- Frequent deployment restarts to reclaim memory

Monitoring Memory Usage:

Track memory consumption over time:

nova deploy stats deployment-id --metric memory --duration 7d

This graphs memory usage for the past week. A linear upward trend indicates a potential leak.

Identifying Leak Sources:

NovaCLI v3.1 provides memory profiling tools:

nova deploy profile deployment-id --type memory --duration 300

This samples memory allocations for 5 minutes and reports the top memory consumers. Look for unexpected growth in specific components.

Common Leak Causes:

Typical memory leak sources include:

- Unclosed database connections
- Cached data without eviction policies
- Event listeners that are never removed
- Large result sets held in memory
- Circular references preventing garbage collection

Connection Pool Leaks:

Connection leaks are among the most common causes. Monitor active connections:

nova deploy connections deployment-id

If connection count steadily increases, your application isn't properly closing connections. Review connection handling code and ensure all connections are closed in finally blocks or using context managers.

Cache Configuration:

Unbounded caches consume memory indefinitely. Configure cache size limits:

nova deploy update deployment-id --cache-max-size 1024

This limits cache to 1GB. Implement LRU or TTL eviction policies to prevent unbounded growth.

Garbage Collection Tuning:

For managed runtime environments, tune garbage collection:

nova deploy update deployment-id --gc-strategy aggressive

Aggressive GC trades CPU for memory efficiency, running collection more frequently.

Temporary Mitigation:

While investigating root causes, schedule regular restarts to prevent crashes:

nova deploy schedule-restart deployment-id --frequency daily --time "03:00"

This restarts the deployment daily at 3 AM, temporarily managing the leak until fixed.

title: API Security Best Practices
body:
Secure API usage is critical for protecting deployments and data. This reference covers authentication security, API key management, and secure integration patterns for the NovaCLI API.

API Key Security:

Key storage:
- NEVER commit API keys to version control
- Store in environment variables or secret managers
- Use .env files (add to .gitignore)
- Rotate keys regularly (every 90 days recommended)

Good:
export NOVACLI_API_KEY="nova_sk_abc123..."

Bad:
const apiKey = "nova_sk_abc123..."  // Hardcoded!

Secret management services:
- AWS Secrets Manager
- HashiCorp Vault
- Azure Key Vault
- Google Secret Manager

Key Types:

Secret keys (server-side):
- Prefix: nova_sk_
- Full access based on scopes
- MUST be kept confidential
- Use in backend services only

Public keys (client-side):
- Prefix: nova_pk_
- Limited read-only access
- Safe for browser/mobile apps
- Restricted to specific domains

Scope-Based Access:

Principle of least privilege:
- Request minimum required scopes
- Create separate keys per use case
- Use read-only keys when possible

Examples:

CI/CD pipeline key:
Scopes: deployments:write, backups:read

Monitoring dashboard key:
Scopes: metrics:read, logs:read

Automated backup key:
Scopes: backups:create, backups:read

IP Restrictions:

Restrict keys to known IPs:

nova api-key create 
  --name "production-api" 
  --allowed-ips "203.0.113.0/24,198.51.100.42"

Update IP restrictions:

nova api-key update key-abc123 
  --allowed-ips "10.0.0.0/8"

HTTPS Only:

Always use HTTPS:
- Default: https://api.novacli.io
- Never use HTTP for API calls
- Validate SSL certificates
- Don't disable certificate verification

Bad:
curl --insecure http://api.novacli.io  // NEVER DO THIS

Good:
curl https://api.novacli.io

Webhook Security:

Verify webhook signatures:

import hmac
import hashlib

def verify_webhook(secret, body, signature):
    expected = http://hmac.new(
        secret.encode(),
        body.encode(),
        hashlib.sha256
    ).hexdigest()
    
    return http://hmac.compare_digest(
        f"sha256={expected}",
        signature
    )

Use timing-safe comparison to prevent timing attacks.

Store webhook secrets securely:
- Use environment variables
- Rotate webhook secrets periodically
- Use unique secrets per webhook

Rate Limit Handling:

Respect rate limits:
- Monitor X-RateLimit-Remaining header
- Implement exponential backoff
- Cache responses when appropriate
- Use webhooks instead of polling

Example:

import time
import random

def api_call_with_backoff(func, max_retries=3):
    for attempt in range(max_retries):
        try:
            return func()
        except RateLimitError as e:
            if attempt == max_retries - 1:
                raise
            
            wait = (2  attempt) + random.uniform(0, 1)
            time.sleep(wait)

Error Information:

Don't expose sensitive errors:

Bad:
return {"error": str(exception)}  // May leak internals

Good:
if isinstance(exception, AuthenticationError):
    return {"error": "Authentication failed"}
else:
    log_error(exception)  // Log details server-side
    return {"error": "An error occurred"}

Log request_id for debugging:

try:
    result = api_call()
except ApiError as e:
    logger.error(f"API error {e.request_id}: {e.message}")
    raise

Token Expiration:

Handle token expiration:

Set expiration dates:
nova api-key create --expires 2025-12-31

Monitor expiration:
nova api-key list --filter expires_soon

Automatic renewal:
- Implement automated key rotation
- Store old key during transition
- Update all services before revoking old key

OAuth Security:

OAuth best practices:
- Use state parameter for CSRF protection
- Validate redirect URIs
- Store tokens securely
- Refresh tokens before expiration
- Revoke tokens on logout

Example OAuth flow:

state = generate_random_string()
store_state_in_session(state)

auth_url = build_auth_url(
    client_id=CLIENT_ID,
    redirect_uri=REDIRECT_URI,
    scope="deployments:read",
    state=state
)

redirect(auth_url)

Audit Logging:

Enable audit logging:

nova settings set audit_logging true

Review audit logs:

nova audit logs --days 30 --filter api_key_usage

Monitor for:
- Failed authentication attempts
- Unusual API usage patterns
- Access from unexpected IPs
- Privilege escalation attempts

Network Security:

Use private networks when possible:
- VPC peering for AWS
- Private Service Connect for GCP
- Private Link for Azure

Firewall rules:
- Whitelist NovaCLI API IPs
- Block outbound to untrusted destinations
- Use egress proxies for auditing

Compliance:

Regulatory compliance:
- SOC 2
- GDPR
- HIPAA
- PCI DSS

Enable compliance mode:

nova settings set compliance_mode strict

Data residency:
- Choose appropriate region
- Enable encryption at rest
- Configure data retention policies

Incident Response:

Revoke compromised keys immediately:

nova api-key revoke key-abc123 --reason "Suspected compromise"

Rotate affected credentials:

nova api-key rotate-all --filter compromised

Review access logs:

nova audit logs --key key-abc123 --since "2024-09-01"

title: Pagination and Filtering in List Endpoints
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 API provides list endpoints for resources like deployments, logs, and backups. Understanding pagination and filtering helps you efficiently retrieve large datasets without overwhelming the API or your application.

Pagination:

All list endpoints use cursor-based pagination to ensure consistent results even when data changes:

GET /api/v3/deployments?limit=50&cursor=eyJpZCI6MTIzNH0

The response includes a next_cursor field when more results are available:

{"data": [...], "next_cursor": "eyJpZCI6MTI4NH0", "has_more": true}

To retrieve the next page, pass the next_cursor value as the cursor parameter in your next request. The default page size is 50 items, maximum is 100.

Filtering:

List endpoints support filtering by common fields:

GET /api/v3/deployments?status=running&region=us-east
GET /api/v3/logs?level=error&since=2024-09-01T00:00:00Z

Multiple filter values for the same field use comma separation:

GET /api/v3/deployments?status=running,pending

Sorting:

Specify sort order with the sort parameter:

GET /api/v3/deployments?sort=created_at:desc
GET /api/v3/backups?sort=size:asc

Available sort fields vary by endpoint. Check the API reference for supported fields.

Field Selection:

Reduce response size by requesting only needed fields:

GET /api/v3/deployments?fields=id,name,status

This returns minimal objects containing only the specified fields, improving performance for large lists.

Date Range Filters:

Many endpoints support date range filtering:

GET /api/v3/logs?since=2024-09-01T00:00:00Z&until=2024-09-07T23:59:59Z

Dates must be in ISO 8601 format with timezone information.

Combining Filters:

All filtering options can be combined:

GET /api/v3/deployments?status=running&region=us-east&sort=created_at:desc&limit=25&fields=id,name

Performance Tips:

Use field selection to minimize data transfer. Filter on indexed fields (status, region, created_at) for best performance. Cache results when appropriate to reduce API calls.

title: Audit Logging Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides comprehensive audit logging capabilities to track configuration changes, access patterns, and administrative actions. This guide covers audit log configuration, retention, and analysis.

Enabling Audit Logs:

Activate audit logging:

[audit]
enabled = true
log_level = "detailed"  # or "basic", "verbose"
log_destination = "file"  # or "syslog", "database"

Detailed level logs all administrative actions. Verbose includes read operations.

Log File Configuration:

Configure file-based audit logging:

[audit.file]
path = "/var/log/nova/audit.log"
max_size_mb = 100
max_files = 10
compress_rotated = true

Rotates logs when reaching size limit. Compressed archives reduce storage.

Syslog Integration:

Send audit logs to syslog:

[audit.syslog]
address = "http://syslog.company.com:514"
protocol = "tcp"
facility = "local0"
severity = "info"

Centralized logging simplifies compliance auditing.

Database Logging:

Store audit logs in database:

[audit.database]
connection_string = "postgres://audituser:${AUDIT_DB_PASSWORD}@auditdb:5432/audit"
table_name = "nova_audit_log"

Enables SQL queries for audit analysis.

Logged Events:

Configure which events are logged:

[http://audit.events]
login_attempts = true
configuration_changes = true
deployment_lifecycle = true
user_management = true
api_calls = true

Customize based on compliance requirements.

Event Filtering:

Exclude routine events:

[audit.filters]
exclude_users = ["monitoring-bot", "health-checker"]
exclude_events = ["health_check", "metrics_scrape"]

Reduces log volume from automated systems.

Sensitive Data Redaction:

Redact sensitive information:

[audit.redaction]
redact_passwords = true
redact_tokens = true
redact_patterns = ["api_key=.", "secret=."]

Prevents credentials from appearing in logs.

Log Enrichment:

Add contextual information:

[audit.enrichment]
include_ip_address = true
include_user_agent = true
include_session_id = true
include_request_id = true

Facilitates correlation across multiple logs.

Tamper Protection:

Protect audit logs from modification:

[audit.integrity]
sign_entries = true
signing_key = "${AUDIT_SIGNING_KEY}"
verify_on_read = true

Cryptographic signatures detect tampering.

Retention Policies:

Configure audit log retention:

[audit.retention]
days = 365
archive_after_days = 90
archive_destination = "s3://audit-archives/"

Long retention supports compliance requirements.

Query and Analysis:

Search audit logs:

nova audit search --user alice --event deployment_created --since 2024-09-01

Filter by user, event type, date range.

Generate reports:

nova audit report --type compliance --period monthly --output report.pdf

Pre-built report templates for common compliance needs.

Real-Time Alerting:

Alert on suspicious activity:

[audit.alerts]
failed_login_threshold = 5
alert_on_privilege_escalation = true
alert_on_bulk_deletion = true
alert_channels = ["email", "slack"]

Immediate notification of security-relevant events.

Compliance Frameworks:

Map to compliance requirements:

[audit.compliance]
frameworks = ["SOC2", "HIPAA", "PCI-DSS"]
auto_generate_reports = true

Automated evidence generation for audits.

title: Environment Variables in NovaCLI v3.1
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 supports environment variable configuration for containerized deployments and CI/CD pipelines where configuration files are impractical. This guide covers the environment variable naming convention, precedence rules, and best practices for production use.

Environment variables provide an alternative to TOML configuration files, particularly useful in twelve-factor applications and cloud-native deployments. Variables override file-based configuration, allowing environment-specific customization without modifying base configuration files.

NovaCLI uses the NOVA_ prefix for all environment variables to prevent namespace collisions with other tools. Variable names follow the pattern: NOVA_SECTION_KEY where SECTION matches the TOML section and KEY matches the configuration key.

Configuration file equivalent and environment variable mapping:

[server]
host = "http://api.nova.io"
port = 443

Environment variables:
NOVA_SERVER_HOST="http://api.nova.io"
NOVA_SERVER_PORT=443

For nested configuration sections, use double underscores:

[logging.fields]
service = "novacli"
environment = "production"

Environment variables:
NOVA_LOGGING_FIELDS_SERVICE="novacli"
NOVA_LOGGING_FIELDS_ENVIRONMENT="production"

Boolean values accept multiple formats for compatibility: true/false, 1/0, yes/no, on/off. String values containing spaces or special characters should be quoted.

Precedence rules determine which configuration source wins when multiple sources define the same setting:

1. Command-line flags (highest priority)
2. Environment variables
3. Configuration file values
4. Default values (lowest priority)

This precedence enables flexible deployment patterns where base configuration lives in files, environment-specific overrides use environment variables, and temporary overrides use command-line flags.

Common environment variables for production:

NOVA_SERVER_HOST: API endpoint URL
NOVA_SERVER_PORT: API port number
NOVA_AUTH_TOKEN: Authentication token
NOVA_LOGGING_LEVEL: Log verbosity (debug, info, warn, error)
NOVA_LOGGING_FORMAT: Output format (json, text)
NOVA_LOGGING_OUTPUT: Log destination path

Security considerations: Never log environment variable values in plain text, as they often contain credentials. NovaCLI automatically redacts variables matching TOKEN, SECRET, PASSWORD, KEY patterns in debug output.

To view current configuration including environment variable overrides:

nova settings show --sources

This displays each setting's value and source (file, env, flag, default), helping debug configuration precedence issues.

title: Uninstalling NovaCLI
body:
If you need to remove NovaCLI from your system, the uninstallation process varies by platform and installation method. This guide covers complete removal including configuration files and cached data.

For Linux systems installed via package manager:

Ubuntu/Debian:
sudo apt remove novacli
sudo apt purge novacli  # Also removes config files

CentOS/Fedora:
sudo dnf remove novacli

Arch Linux:
yay -R novacli

For manual binary installations on Linux:

sudo rm /usr/local/bin/nova
rm -rf ~/.novacli

The second command removes your local configuration directory including authentication tokens and settings.

For macOS installed via Homebrew:

brew uninstall novacli
rm -rf ~/.novacli

For macOS DMG installations:

Drag NovaCLI from Applications to Trash, then:

rm /usr/local/bin/nova
rm -rf ~/.novacli

For Windows MSI installations:

Uninstall through Settings > Apps > Apps & features, locate NovaCLI, click Uninstall.

Manually remove configuration:

rd /s /q %USERPROFILE%.novacli

For Windows installed via winget:

winget uninstall Nova.CLI

For Chocolatey:

choco uninstall novacli

Verify complete removal:

nova --version

Should display "command not found" or equivalent error.

Removing shell completions:

Bash:
rm /etc/bash_completion.d/nova

Zsh:
Remove the nova completion line from ~/.zshrc

Fish:
rm ~/.config/fish/completions/http://nova.fish

PowerShell:
Remove the nova completion line from your PowerShell profile.

Before uninstalling, consider backing up your configuration if you might reinstall later:

cp -r ~/.novacli ~/novacli-backup

Or export specific settings:

nova settings export --output my-settings.toml

Delete any active deployments before uninstalling to avoid orphaned resources that continue incurring charges:

nova deploy list
nova deploy delete <deployment-id> --confirm

Revoke authentication tokens through the web console under Settings > API Tokens for additional security.

Docker users can simply remove the container images:

docker rmi nova/cli:3.1

No additional cleanup is needed for containerized usage unless you mounted configuration volumes.

Reinstallation after uninstall is straightforward. Follow the installation guide for your platform. Previously created deployments remain accessible through the web console even without NovaCLI installed.

title: Batch Operations API Guide
body:
The NovaCLI API supports batch operations for efficient bulk resource management. This reference covers batch endpoints, parallel processing, and error handling for bulk operations.

Batch Create Deployments:

Create multiple deployments in single request:

POST /batch/deployments

Request body:

{
  "operations": [
    {
      "name": "deploy-1",
      "size": "small",
      "region": "us-east-1"
    },
    {
      "name": "deploy-2",
      "size": "medium",
      "region": "eu-west-1"
    },
    {
      "name": "deploy-3",
      "size": "large",
      "region": "ap-southeast-1"
    }
  ],
  "parallel": true,
  "fail_on_error": false
}

Response includes results for each operation:

{
  "status": "partial_success",
  "results": [
    {
      "index": 0,
      "status": "success",
      "deployment": {
        "id": "dep-abc123",
        "name": "deploy-1"
      }
    },
    {
      "index": 1,
      "status": "success",
      "deployment": {
        "id": "dep-xyz789",
        "name": "deploy-2"
      }
    },
    {
      "index": 2,
      "status": "error",
      "error": {
        "code": "CAPACITY_INSUFFICIENT",
        "message": "Insufficient capacity in ap-southeast-1"
      }
    }
  ],
  "summary": {
    "total": 3,
    "succeeded": 2,
    "failed": 1
  }
}

Batch Update:

Update multiple resources:

PATCH /batch/deployments

Request body:

{
  "operations": [
    {
      "id": "dep-abc123",
      "size": "large"
    },
    {
      "id": "dep-xyz789",
      "config": {
        "maxConnections": 200
      }
    }
  ]
}

Batch Delete:

Delete multiple deployments:

DELETE /batch/deployments

Request body:

{
  "ids": ["dep-abc123", "dep-xyz789", "dep-def456"],
  "force": false,
  "create_backups": true
}

Error Handling:

fail_on_error modes:

fail_on_error: true
- Stop on first error
- Rollback successful operations
- Return partial results

fail_on_error: false (default)
- Continue despite errors
- Complete all operations
- Return all results with error details

Transaction Support:

Atomic batch operations:

POST /batch/deployments
{
  "operations": [...],
  "transaction": true
}

All-or-nothing: Either all succeed or all rollback.

Parallel Processing:

Control parallelism:

{
  "operations": [...],
  "parallel": true,
  "max_concurrency": 5
}

Parallel: Faster but unordered
Sequential: Slower but ordered

Rate Limits:

Batch operations count as single request:
- Batch of 10 = 1 request against rate limit
- Maximum batch size: 100 operations
- Recommended batch size: 10-50

Batch Status:

Check batch operation status:

GET /batch/operations/{batch_id}

Response:

{
  "id": "batch-abc123",
  "status": "in_progress",
  "progress": {
    "total": 100,
    "completed": 45,
    "failed": 2,
    "pending": 53
  },
  "created_at": "2024-09-15T10:30:00Z",
  "estimated_completion": "2024-09-15T10:45:00Z"
}

Async Batch Operations:

Large batches run asynchronously:

POST /batch/deployments
{
  "operations": [...],  // 100 operations
  "async": true
}

Response:

{
  "batch_id": "batch-abc123",
  "status": "accepted",
  "status_url": "/batch/operations/batch-abc123"
}

Poll for completion or use webhooks.

Batch Validation:

Validate before execution:

POST /batch/deployments/validate
{
  "operations": [...]
}

Returns validation errors without executing.

Partial Results:

Retrieve partial results:

GET /batch/operations/{batch_id}/results

Returns completed operations even if batch still running.

Batch Ordering:

Preserve operation order:

{
  "operations": [...],
  "ordered": true,
  "parallel": false
}

Operations execute in array order.

Dependency Management:

Define operation dependencies:

{
  "operations": [
    {
      "id": "op-1",
      "name": "parent-deploy"
    },
    {
      "id": "op-2",
      "depends_on": ["op-1"],
      "name": "child-deploy"
    }
  ]
}

Batch Limits:

Operation limits:
- Maximum operations per batch: 100
- Maximum concurrent batches: 5
- Async batch timeout: 1 hour
- Batch retention: 7 days

Best Practices:

Batch size recommendations:
- 10-50 operations: Optimal balance
- 1-10 operations: Use regular API
- 50-100 operations: Consider async
- 100+ operations: Split into multiple batches

Error recovery:
- Use fail_on_error: false
- Retry failed operations
- Log batch_id for troubleshooting
- Monitor batch status

Performance:
- Batch reduces API calls
- Faster than individual requests
- Lower rate limit impact
- Use for bulk operations

title: Keyboard Shortcuts and Aliases
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 commands can be lengthy. This guide demonstrates keyboard shortcuts, command aliases, and productivity tips to speed up your workflow.

Built-in command aliases:

NovaCLI provides short aliases for frequently used commands:

nova d = nova deploy
nova a = nova auth
nova s = nova settings
nova l = nova logs

Combine with subcommands:

nova d create  # Same as nova deploy create
nova d ls      # Same as nova deploy list
nova l tail    # Same as nova logs tail

Create custom shell aliases for your most common operations:

Bash/Zsh:

alias ndeploy='nova deploy create --size small --env development'
alias nlist='nova deploy list --format table'
alias ninfo='nova deploy info'

Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc for persistence.

Fish:

abbr ndeploy 'nova deploy create --size small --env development'
abbr nlist 'nova deploy list --format table'

PowerShell:

Set-Alias ndeploy 'nova deploy create'
function nlist { nova deploy list --format table }

Add to your PowerShell profile.

Shell functions provide more flexibility than aliases:

Create a deployment with sensible defaults:

function quick-deploy() {
  local name=$1
  nova deploy create 
    --name $name 
    --region us-east-1 
    --size small 
    --env development 
    --engine postgresql-15
}

Usage:

quick-deploy my-app

Delete deployment by name:

function quick-delete() {
  nova deploy delete $(nova deploy list --format json | jq -r ".[] | select(.name=="$1") | .id") --confirm
}

Get deployment ID by name:

function did() {
  nova deploy list --format json | jq -r ".[] | select(.name=="$1") | .id"
}

Usage:

nova deploy info $(did my-app)

Environment variables set default values:

export NOVA_DEFAULT_REGION=us-west-1
export NOVA_DEFAULT_SIZE=medium

Now deployments use these defaults when flags are omitted.

Shell history search (Ctrl+R) finds previous commands quickly. Tag commands with comments for easier retrieval:

nova deploy create --name prod-app  # production deployment

Searching for "production" finds this command.

Tab completion (covered in shell completion guide) significantly reduces typing. Always press Tab after partial commands.

For frequently accessed deployments, store IDs in variables:

PROD_DEPLOY=$(did production-app)

nova logs tail $PROD_DEPLOY
nova deploy stats $PROD_DEPLOY

title: Resolving Replication Lag
body:
Replication lag causes read replicas to serve stale data, impacting application consistency. NovaCLI v3.1 provides tools to monitor, diagnose, and reduce replication delays.

Measuring Replication Lag:

Check current lag for all replicas:

nova deploy replication-status deployment-id

This displays lag in seconds and bytes for each replica. Lag above 5 seconds may impact application behavior.

Causes of Replication Lag:

Common causes include:

- High write volume exceeding replica capacity
- Network latency between primary and replica
- Resource constraints on replica (CPU, disk I/O)
- Long-running queries blocking replication on replica

Write Volume:

Excessive write activity can overwhelm replication. Monitor write rate:

nova deploy stats deployment-id --metric writes-per-second

Reduce write volume by batching writes, using bulk operations, or upgrading replica size:

nova replica resize replica-id --size large

Network Latency:

Cross-region replicas experience higher lag due to network distance. Measure network latency:

ping -c 10 replica-hostname

For latency-sensitive applications, use same-region replicas.

Replica Resource Constraints:

Check replica resource usage:

nova deploy stats replica-id --detailed

If CPU or disk I/O is saturated, upgrade replica resources:

nova replica resize replica-id --size xlarge

Blocking Queries:

Long-running queries on replicas can block replication. Identify blocking queries:

nova deploy queries replica-id --blocking

Terminate problematic queries:

nova deploy kill-query replica-id query-id

Replication Configuration:

Tune replication parameters for better performance:

nova replica update replica-id --parallel-workers 8

More parallel workers improve replication throughput but consume more resources.

Monitoring and Alerts:

Set up alerts for excessive lag:

nova alerts create --replica replica-id --metric lag-seconds --threshold 10

This alerts when lag exceeds 10 seconds.

Failover Considerations:

High replication lag delays failover. Before planned failover, wait for lag to drop:

nova deploy wait-for-sync deployment-id --max-lag 1

title: API Testing and Mock Server
body:
NovaCLI provides testing tools including a mock API server for development and integration testing. This reference covers test environments, mock data, and testing best practices.

Mock Server:

Local mock server for development:

nova mock-server start --port 8080

Access at:
http://localhost:8080/v1

Mock server features:
- Returns realistic responses
- No authentication required
- Predictable data
- No rate limits
- Instant responses

Configuration:

Customize mock behavior:

nova mock-server start 
  --port 8080 
  --latency 100 
  --error-rate 0.05

Options:
- latency: Simulate network delay (ms)
- error-rate: Random error percentage (0.0-1.0)
- seed: Deterministic random data

Mock Data:

Predictable mock deployments:

GET http://localhost:8080/v1/deployments

Returns:
- dep-mock-001 through dep-mock-100
- Various regions and sizes
- Different statuses
- Consistent across restarts with same seed

Custom Mock Data:

Load custom fixtures:

nova mock-server start --fixtures ./fixtures.json

fixtures.json:

{
  "deployments": [
    {
      "id": "dep-test-1",
      "name": "test-deployment",
      "status": "active"
    }
  ]
}

Testing Environments:

Environment URLs:

Production: https://api.novacli.io
Staging: https://staging-api.novacli.io
Sandbox: https://sandbox-api.novacli.io
Local Mock: http://localhost:8080

Sandbox environment:
- Free tier unlimited
- Test data isolated
- Safe for experiments
- Reset daily at 00:00 UTC

Test API Keys:

Generate test keys:

nova api-key create 
  --name "test-key" 
  --environment sandbox

Test keys:
- Prefix: nova_test_
- Only work in sandbox
- Cannot access production
- No rate limits

Integration Testing:

Python example:

import unittest
from novacli import Client

class TestDeployments(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self.client = Client(
            api_key="nova_test_abc123",
            base_url="http://localhost:8080"
        )
    
    def test_create_deployment(self):
        deployment = self.client.deployments.create(
            name="test-deploy",
            size="small"
        )
        self.assertEqual(http://deployment.name, "test-deploy")

JavaScript example:

const { NovaCLI } = require('@novacli/sdk');
const assert = require('assert');

describe('Deployments', () => {
  const client = new NovaCLI({
    apiKey: 'nova_test_abc123',
    baseURL: 'http://localhost:8080'
  });

  it('should create deployment', async () => {
    const deployment = await client.deployments.create({
      name: 'test-deploy',
      size: 'small'
    });
    assert.equal(http://deployment.name, 'test-deploy');
  });
});

Mock Error Scenarios:

Simulate specific errors:

GET http://localhost:8080/v1/deployments/error-404

Returns 404 Not Found

GET http://localhost:8080/v1/deployments/error-500

Returns 500 Internal Server Error

Special IDs:
- error-400: Bad Request
- error-401: Unauthorized
- error-403: Forbidden
- error-404: Not Found
- error-429: Rate Limited
- error-500: Server Error
- slow-response: 5 second delay

Webhook Testing:

Test webhook delivery:

nova mock-server start --webhook-target http://localhost:3000/webhook

Mock server sends test webhooks:
- deployment.created events
- Every 30 seconds
- Valid HMAC signatures

Snapshot Testing:

Record/replay API interactions:

nova test record --output snapshots/

Records actual API responses.

nova mock-server start --snapshots snapshots/

Replays recorded responses.

Contract Testing:

Validate API contracts:

nova test contract --spec openapi.json

Verifies:
- Response schemas match spec
- Required fields present
- Data types correct
- Status codes valid

Load Testing:

Test against mock server:

nova test load 
  --url http://localhost:8080 
  --requests 1000 
  --concurrency 50

Safe load testing without affecting production.

Docker Support:

Run mock server in Docker:

docker run -p 8080:8080 novacli/mock-server

Docker Compose:

services:
  mock-api:
    image: novacli/mock-server
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    environment:
      - LATENCY=50
      - ERROR_RATE=0.01

CLI Testing:

Test CLI commands:

nova test cli --command "deploy list" --mock

Uses mock server automatically.

Coverage Tracking:

Track API endpoint coverage:

nova test coverage --report

Shows which endpoints tested.

title: Configuring SCRAM-SHA-256 for Read-Only Users
Compliance and Governance Configuration
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides compliance and governance features to meet regulatory requirements and organizational policies. This guide covers configuring compliance controls, policy enforcement, and audit trails.

Compliance Mode:

Enable compliance mode:

[compliance]
mode = "strict"  # or "standard", "custom"
frameworks = ["SOC2", "HIPAA", "GDPR", "PCI-DSS"]

Strict mode enforces all controls automatically.

Data Classification:

Classify deployment data:

[http://compliance.data_classification]
default_level = "internal"
supported_levels = ["public", "internal", "confidential", "restricted"]

Set classification:

nova deploy update <deployment-id> 
  --data-classification confidential

Encryption Requirements:

Enforce encryption based on classification:

[compliance.encryption]
required_for = ["confidential", "restricted"]
at_rest = true
in_transit = true
key_rotation_days = 90

Access Controls:

Enforce access control policies:

[compliance.access_control]
require_mfa = true
max_session_duration = 480  # minutes
require_justification = ["deploy:delete", "data:export"]

Provide justification:

nova deploy delete <deployment-id> 
  --justification "Decommissioning obsolete service"

Data Retention:

Enforce retention policies:

[compliance.retention]
audit_logs_days = 2555  # 7 years
backup_retention_days = 90
data_deletion_after_days = 365

Automatic deletion:

[compliance.deletion]
auto_delete_expired = true
require_approval = true
approvers = ["mailto:compliance-team@company.com"]

Data Residency:

Enforce geographic restrictions:

[http://compliance.data_residency]
enabled = true
allowed_regions = ["eu-west-1", "eu-central-1"]
prohibit_cross_border = true

Change Management:

Require approval for changes:

[compliance.change_management]
require_change_ticket = true
ticket_system = "jira"
ticket_url_pattern = "https://jira.company.com/browse/{ticket_id}"

Create deployment with ticket:

nova deploy create 
  --name my-deployment 
  --change-ticket CHANGE-12345

Segregation of Duties:

Enforce role separation:

[compliance.segregation]
enabled = true
separate_roles = [["creator", "approver"], ["developer", "auditor"]]

Same user cannot have conflicting roles.

Privacy Controls:

Protect personal data:

[compliance.privacy]
pii_detection = true
pii_masking = true
pii_fields = ["email", "phone", "ssn"]

Masked in logs and exports.

Right to be Forgotten:

Support data subject requests:

nova compliance delete-user-data 
  --user-id 12345 
  --reason "GDPR data subject request"

Compliance Reports:

Generate compliance reports:

nova compliance report 
  --framework SOC2 
  --period 2024-Q3 
  --output report.pdf

Automatic reporting:

[compliance.reporting]
auto_generate = true
frequency = "monthly"
recipients = ["mailto:compliance@company.com"]

Policy as Code:

Define policies programmatically:

# policy.rego
package novacli.compliance

allow_deployment {
  input.size != "xlarge"
  input.region in ["us-east-1", "us-west-2"]
  input.encryption_enabled == true
}

Load policy:

nova policy load compliance-policy.rego

Violation Detection:

Detect policy violations:

[compliance.monitoring]
continuous_monitoring = true
violation_alerting = true
auto_remediation = false

Review violations:

nova compliance violations --days 30

Compliance Dashboard:

View compliance status:

nova compliance dashboard

Displays:
- Compliance score
- Active violations
- Remediation progress
- Audit findings

Third-Party Attestations:

Integrate with compliance platforms:

[compliance.integrations]
vanta_enabled = true
vanta_api_key = "${VANTA_API_KEY}"

drata_enabled = true
drata_webhook = "${DRATA_WEBHOOK}"

Certification Evidence:

Collect evidence automatically:

[compliance.evidence]
auto_collect = true
evidence_types = ["logs", "configs", "access_reports"]
storage_location = "s3://compliance-evidence/"

Export evidence:

nova compliance export-evidence 
  --framework SOC2 
  --period 2024-Q3

title: Understanding NovaCLI Pricing
body:
NovaCLI deployments incur charges based on instance size, storage, data transfer, and optional add-ons. Understanding the pricing model helps you optimize costs while meeting performance requirements.

Instance Pricing:

Instances are billed hourly based on size. Pricing is pro-rated to the second, so you only pay for actual usage.

Small: $0.05/hour (~$36/month)
Medium: $0.15/hour (~$108/month)
Large: $0.40/hour (~$288/month)
Extra-Large: $1.00/hour (~$720/month)

Development instances cost 30% less but have lower uptime SLAs and may be preempted during peak demand.

Storage Pricing:

Storage is billed per GB-month:

Standard SSD: $0.10/GB/month
High-performance NVMe: $0.25/GB/month

Storage scales automatically as your data grows. You're billed for allocated storage, not provisioned capacity.

Data Transfer:

Inbound data transfer: Free
Outbound to internet: $0.09/GB after 100GB free tier
Outbound to same region: Free
Outbound to different region: $0.02/GB

Backup Storage:

Automated backups (last 7 days): Included
Extended backup retention: $0.05/GB/month
Cross-region backup copies: $0.08/GB/month

Optional Add-ons:

High Availability (multi-zone): +50% of instance cost
Read replicas: Full instance cost per replica
Point-in-time recovery: $0.10/GB/month

View estimated costs before creating deployments:

nova deploy estimate 
  --size medium 
  --storage 100 
  --ha-mode multi-zone

Displays breakdown: instance, storage, backup, HA costs.

Monitor current spending:

nova billing current-month

Shows charges by deployment and resource type.

Set spending alerts:

nova billing set-alert --threshold 500 --email mailto:your@email.com

Receive notifications when monthly spending approaches limits.

Cost optimization tips:

1. Right-size instances. Start small and scale up based on metrics.
2. Use development mode for non-production workloads.
3. Delete unused deployments promptly.
4. Stop deployments during off-hours if downtime is acceptable.
5. Keep backups in the same region unless compliance requires otherwise.
6. Monitor data transfer patterns and optimize query efficiency.

Free tier:

New accounts receive $100 credit valid for 30 days. Sufficient for several weeks of small instance usage.

Detailed billing:

nova billing download-invoice --month 2024-09 --format pdf

Downloads itemized invoice showing per-deployment costs, hourly breakdowns, and data transfer details.

title: Resolving Backup and Restore Failures
body:
Backup and restore operations are critical for data protection. When these operations fail in NovaCLI v3.1, prompt diagnosis and resolution prevents data loss and minimizes downtime.

Backup Failure: Insufficient Storage:

The most common backup failure is insufficient backup storage quota. Error: "Backup failed: Storage quota exceeded (used: 500GB/500GB)." Delete old backups to free space:

nova backup list --deployment deployment-id
nova backup delete backup-id

Alternatively, increase your backup storage quota in the Nova dashboard under Settings > Billing > Storage.

Backup Failure: Lock Timeout:

Backups require exclusive locks on certain database objects. If your deployment has long-running queries or transactions, backup may fail with "Lock acquisition timeout." Terminate blocking queries:

nova deploy queries deployment-id --filter "state=active AND duration > 3600"

Kill long-running queries before retrying backup:

nova deploy kill-query deployment-id query-id

Restore Failure: Version Mismatch:

Restoring backups across incompatible versions fails. Error: "Cannot restore v2.0 backup to v3.1 deployment." You must restore to a deployment running the same major version as the backup source, then upgrade.

Create a v2.0 deployment, restore the backup, then upgrade:

nova deploy create --version 2.0 --name temp-restore
nova backup restore backup-id --target temp-restore
nova deploy upgrade temp-restore --version 3.1

Restore Failure: Insufficient Resources:

Restoring large backups requires adequate deployment resources. If restore fails with "Out of memory" or "Disk space exhausted," resize the target deployment before restoring:

nova deploy resize deployment-id --size xlarge
nova backup restore backup-id --target deployment-id

Corrupted Backup:

Rarely, backups become corrupted due to storage issues. Error: "Backup integrity check failed." Try an earlier backup:

nova backup list --deployment deployment-id --sort created_at:desc

If all recent backups are corrupted, contact support immediately for recovery options.

Partial Restore:

For large databases, consider partial restore to reduce time and resource requirements:

nova backup restore backup-id --target deployment-id --databases db1,db2

This restores only specified databases rather than the entire backup.

title: API Changelog and Breaking Changes
body:
The NovaCLI API evolves with careful version management. This reference documents API changes, deprecation notices, and migration paths between versions.

API v1.0 (2023-06-01):

Initial GA release:

Features:
- REST API for deployments
- Basic authentication
- JSON responses
- Offset pagination
- Rate limiting

Endpoints:
- GET/POST /deployments
- GET/PUT/DELETE /deployments/{id}
- GET /backups
- POST /backups

API v1.1 (2023-09-01):

Minor update:

New features:
- Cursor-based pagination
- Webhook support
- Batch operations (beta)
- Field filtering

Backward compatible: Yes

Deprecations:
- Offset pagination (still supported)
- camelCase fields (snake_case preferred)

API v1.2 (2023-12-01):

Enhancements:

New features:
- OAuth 2.0 support
- GraphQL API (beta)
- Real-time metrics
- Enhanced error codes

Backward compatible: Yes

Deprecations:
- Basic authentication (removed 2024-12-01)
- Legacy date format (Unix timestamps)

API v1.3 (2024-03-01):

Stability improvements:

New features:
- Batch operations GA
- Improved rate limiting
- Regional endpoints
- Request tracing

Backward compatible: Yes

Bug fixes:
- Fixed pagination edge cases
- Corrected timezone handling
- Improved error messages

API v1.4 (2024-06-01):

GraphQL promotion:

New features:
- GraphQL API GA
- Subscriptions support
- Advanced filtering
- Aggregations

Backward compatible: Yes

Performance improvements:
- 30% faster response times
- Reduced payload sizes
- Better caching

API v1.5 (2024-09-01):

Current stable:

New features:
- API versioning in headers
- Deprecation warnings
- Enhanced documentation
- SDK improvements

Backward compatible: Yes

Breaking Changes Log:

v1.0 to v1.1:
- None (fully backward compatible)

v1.1 to v1.2:
- None (deprecations announced)

v1.2 to v1.3:
- None (fully backward compatible)

v1.3 to v1.4:
- None (GraphQL separate endpoint)

v1.4 to v1.5:
- None (only additions)

Deprecation Timeline:

Basic Authentication:
- Announced: 2023-12-01 (v1.2)
- Warning phase: 2024-06-01
- Sunset date: 2024-12-01
- Removed: 2025-01-01
- Replacement: OAuth 2.0 or API keys

Offset Pagination:
- Announced: 2023-09-01 (v1.1)
- Warning phase: 2024-03-01
- Sunset date: 2025-06-01
- Removed: 2025-09-01
- Replacement: Cursor pagination

camelCase Fields:
- Announced: 2023-09-01 (v1.1)
- Warning phase: 2024-01-01
- Sunset date: 2025-03-01
- Removed: Never (dual support)
- Replacement: snake_case

Upcoming Changes:

Planned for v1.6 (2024-12-01):
- Enhanced batch operations
- Improved webhook delivery
- New metrics endpoints
- Performance optimizations

Planned for v2.0 (2025-06-01):
- Remove deprecated features
- Simplified authentication
- Restructured endpoints
- New field naming conventions

Breaking changes:
- Remove basic authentication
- Remove offset pagination
- camelCase fields unsupported
- New error format

Migration Guides:

v1.2 to v1.3:

No breaking changes, recommended updates:

1. Update error handling for new codes
2. Adopt cursor pagination
3. Use snake_case fields
4. Enable request tracing

Code changes:

// Before
const deployments = await client.get('/deployments?offset=100');

// After
const deployments = await client.get('/deployments?cursor=abc123');

v1.4 to v1.5:

No breaking changes, optional improvements:

1. Use version headers
2. Monitor deprecation warnings
3. Update SDK to latest
4. Review documentation updates

Preparing for v2.0:

Migration checklist:

1. Replace basic auth with API keys
2. Convert to cursor pagination
3. Update field names to snake_case
4. Test with v2.0 compatibility mode
5. Update error handling
6. Review v2.0 migration guide

Testing compatibility:

curl -H "Accept: application/vnd.novacli.v2+json" 
  https://api.novacli.io/v1/deployments

Returns v2.0 format preview.

Changelog Access:

View full changelog:

GET /changelog

Returns:

{
  "versions": [
    {
      "version": "1.5.0",
      "released": "2024-09-01",
      "changes": [...],
      "breaking": false
    }
  ]
}

Subscribe to updates:

POST /changelog/subscribe
{
  "email": "mailto:dev@company.com",
  "notify_breaking_changes": true
}

title: Getting Started FAQ
body:
This FAQ addresses common questions from new NovaCLI v3.1 users. Answers provide quick guidance for typical scenarios.

Q: Do I need an existing Nova account to use NovaCLI?

A: Yes. Create a free account at http://nova.io before installing NovaCLI. The CLI authenticates with your account credentials.

Q: Can I manage multiple Nova organizations with one NovaCLI installation?

A: Yes. Use profiles (nova profiles create) to switch between organizations. Each profile stores separate authentication.

Q: Are deployment names unique globally or per account?

A: Deployment names must be unique within your organization, not globally. Multiple organizations can use the same deployment name.

Q: How long does deployment creation take?

A: Typically 3-5 minutes for small to medium instances. Large instances may take 7-10 minutes. Development mode provisions slightly faster.

Q: Can I change instance size after creation?

A: Yes. Use nova deploy resize <deployment-id> --size <new-size>. Resizing causes brief downtime (30-90 seconds) in v3.1.

Q: What happens if my authentication token expires?

A: Commands will fail with "authentication required" errors. Run nova auth login to refresh your token. Tokens expire after 30 days of inactivity.

Q: Can I use NovaCLI without internet access?

A: No. NovaCLI communicates with Nova API servers for all operations. Internet connectivity is required.

Q: Does NovaCLI work behind a corporate proxy?

A: Yes. Configure proxy settings: nova settings set proxy.http <url> and nova settings set proxy.https <url>. Or use environment variables: HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY.

Q: How do I update NovaCLI to the latest version?

A: Method depends on installation. Package managers: apt update && apt upgrade novacli. Homebrew: brew upgrade novacli. Manual: download new binary and replace existing.

Q: Are my credentials stored securely?

A: Yes. Credentials are encrypted at rest using platform-specific secure storage: Keychain (macOS), Credential Manager (Windows), encrypted file (Linux).

Q: Can I script NovaCLI commands?

A: Yes. NovaCLI is designed for automation. Use --format json for machine-readable output and environment variables for authentication.

Q: What's the difference between stopping and deleting a deployment?

A: Stopping pauses the deployment, stopping compute charges but retaining data. Deleting permanently removes everything and cannot be undone.

Q: How do I get help for a specific command?

A: Append --help to any command: nova deploy create --help. Displays all flags, examples, and detailed descriptions.

Q: Does NovaCLI support Windows PowerShell?

A: Yes. Full support for PowerShell including tab completion and standard output formatting.

title: Resolving Billing and Quota Errors
body:
Billing issues and quota limits interrupt service and prevent resource provisioning. Understanding billing errors and quota management restores full functionality in NovaCLI v3.1.

Common Billing Errors:

- "Payment method declined"
- "Account suspended: payment overdue"
- "Insufficient credits for operation"
- "Billing information incomplete"

Payment Failures:

When payment fails, update payment method:

nova account update-payment --card-number XXXX

Or update via dashboard at https://dashboard.nova.io/billing

Account Suspension:

Overdue payments result in account suspension:

- 7 days overdue: warning emails sent
- 14 days overdue: new deployments blocked
- 30 days overdue: existing deployments suspended (read-only)
- 60 days overdue: deployments deleted

Reactivate suspended account:

1. Update payment method
2. Pay outstanding balance
3. Contact support to restore service

Quota Limits:

Each plan has resource quotas:

- Number of deployments
- Total storage
- Number of backups
- API request rate

Check current quota usage:

nova account quota

This shows limits and current usage for all resources.

Exceeding Quotas:

"Quota exceeded" errors prevent new resource creation. Options:

- Delete unused resources to free quota
- Upgrade plan for higher limits
- Request temporary quota increase from support

Upgrading Plans:

Upgrade to higher tier for increased quotas:

nova account upgrade --plan pro

Upgrades take effect immediately. No service interruption.

Usage Monitoring:

Monitor usage to avoid unexpected charges:

nova account usage --month 2024-09

This shows detailed usage breakdown by resource type.

Billing Alerts:

Set alerts for usage thresholds:

nova account set-alert --type usage --threshold 80

Alerts at 80% of quota or budget limits enable proactive management.

Invoice Issues:

Access invoices for accounting:

nova account invoices --year 2024

Download specific invoices:

nova account invoice-download invoice-id > invoice.pdf

Cost Optimization:

Reduce costs by:

- Deleting unused deployments
- Reducing backup retention periods
- Downsizing over-provisioned deployments
- Using reserved instances for predictable workloads

Review cost optimization recommendations:

nova account cost-recommendations

title: API Performance Optimization Guide
body:
Optimize API usage for maximum performance and efficiency. This reference covers caching strategies, request optimization, and performance best practices for the NovaCLI API.

Response Caching:

Cache-Control headers:

GET /deployments/dep-abc123

Response includes:

Cache-Control: max-age=60, private
ETag: "abc123def456"
Last-Modified: Wed, 15 Sep 2024 10:30:00 GMT

Conditional Requests:

Use ETags for conditional requests:

GET /deployments/dep-abc123
If-None-Match: "abc123def456"

Response:
- 304 Not Modified: Use cached version
- 200 OK: Resource changed, new data

Last-Modified:

GET /deployments/dep-abc123
If-Modified-Since: Wed, 15 Sep 2024 10:30:00 GMT

Response:
- 304 Not Modified: Not changed
- 200 OK: Resource updated

Client-Side Caching:

Cache implementation:

const cache = new Map();
const CACHE_TTL = 60000; // 1 minute

async function getCached(url) {
  const cached = cache.get(url);
  if (cached && http://Date.now() - cached.timestamp < CACHE_TTL) {
    return http://cached.data;
  }
  
  const data = await fetch(url);
  cache.set(url, {
    data,
    timestamp: http://Date.now()
  });
  return data;
}

Request Optimization:

Field selection:

GET /deployments?fields=id,name,status

Returns only requested fields:
- Smaller payloads
- Faster responses
- Lower bandwidth
- Better performance

GraphQL for precise queries:

query {
  deployment(id: "dep-abc123") {
    id
    name
    status
  }
}

Fetch exactly what you need.

Batch Requests:

Batch multiple operations:

POST /batch/operations
{
  "operations": [
    {"method": "GET", "path": "/deployments/dep-1"},
    {"method": "GET", "path": "/deployments/dep-2"},
    {"method": "GET", "path": "/deployments/dep-3"}
  ]
}

Benefits:
- Single network round trip
- Lower latency
- Fewer rate limit hits
- Reduced overhead

Connection Reuse:

HTTP Keep-Alive:

Connection: keep-alive

Reuse TCP connections:
- Eliminate handshake overhead
- Reduce latency
- Better throughput

HTTP/2 support:
- Multiplexed streams
- Header compression
- Server push
- Lower latency

Compression:

Request compression:

Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br

Response compressed:

Content-Encoding: gzip

Reduction:
- 70-90% smaller payloads
- Faster transfers
- Lower bandwidth costs

Pagination Strategy:

Optimal page size:

// Too small - many requests
GET /deployments?limit=10  // Bad

// Optimal balance
GET /deployments?limit=50  // Good

// Too large - slow response
GET /deployments?limit=500  // Bad

Recommended:
- 50-100 items per page
- Use cursor pagination
- Fetch on demand
- Implement virtual scrolling

Parallel Requests:

Fetch in parallel:

const [deployments, backups, metrics] = await Promise.all([
  client.deployments.list(),
  client.backups.list('dep-abc123'),
  client.metrics.get('dep-abc123')
]);

Benefits:
- Reduced total time
- Better resource utilization
- Improved user experience

Caution: Respect rate limits

Request Debouncing:

Debounce rapid requests:

let debounceTimer;

function debouncedSearch(query) {
  clearTimeout(debounceTimer);
  debounceTimer = setTimeout(() => {
    http://api.search(query);
  }, 300);
}

Prevents excessive API calls during typing.

Webhooks vs Polling:

Polling (inefficient):

setInterval(() => {
  client.deployments.get('dep-abc123');
}, 5000);

Problems:
- Wastes API calls
- Higher latency
- Rate limit issues

Webhooks (efficient):

client.webhooks.create({
  url: 'https://myapp.com/webhook',
  events: ['deployment.updated']
});

Benefits:
- Real-time updates
- No polling overhead
- Lower rate limit usage

CDN and Edge Caching:

Cache at edge:

Use regional endpoints:
- http://us-east-1.api.novacli.io
- http://eu-west-1.api.novacli.io
- http://ap-southeast-1.api.novacli.io

Benefits:
- Lower latency
- Geographic proximity
- Better performance

Connection Pooling:

Maintain connection pool:

const client = new NovaCLI({
  apiKey: 'nova_sk_abc123',
  pool: {
    maxConnections: 10,
    maxIdleTime: 30000
  }
});

Reuses connections efficiently.

Monitoring Performance:

Track API performance:

const start = http://Date.now();
const result = await http://api.call();
const duration = http://Date.now() - start;

http://logger.info(API call took ${duration}ms);

Metrics to track:
- Response time
- Error rate
- Cache hit ratio
- Rate limit usage

Performance Headers:

Response timing headers:

X-Response-Time: 45ms
X-Cache-Status: HIT
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 847

Use for optimization decisions.

title: Webhooks and Event Notifications
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 supports webhooks for real-time notifications about deployment events, allowing you to build reactive integrations and automation workflows without polling.

Supported Events:

The webhook system can notify you about:

- deployment.created: New deployment provisioned
- deployment.updated: Deployment configuration changed
- deployment.deleted: Deployment removed
- deployment.status_changed: Status transition (pending  running, running  stopped, etc.)
- backup.completed: Automated or manual backup finished
- backup.failed: Backup operation encountered an error
- alert.triggered: Monitoring alert activated
- maintenance.scheduled: Upcoming maintenance window announced

Webhook Configuration:

Create a webhook endpoint through the API:

POST /api/v3/webhooks
{"url": "https://your-app.com/webhooks/nova", "events": ["deployment.status_changed", "alert.triggered"], "secret": "your-signing-secret"}

The secret is used to verify webhook authenticity. Store it securely and use it to validate incoming requests.

Webhook Payload:

All webhook events use a consistent payload structure:

{"event": "deployment.status_changed", "timestamp": "2024-09-18T14:23:45Z", "data": {"deployment_id": "dep-abc123", "old_status": "pending", "new_status": "running"}, "webhook_id": "wh-xyz789"}

Signature Verification:

Each webhook request includes an X-Nova-Signature header containing an HMAC SHA-256 signature of the request body:

expected_signature = HMAC-SHA256(request_body, webhook_secret)
if request.headers['X-Nova-Signature'] != expected_signature:
    return 401

Always verify signatures to prevent spoofed requests.

Retry Behavior:

If your endpoint returns a non-2xx status or times out after 10 seconds, Nova retries with exponential backoff:

- Retry 1: after 30 seconds
- Retry 2: after 5 minutes
- Retry 3: after 30 minutes
- Retry 4: after 2 hours

After 4 failed attempts, the webhook is marked as failing. Consecutive failures over 7 days will disable the webhook.

Testing Webhooks:

Test your webhook endpoint:

nova webhook test wh-xyz789

This sends a test event to verify your endpoint is reachable and processing events correctly.

title: Advanced Security Hardening
body:
NovaCLI v3.1 provides security hardening options beyond basic configuration. This guide covers advanced security features including encryption, access controls, and threat mitigation.

Encryption at Rest:

Enable transparent data encryption:

[security.encryption]
at_rest_enabled = true
algorithm = "AES-256-GCM"
key_rotation_days = 90
key_source = "kms"  # or "vault", "local"

Key rotation limits exposure from compromised keys.

Encryption in Transit:

Enforce TLS for all connections:

[security.tls]
min_version = "1.3"
cipher_suites = ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256"]
verify_client_cert = true

Strong cipher suites prevent cryptographic attacks.

Role-Based Access Control:

Define granular permissions:

[security.rbac]
enabled = true
default_role = "viewer"

[security.rbac.roles.admin]
permissions = ["*"]

[security.rbac.roles.operator]
permissions = ["deploy:create", "deploy:update", "deploy:delete"]

[security.rbac.roles.viewer]
permissions = ["deploy:list", "deploy:read"]

Principle of least privilege limits blast radius.

Multi-Factor Authentication:

Require MFA for sensitive operations:

[security.mfa]
enabled = true
provider = "totp"  # or "duo", "okta"
require_for_operations = ["deploy:delete", "user:create"]

Prevents unauthorized access from stolen credentials.

IP Restriction Policies:

Restrict administrative access:

[security.ip_restriction]
admin_allowlist = ["10.0.0.0/8", "203.0.113.42/32"]
enforce_for_api = true
enforce_for_cli = true

Geographic restrictions:

[security.geo_restriction]
allowed_countries = ["US", "CA"]
block_tor_exit_nodes = true
block_vpn_providers = false

Rate Limiting:

Prevent brute force attacks:

[security.rate_limiting]
login_attempts_per_hour = 10
api_requests_per_minute = 100
penalty_duration_minutes = 30

Session Management:

Secure session configuration:

[security.sessions]
max_duration_hours = 8
idle_timeout_minutes = 30
require_reauth_for_sensitive = true
single_session_per_user = false

Sessions expire after inactivity period.

Command Authorization:

Require approval for dangerous operations:

[security.authorization]
require_approval = ["deploy:delete", "config:update"]
approvers_required = 2
approver_roles = ["admin", "senior-operator"]

Two-person rule prevents accidental damage.

Vulnerability Scanning:

Automatic security scanning:

[security.scanning]
container_scanning = true
dependency_scanning = true
scan_frequency = "daily"
fail_on_critical = true

Integration with security tools:

[security.integrations]
trivy_enabled = true
snyk_api_key = "${SNYK_API_KEY}"

Security Headers:

Configure HTTP security headers:

[security.headers]
strict_transport_security = "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains"
content_security_policy = "default-src 'self'"
x_frame_options = "DENY"
x_content_type_options = "nosniff"

Prevents common web attacks.

Secret Scanning:

Detect accidentally committed secrets:

[security.secret_scanning]
enabled = true
patterns = ["api_key", "password", "private_key"]
alert_on_detection = true

Integration with GitGuardian or similar tools.

Security Policies:

Enforce organizational policies:

[security.policies]
password_min_length = 16
password_require_special = true
password_expiry_days = 90
account_lockout_attempts = 5

Compliance Certifications:

Meet certification requirements:

[security.compliance]
soc2_mode = true
hipaa_mode = false
pci_dss_mode = false

Mode enables required controls automatically.

title: Next Steps After Getting Started
body:
You've installed NovaCLI, authenticated, and created your first deployment. This guide points you toward intermediate topics to continue your learning journey.

Configuration Deep Dive:

Explore advanced configuration options beyond basic deployment creation. Learn about TOML configuration files, environment-specific settings, and configuration profiles. See the Configuration section of the documentation.

Key topics:
- Custom TOML config structure
- Environment variable overrides
- Profile management for multiple accounts
- Performance tuning parameters

API Integration:

NovaCLI interacts with the Nova REST API. Understanding API endpoints helps when building custom integrations or debugging issues. Review the API Reference documentation.

Important endpoints:
- Deployment management
- Authentication and authorization
- Metrics and monitoring
- Billing and usage

Security Hardening:

Production deployments require security best practices. Learn about authentication methods, network isolation, encryption, and audit logging.

Security checklist:
- Enable multi-factor authentication
- Configure IP allowlists
- Use certificate-based auth for automation
- Enable audit logging
- Rotate credentials regularly
- Review access permissions quarterly

Monitoring and Observability:

Set up monitoring to track deployment health, performance metrics, and potential issues. Configure alerting for proactive incident response.

Monitoring tools:
- nova deploy stats for real-time metrics
- nova logs for application and system logs
- Third-party integrations (Prometheus, Datadog, etc.)
- Custom alerting rules

Backup and Disaster Recovery:

Protect your data with backup strategies. Understand backup retention, point-in-time recovery, and cross-region replication.

Backup strategy:
- Automated daily backups (enabled by default)
- Manual snapshots before major changes
- Cross-region backup copies for critical data
- Test restoration procedures regularly

Continuous Integration:

Integrate NovaCLI into CI/CD pipelines for automated testing and deployment. Use Docker images and environment variables for reproducible builds.

CI/CD patterns:
- GitHub Actions workflows
- GitLab CI configurations
- Jenkins pipeline scripts
- Automated testing against ephemeral deployments

Troubleshooting:

Learn diagnostic techniques for common issues. Understand log analysis, performance profiling, and when to contact support.

Troubleshooting resources:
- nova deploy debug command
- Log level adjustment
- Performance metrics interpretation
- Support ticket submission

Community Resources:

Join the NovaCLI community for tips, examples, and support from other users.

Community channels:
- Discussion forums
- GitHub issues and examples
- Monthly webinars
- Documentation feedback

title: API Compliance and Data Privacy
body:
The NovaCLI API implements comprehensive compliance controls and data privacy features to meet regulatory requirements. This reference covers GDPR, SOC 2, data residency, and privacy controls.

GDPR Compliance:

Data processing agreement:

Access DPA:
GET /legal/dpa

Download signed DPA for records.

Data controller vs processor:
- NovaCLI: Data processor
- Customer: Data controller
- Responsibilities clearly defined

Right to Access:

Export user data:

GET /gdpr/data-export
Authorization: Bearer USER_TOKEN

Returns comprehensive data export:
- User profile
- Deployment configurations
- Audit logs
- API usage
- Billing records

Format: JSON or CSV
Delivery: Download link (expires 7 days)

Right to be Forgotten:

Delete user data:

DELETE /gdpr/user-data
Authorization: Bearer USER_TOKEN
{
  "confirm": true,
  "reason": "GDPR data subject request"
}

Deletion scope:
- User profile
- Personal identifiable information
- Optional: Deployments and backups
- Retained: Anonymized audit logs (legal requirement)

Processing time: 30 days
Confirmation: Email notification

Data Rectification:

Correct inaccurate data:

PATCH /users/me
{
  "email": "mailto:corrected@email.com",
  "name": "Corrected Name"
}

Data Portability:

Export in machine-readable format:

GET /gdpr/data-export?format=json

Standard format for migration to competitors.

SOC 2 Compliance:

SOC 2 Type II certification:

Certification details:
GET /compliance/soc2

Returns:
- Certificate validity
- Audit report (summary)
- Control objectives
- Compliance status

Full report: Available under NDA for enterprise customers

Controls implemented:
- Access controls
- Encryption at rest and in transit
- Change management
- Incident response
- Business continuity
- Vendor management

Data Residency:

Regional data storage:

Specify data location:

POST /deployments
{
  "name": "eu-deployment",
  "region": "eu-west-1",
  "data_residency": {
    "require_eu_storage": true,
    "allow_replication": false
  }
}

Available regions:
- EU: eu-west-1, eu-central-1
- US: us-east-1, us-west-2
- APAC: ap-southeast-1, ap-northeast-1

Data sovereignty:
- Data stays in specified region
- No cross-border transfers
- Compliant with local regulations

Encryption:

At rest:
- AES-256 encryption
- Encrypted database volumes
- Encrypted backups
- Key management via KMS

In transit:
- TLS 1.3
- Perfect forward secrecy
- Strong cipher suites
- Certificate pinning available

Verify encryption:

GET /deployments/{id}/encryption-status

Response:

{
  "at_rest": true,
  "algorithm": "AES-256-GCM",
  "key_rotation": "automatic",
  "last_rotated": "2024-09-01T00:00:00Z"
}

Data Retention:

Configure retention policies:

PUT /deployments/{id}/retention
{
  "backups_days": 90,
  "logs_days": 30,
  "metrics_days": 365,
  "audit_logs_days": 2555  // 7 years for compliance
}

Automatic deletion:
- Data deleted after retention period
- Secure erasure methods
- Confirmation notifications
- Retention for legal compliance

Access Logs:

Comprehensive audit trail:

GET /audit-logs

Tracks:
- API access
- Data modifications
- User actions
- Authentication events
- Configuration changes

Retention: 7 years (compliance requirement)
Format: Immutable, timestamped logs

Privacy Controls:

Data minimization:

GET /deployments?fields=id,name

Request only necessary data.

Purpose limitation:
- Data used only for specified purposes
- Documented in privacy policy
- User consent required

Storage limitation:
- Retain only as long as necessary
- Automatic deletion policies
- Regular data reviews

Compliance Certifications:

Available certifications:
- SOC 2 Type II
- ISO 27001
- GDPR compliant
- HIPAA available (Enterprise)
- PCI DSS Level 1

Request certificates:
GET /compliance/certificates

Data Processing Addendum:

Customer DPA:

Access and sign DPA:
- Available in dashboard
- Required for EU customers
- Defines processing terms
- Outlines security measures

Subprocessors:

List of subprocessors:
GET /legal/subprocessors

Notification: 30 days before new subprocessor

Incident Response:

Data breach notification:

Timeline:
- Detection: Real-time monitoring
- Assessment: Within 24 hours
- Notification: Within 72 hours
- Remediation: Immediate

Notification includes:
- Nature of breach
