- Affected data
- Mitigation steps
- Contact information

title: API Versioning and Deprecation Policy
body:
The Nova REST API uses explicit versioning to ensure backward compatibility while enabling innovation. Understanding the versioning strategy helps you plan upgrades and avoid breaking changes.

Version Format:

API versions are specified in the URL path:

GET https://api.nova.io/api/v3/deployments

The current version is v3, released alongside NovaCLI v3.0 in June 2024. Each major CLI release typically introduces a new API version.

Supported Versions:

Nova maintains three API versions simultaneously:

- v3 (current): Full support, all new features
- v2 (maintenance): Security fixes only, no new features
- v1 (deprecated): Security fixes for critical vulnerabilities only

Version Lifecycle:

Each API version follows a predictable lifecycle:

1. Active (18 months): Full support, new features, bug fixes
2. Maintenance (12 months): Security fixes only, no new endpoints or features
3. Deprecated (6 months): Critical security fixes only, sunset warnings in API responses
4. Sunset: Version removed, requests return 410 Gone

Deprecation Warnings:

When using deprecated features or versions, API responses include warning headers:

X-Nova-Deprecation: This endpoint will be removed on 2025-06-10. Migrate to /api/v3/deployments.

Monitor these warnings in your logs to identify migration tasks.

Breaking vs Non-Breaking Changes:

Within a major version, Nova only makes non-breaking changes:

- Adding new endpoints (non-breaking)
- Adding optional request parameters (non-breaking)
- Adding response fields (non-breaking)
- Removing or renaming endpoints (breaking, requires new major version)
- Changing required parameters (breaking)
- Changing response field types (breaking)

Migration Support:

When new API versions are released, Nova provides:

- Migration guides documenting all breaking changes
- Parallel support for old and new versions during the migration window
- CLI commands to test against new versions: nova api-version set v4

Best Practices:

Use explicit version numbers in all API calls. Monitor deprecation warnings in production. Plan upgrades during the Active support window before features enter Maintenance. Subscribe to the API changelog at http://changelog.nova.io for version announcements.

title: Resolving Data Corruption Issues
body:
Data corruption is rare but serious, requiring immediate attention to prevent data loss. NovaCLI v3.1 provides detection and recovery tools for corruption scenarios.

Detecting Corruption:

Corruption symptoms include:

- Unexpected query errors: "invalid page header"
- Deployment crash and restart loops
- Inconsistent query results
- Backup failures with integrity errors

Run integrity checks:

nova deploy check-integrity deployment-id

This scans all data files for corruption and reports affected tables.

Common Causes:

Data corruption typically results from:

- Hardware failures (disk errors, memory errors)
- Improper shutdowns or crashes during writes
- Storage system issues
- Software bugs

Immediate Actions:

When corruption is detected:

1. Stop writes to prevent further damage
2. Create an immediate backup (if possible)
3. Document error messages and affected tables
4. Contact support with diagnostic information

Partial Recovery:

For isolated corruption, recover affected tables from backups:

nova backup restore backup-id --target deployment-id --tables affected_table

This restores only the corrupted table, preserving other data.

Full Recovery:

If corruption is widespread, restore from the most recent clean backup:

nova backup list deployment-id
nova backup restore backup-id --target deployment-id

Verify backup integrity before restoring:

nova backup verify backup-id

Rebuilding Indexes:

Index corruption is more common than data corruption. Rebuild affected indexes:

nova deploy reindex deployment-id --table affected_table

For all indexes:

nova deploy reindex deployment-id --all

Reindexing can take significant time on large tables but runs online without blocking reads.

Preventing Corruption:

Minimize corruption risk:

- Enable automatic backups with appropriate frequency
- Use redundant storage tiers (RAID, replicated storage)
- Monitor hardware health metrics
- Avoid force-killing deployment processes
- Keep NovaCLI and deployment software updated

Data Validation:

Implement application-level checksums for critical data. Periodically validate checksums to detect corruption early:

nova deploy query deployment-id --query "SELECT * FROM critical_table WHERE checksum != calculate_checksum(data)"

title: Security Advisory: CVE-2024-12345 Patched in v3.1.2
body:
A security vulnerability has been identified and patched in NovaCLI v3.1.2. All users are strongly encouraged to upgrade immediately.

Vulnerability Details:

CVE-2024-12345: Credential Exposure in Log Files

Severity: High (CVSS 7.5)

Affected Versions:
- NovaCLI v3.0.0 through v3.1.1
- NovaCLI v2.0.0 through v2.6.0

Unaffected Versions:
- NovaCLI v3.1.2 and later
- NovaCLI v1.x (end of life)

Description:

Under specific conditions, authentication tokens could be inadvertently written to debug log files when verbose logging is enabled. If an attacker gains access to these log files, they could extract valid API tokens and gain unauthorized access to deployments.

Exploit Conditions:

- Verbose logging must be enabled (--verbose flag or DEBUG log level)
- Log files must be accessible to attacker
- Affects CLI operations involving authentication refresh

Mitigation:

Immediate Actions:

1. Upgrade to patched version:
   - v3.1.x users: upgrade to v3.1.2
   - v2.x users: upgrade to v2.6.1

2. Rotate API tokens:
   nova auth list-tokens
   nova auth revoke-token old-token-id
   nova auth create-token --name "Replacement Token"

3. Review log files for exposed credentials:
   grep -r "Bearer " ~/.nova/logs/

4. Audit access logs for suspicious activity:
   nova account audit-log --since 30d

Patch Details:

The v3.1.2 patch implements:
- Token redaction in all log outputs
- Enhanced credential scrubbing in error messages
- Secure log file permissions enforcement
- Additional security headers in API requests

Workaround for Unpatched Systems:

If immediate upgrade is not possible:
- Disable verbose logging
- Restrict log file permissions: chmod 600 ~/.nova/logs/*
- Monitor access to log directories
- Rotate tokens frequently

Credits:

This vulnerability was responsibly disclosed by security researcher Jane Chen. Nova thanks Jane for her responsible disclosure.

Contact:

For questions: mailto:security@nova.io
For support: https://support.nova.io
